title: Gotham Steel 9.5 Inch Non Stick Frying Pans, Frying Pans Nonstick Skillet, Healthy and Non Toxic Ceramic Pan for Cooking, Nonstick Frying Pan, Oven Safe Skillet, Dishwasher Safe - Copper
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Almost nonstick', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This is a great frying pan for the size and apparent avoidance of any consequences from synthetic materials - it is not quite nonstick though, everything will stick to it a little bit from eggs to browning the meat but it’s not terrible, only directly under the burner. Overall it heats fairly evenly, probably about 60% around the edges versus 100% directly underneath the burner. Pretty easy cleanup, seems durable.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 24, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Amazing! Excellent Non-Stick Titanium Ceramic Frying Pans!', 'author': 'Vinny P.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Quick Update, as of March 26, 2017:It is now almost 10 months since I ordered these pans. After having owned these pans for over 9 months now, I can say that the two pans are still performing so well that if I could give this product ten (10) stars instead of the maximum 5 stars currently allowed by Amazon, I would do so.Perhaps the strangest thing about these two pans is that starting about a month after I had first purchased them, everyone in the house -- including even our overnight visitors -- stopped using all of the other frying pans in the house (most of them well-conditioned cast iron pans, and also one teflon-coated pan) and also ceased using stainless steel pots to quickly heat food or to reheat leftover meals from the fridge, and instead switched to solely using these two pans, simply because nothing ever sticks to them (ever see how badly egg and cheese omelet leftovers stick to a stainless steel pot if you try to use if for reheating them? ... it is quite gross, whereas if you put that same food in one of these ceramic coated pans, it reheats quickly with ZERO sticking!).So, I, along with everyone else in my house, love these pans more than ever now that we have been using them each many times per day for nearly a year!Simply amazing pans! They are truly nonstick!My Original ReviewI purchased two of these Gotham Steel non-stick titanium ceramic frying pans, one in the 9.5" diameter size and one in the 12.5" diameter size, a few weeks ago. I am a trained scientist and engineer, and thus i am not easily amazed by consumer kitchenware products that claim to be non-stick. However, I am amazed by the performance of these pans after 3.5 weeks of having used them daily.I want to briefly mention that I was an early adapter/user of the so-called non-stick ceramic frying pan technology back around 2010 when the very first generation of "non-stick" ceramic frying pans hit the market. I bought one of those early first-generation products back in late 2010 -- it was a "Green" brand frying pan bearing a so-called "green" so-called non-stick ceramic surface. That pan turned out to be horrible from the very first use; everything stuck to it, and when I complained to the "Green" manufacturer,, they acknowledged the problem, and advised that I condition the pan, using hot oil and an oven, in the same fashion that a cast iron pan is conditioned, to try to make it more non-stick, Needless to say, I immediately abandoned that first-generation "non-stick" ceramic frying pan, and resolved to wait at least 5 to 6 years before purchasing another non-stick ceramic pan so that the ceramic technology could mature over the years.Indeed, my purchase of the two Gotham Steel pans in late July of 2016, about 4 weeks ago, came about only because I was convinced, after having done some careful research on the web, that the non-stick ceramic frying pan technology had matured greatly over the past 6 years. It is my impression that the non-stick ceramic pans currently on the market -- including the Gotham Steel titanium ceramic pans -- are using approximately sixth-generation non-stick ceramic technology, and it appeared from my research that this latter-generation non-stick ceramic technology was far better than the first-generation product that I had tried back in 2010..Each of these pans has seen use multiple times per day since they arrived here about 3+ weeks ago, and they are still performing perfectly. Nothing ever sticks to the pan surface to any noticeable degree, and post-cooking cleanup of the pans takes just a few seconds, because nothing ever sticks. I am quite amazed at the performance of these two pans.Incidentally, I regularly use sharp-edged metal utensils in these pans, including using a steak knife to slice Italian sausages while in the pan, and neither of the pans shows even the faintest scratch marks!My only cautionary note, if you are considering purchasing one of these fine pans, is that it is very important to never allow the temperature of the cooking surface on the bottom of the pan to exceed 500 degrees F; this upper temperature limit is also firmly and clearly noted in the product information provided with the pan by the manufacturer. It is also very important to never allow cooked foods to dry out and burn onto the pan surface, nor to allow cooked foods to dry and harden on the pan.For full transparency, I want to disclose that I purchased each of these two Gotham Steel pans at their full listed price on Amazon Prime Marketplace. This review reflects my honest experience and opinion in having used these pans on a regular basis.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 26, 2016', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Non stick feature is questionable', 'author': 'M. Downing', 'rating': 4, 'content': "I cooked eggs with the pan on my first use and the non-stick feature worked beautifully. The eggs slid right out of the pan. I cleaned it in my dishwasher once and on the second use the eggs stuck to the pan and I needed to use a spatula. I bought this pan because it said you could use it in the dishwasher but it seems that this may truly affect the non-stick surface. I still give this pan 4 out of 5 stars because it cleans up better than any pan I've ever seen. I've since gone back to cooking spray and my eggs slide out once again.I would recommend this pan if you don't mind using cooking spray or olive oil. Knowing what I know now, I would still purchase this pan again.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 11, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars ~ Great product ~', 'author': 'McKenna Grace Fisher', 'rating': 5, 'content': '~ Best pan ever ~ I have used this to make my Just Out eggs and it cooks them very well ~ Easy to clean too ~', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 21, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Worth the cost', 'author': 'Kamyar M', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Bought it for some eggs, and they were pretty good, just have to avoid the oil splashes, but that doesn’t matter much, it’s pretty useful.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 11, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love GS Products', 'author': 'Julie Ann', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'My bf and I have really gotten into Gotham Steel products (have the draining pasta pot and just got the panini maker), and this one is another high quality product. It cooks and cleans like a dream, and we like that it has a hanging hook. We were concerned the handle would get too hot without any rubber grip but so far there have been no issues at all.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 20, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "3.0 out of 5 stars Non-stick capability doesn't last", 'author': 'Dick Davis', 'rating': 3, 'content': "This was a replacement for another Gotham Steel skillet we ruined. The instructions said to not use cooking spray. For the first few weeks, it worked fine. We used medium to low heat as instructed and never had a sticking problem. After awhile food was beginning to stick so we started using cooking spray out of necessity. It's OK with spray. The TV ads are true, at the beginning.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 6, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Great for 6 months.', 'author': 'pam rathbun', 'rating': 3, 'content': "The nonstick worked great for several months. Pans were well priced and easy to clean. Now, 7 months after purchase (with frequent use) they need to be replaced (nonstick is largely gone requiring lots of butter for making eggs). Unlike the post on Amazon, the pan's packaging says that it cannot be in the oven higher than 400 and can only be used at low heat on the stove top. Decent but not great for longterm use.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 27, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Bottom of pan', 'author': 'R. A.', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'Make sure you remove the sticker from the bottom of the pan (who thought this was a good idea). I have several Gotham Steel pans. My 11" pan wore out after 3 years. When I replaced it I realized the new 11" pan wasn\'t the same shape. It\'s weirdly smaller with less volume. I returned it for the 12.5" pan. This pan had the sticker on the bottom. Also, the handle is different. It\'s not rounded, the edges of the handle are a bit squared off and feel sharp when lifting a pan full of food.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 14, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Good nonstick skillet', 'author': 'J. Wagner', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'Second time I got one. The first one did eventually get some scratches but I think someone in home hold used wrong utensil. Very easy to clean.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 3, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

title: T-fal Ultimate Hard Anodized Nonstick Fry Pan Set 10, 12 Inch Oven Safe 400F Cookware, Pots and Pans, Dishwasher Safe Grey
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Very happy with the quality and durability of these nonstick pans. Great value.', 'author': 'DaveyB', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I first purchased these pans over 1.5 year ago and they still have their nonstick properties. I am very pleased that these have lasted over time better than other more expensive nonstick pans I have purchased in the past.I like that these pans are not ultra-thin, but yet don't have so much weight to them that they are slow to heat up like some of the more expensive cookwear brands. I find that they strike a nice balance between being relatively lightweight and fast to heat up, yet not so thin that they feel cheap or don't spread the heat evenly throughout the pan.I was pleased with this product enough that I ended up purchasing it a second time when my mother needed a new set of nonstick pans. Highly recommended for ease of use, durability, and value.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 5, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent cookware set - easy to use AND clean', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'The pans are truly nonstick and conduct heat very well for even cooking. I have now had this set for 1.5 years and seen no wear or decrease in quality. I purchased this set because my husband hates hand-washing dishes and insisted on a set that was dishwasher-safe. I was skeptical, but we regularly wash these in the dishwasher and have had only one issue (see below). In addition - when I do choose to hand wash them, food slides off very easily.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 2, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars EXCEPTIONAL PRODUCT - UPDATE', 'author': 'Cardione1', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'We all have some of these: chipped, scratched pots and pans that wobble on a range because of being WARPED. I\'ve had enough with my pans and began research on cookeware sets. I will note here that my current cookware is the high end non-stick, with my fry pans being those bought after watching some fool on TV melt candy in a wrapper in the pan and then wiping it clean. (These pans by the way are only 8 months old and are already WARPED). For new cookware, my ONE main requirement was that they were or would be NON-WARPING. The second requirement was that they be non-stick. After some research I settled on the 14 piece of T-Fal non-stick / non-warp set. Item came well packaged and unpacking the items I was impressed with the feel of each piece: not too heavy or light even with a lid. I also noted the non-stick interior surface and the very nice looking anodized exterior. Very nice touch with the vented lids (an actual hole in the glass) and the FULL insulation of the handles. Now I mention this insulation because I have (had) cookware items that had decorative (?) metal ends on the handles that would occasionally get very warm while being used.( Nothing like grabbing a pot or pan handle that want to cook your hand medium rare.) I washed each piece and WITHOUT SEASONING, took the largest frying pan, placed it on the range on MED HEAT (about 5-6 on an electric glass top range) and let it heat up. After 2-3 minutes, I noted that the T-FAL center emblem in the pan really didn\'t look like it changed much. I expected it to go from the T-FAL logo to a full red dot. Didn\'t happen but it was no biggie as in the past several months I began preheating my fry pans for about 3 minutes due to their warped exterior. Next I added magarine as I was going to cook sunnyside up eggs. I was impressed to note that the margarine melted quickly AND when spread about the pan, little bubbles began to show up over the ENTIRE pan surface. This meant that the pan was heating up evenly. In went the eggs and after placing a lid on the pan I turned away to get something off the counter. Now, with my older warped fry pans I could do this same act, return to the range and begin to slowly rotate the pan to get even heating on the eggs. Not so with this T-Fal fry pan. I noted the whites turning opaque quickly and the yolks getting their whitish color meaning they would be just slightly runny. In short, these eggs came out perfect and in well over 1/2 the time from my old cookware. Even my other half was impressed. Now my next "adventures in cooking" will involve sautéing, making my alfredo sauce, grilling (this set came with a VERY NICE grill pan!) and frying. So far I am following the instructions by keeping the range heat at MED or just a bit more. Noted is that one foray into frying eggs does not provide enough experience with this cookware to turn cartwheels in the kitchen. But so far, with eggs being one of my more difficult items to make because of my other warped pans with uneven heat, this T-Fal pan is impressive. So, my rating of 4 is tentative as I will update this review within a short time after I try other pieces of this set.UPDATE:First this disclaimer: I HAVE NOT and AM NOT an employee of T-Fal or Amazon, and I have NOT been hired to write a raving review. That said, now for the update. I have had this set now for over a month and have used all but one of the pans. The total experience has been incredible. I cook out of self-defense (the other half is banned by the EPA from boiling water) and am pretty fast in the kitchen when I am cooking.- WEIGHT OF PANS: I thought the pans were a bit on the light side until I started using them. Whether it was thought of during design or not, the pans are heavy enough to withstand various cooking requirements but light enough where you don\'t break your wrist when lifting.- NON STICK SURFACE: Come on now! Who in their right mind melts plastic spoons or uses an electric beater on their non-stick cookware! I believe surface of this T-Fal would take this abuse with no problem, but I happen to like my food without the taste of plastic. I\'ve used nearly all the pans and found them all to be amazingly non-stick as well as sturdy. I still use butter/olive oil when sautéing or frying. I have had nothing stick to the pans nor have any of these pans lost any of their non-stick capability.- HEATING: This is the BEST part of this cookware. If you cook/have cooked with slightly warped cookware, you know the problem with hot heat spots or very little heat at all. Thus, you have to move the pan around a bit to get yours items cooked. Each of the pans in this T-Fal set has VERY even heat distribution. There is a "plate" on the bottom of the pans that distributes the heat evenly. I have found that because of this, I\'ve noted shorter cooking times on various items AND I now cook on a lower heat settings NOTE: This T-Fal cookware set will cause you to change how your cook and for how long. The even heat distribution is stunning. ALSO, I do preheat my pans (except for boiling water) and use only wooden or high heat tolerant silicone utensils..- STORAGE OF THE COOKWARE: I don\'t stack this cookware. Instead I hang it up. This simply helps prolong the life of my investment.Overall, I am very impressed with this cookware. Even my other half (known for making ANGRY little pellets called hamburgers), has begun to learn that this cookware can even make her a decent cook. And yes, I bit on the late night adverts showing the frying pans melting plastic spoons and candy in wrappers and magically not sticking. I bought 3. Within 90 days they either lost their non-stick capability, began to warp, or both.Some people are gourmet cooks; others have trouble boiling water. This cookware will holdup very well and serve both very well. My motto is that you get what you pay for. And you WILL get more than you\'ve paid for this set. I raise my rating to 5 stars and I do recommend as a BUY.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 29, 2018', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Durable, affordable, and versatile.', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Gotta hand it to T-Fal for making an absolutely marvelous cookware set that easily rivals other nonstick sets in the $400-500 range. This is a very attractive cookware set, and functions flawlessly. Non-stick MEANS non-stick, and cleanup is a breeze. The weight and thickness of the cookware is excellent, they truly feel durable and sturdy in every way. I discovered this line from T-Fal about 7 years ago and I honestly would rather buy their sets than Wolfgang Puck, Martha Stewart, or whatever fad brand of nonstick comes along next season.NOTE: these pans will tolerate softer wood utensils like Bamboo, but you should always use silicone or plastic when possible. Metal utensils will chip and scratch, same as any nonstick. Even so, this set is VERY scratch resistant and will last for many years with proper care.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 19, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars I definitely recommend this set', 'author': 'Devin Watson', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'Great product. Nice and durable, heat is evenly distributed, and not easily scratched. Can take awhile to heat on an electric stove,not sure about gas type one. But great product overall I recommend.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 25, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Nice set of pots and pans', 'author': 'K. Gee', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I had my last pots and pan for around 10 year. The non stick started to peel. I checked reviews and these seemed to have decent reviews and a good price. They are nice quality and not super heavy but they’re sturdy. Food cooks evenly and they are easy to clean.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 30, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Initial Impression', 'author': 'Mitchell V. Rader Jr.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I\'m doing an initial review of this cookware set. As it\'s being used, my intention is to come back to this review with updates.I ordered this set after doing a bit of \'googling\' on what is the best cookware set for 2019 - I wanted something for our gas range. I think it\'s something to take into consideration when choosing what you\'re going to buy. An example - on a gas range - if the setting is high and your cookware has some sort of enamel-like finish, and the flames are coming over the sides of the pot/pan - it\'s going to discolor the finish after a period of time.I looked at the top 10 bracket, the top 5 bracket, I went to reviews, Good Housekeeping, Consumer Reports, just to name two of several, and surprisingly (at least for me) T-Fal was a set that kept popping up as one of the best. I\'ve always thought of T-Fal as one of those starter cookware sets that someone might purchase when they\'re moving into their first apartment and starting out on their own - it is/was inexpensive - a set for a person learning to cook and therefore not requiring something more \'higher-end.\' If you have/had those thoughts as well, you might want to set them aside, at least with this set..Upon pulling everything out of the box my first impression was they look really nice. The set is light weight - the handles are riveted, silicone encased and can withstand up to 400 degree oven temperature. The lids are heavy tempered glass, each one having a small vent hole, and the handles are also silicone encased as well. The design of the lid-handles seems to take into account the use of pot holders since there\'s substantial space between the glass and the handle itself. All of the lids in my set fit nicely onto their respective pot/pan - no warpage or bent rims. The pots/pans are dishwasher safe (mine aren\'t going to see the inside of a dishwasher), and this particular set you can use metal utensils (I personally ain\'t-a-gonna do it). It comes with a steamer that is designed to stack on top of the large pot (not the dutch oven). When you\'re done steaming, grab some pot holders and lift the insert out by it\'s handles - no muss, no fuss. It\'s a much better option than the collapsible steamer I currently using.It comes with instructions on how to care for your cookware. READ THE INSTRUCTIONS! Why you may ask? This set is replacing a Calphalon set, and yes Calphalon was/is rated highly as well. But why replace it? Because being the knuckle head that I am, I didn\'t read the instructions. I knew Calphalon had to be hand washed (at least the set that I own) - but what I didn\'t know was what high heat does to the pots. When you read the instructions for T-Fal, and because it\'s aluminum, it\'ll say something to the effect of using low to medium heat (because aluminum conducts heat really well). See … I didn\'t know that about anodized aluminum and what I ended up doing was burning the finish off of each pot and skillet bottom of my Calphalon set - right down to the bare aluminum and of course this affected the non-stick surface on the inside. So please, read and follow the instructions. One other thing before I wrap this up. When I was doing my \'research\' I came across this one video of an owner showing how an empty T-Fal pot didn\'t sit level on her stove. Seems the handle was heavy enough that it caused the pot to tip. She said this was a problem - and I guess it could be if you\'re in the process of putting something inside the pot in preparation of cooking. I do get that - but I placed an empty pot on the stove, centered over the burner, and it sat just fine - although I\'ll say my stove grate is different than the stove in the video - it also sat level on the counter top. Perhaps this might be something to take into consideration???So initial impression is the set seems to be of good quality, looks nice, and I\'m looking forward to putting this set through it\'s paces.UPDATE:As of December 4, 2019 I have to say that the T-Fal set has held up extremely well - cooking with this set is a breeze. I keep the burner setting usually at med-high if I want to bring something to a boil - and it doesn\'t take long for that to happen. The pots and pans conduct heat really well and there\'s practically no sticking. Usually I can pretty-much rinse off any food residue left behind using just running hot water. I\'m pretty good at using either wooden or silicon-type utensils when cooking, though on occasion I\'ve used metal spoons to stir, and there are no marks inside any of the pots/pans. I\'m not one of those cooks adept enough to shift a pan around and flip the contents briefly into the air (my cool-factor is not that high) so "skating" the bottom of a pot/pan over the cast-iron grate has not taken place, so I can\'t say what would happen to this set if I were to do so. If I were to hazard a guess, I would say that more than likely there would be some marring of the bottom since cast iron probably trumps aluminum. Overall I\'m very please with this purchase and the performance of this cook set.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States April 9, 2019', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love this set. Great purchase', 'author': 'JimmyD', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Bought this to replace one of those as-seen-on-TV copper cookware sets. Over about 4 years the copper set lost most of it's nonstick ability.This set so far has been pretty amazing. Heats up quickly and evenly. I've got a glass cooktop and I've found that setting the burners to 3 or 4 is more than hot enough to cook. Absolutely no need to crank that burner up to HIGH.Nothing sticks to the pan, super easy to clean. I refuse to put these in the dishwasher. I've threatened bodily harm to anyone in my household that tries to cook on high heat or stick these in the dishwasher. Cooking is a joy again.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 5, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Superb Cookware', 'author': 'revkenq', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I wanted to wait at least a couple after my initial purchase to write a review, since writing an immediate review offers little information as to the durability of the product. I purchased my first T-Fal set of pots and pans nearly 45 years ago, and never regretted the decision, just as I\'ve not regretted this one. After several months of use, the pots and pans looks as they did when I purchased them, no discoloring, and no scratches. The only thing that is slightly affected is the bottom of the pans where they are frequently slid back and forth over the stove top burner. Of course, this poses no problem for me, as I\'m not concerned about the bottom, and as stated, it\'s only slightly affected.One of the things that I really like about this set is the "weight" of them. They aren\'t lightest pots and pans, neither are they the heaviest. They are in fact, about medium weight and thickness. I suppose you could say they are in the "Goldie Locks" zone, in other words, the weight and thickness are "just right."As I am not always careful about storing my pots and pans, I decided with this set to purchase some pot and pans dividers/protectors which can be cut to size and placed on the inside surface of the pans to keep them from coming into contact with the other pots and pans, thus preventing accidental scratching, especially, if one tends to "toss" them into the cupboard, instead of gently laying them down.Everything about this T-Fal set is by and large "pros." However, there is one slight "con," and that is because of the way the bottom of the set is designed for optimum heat distribution, they are prone to sliding around on the stove top. This problem is solved easily enough by just holding onto the handle when stirring anything. It might seem like a small nuisance, but like anything, doing frequently, it will become a habit, and you will doing it without thinking about it. Actually, I would think this would be the safest way to stir things on the stove even if they didn\'t tend to slide a little.With this set, I did take the time to read quite a few of the reviews, and I was impressed to say the least. One video review showed a customer who had bought this same set about five years before, as well as the same set recently. I was quite impressed with the five-year old set as it looked brand new, except with a little wear on the bottom.Oh yes, there is one more "con," sort of, and that is there aren\'t lids for every pot and pans, in fact, there about half as many lids and there are pots and pans, although, each lid fit two pots or pans. So, if it were possible, I would purchase lids for all of them, despite the fact that it really isn\'t necessary seeing as most people only have four burners on their stove, and foods that had already been cooked would most likely have been placed into bowls. But, what if I didn\'t want to place it in a bowl, and wanted to set the whole thing aside with the lid on it? But alas, me thinks I will survive this great disadvantage.Obviously, a person could spend a lot more money on a set of pots and pans, but for everyday cooking, I don\'t think you could purchase a better set, at least, not for the money. Ken', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 16, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars A few things to be aware of', 'author': 'D Coombs', 'rating': 4, 'content': "SECOND UPDATEAfter about 4 years of use I continued to be VERY hapy with these pans. 0 problems with the non stick surface. I have replaced most of these pans with Hex Clad because of the hybrid characteristics (weight + non stick) of Hex Clad. After 4 years, these T-Fal are still better non-stick than the new hex-clad but I can use Hex Clad for all stainless / most non-stick purposes.Obviously the price point on Hex Clad is entirely different, this isn't meant to recomend Hex Clad over T-Fal, they both have their place! I still use a few of the T-Fal when I need something really really non-stick, I passed the rest of these pans to my adult children who are using them very happily. I would not hesitate to recomend these!UPDATEAfter a little less than 1 year of use the review remains largely unchanged. The only thing I would say is that the square gridles warped slightly early on. I use a gas range, and the warp is not bad enough to impact my use, but if these were used on a glass cooktop I expect that the griddles would be nearly unusable. The finish has not scratched or flaked or diminished in any way that I can perceive, I do NOT use metal utensils, and I always hand-wash. Some of the other reviews show pictures of the bottom of the pan with the finish rubbed off, I have not experienced this.I have two large T-fal frying pans I purchased from Costco, that I like very much. I had a set of Kirkland non-stick and a set of Circulon non-stick that I have had for about 12 years and 15 years respectively. I bought two of these sets to replace the two sets above. I thought that these pan sets were the same as the frying pans I bought at Costco based on the appearance in the picture. I have not rated these pans for scratch resistance because I have only had them for a few weeks. If they are as good as the T-Fal from Costco I expect they will do well, but I can't rate them yet.About 80% of the time I use cast iron or stainless steel. The good thing about those materials are heat retention and being able to handle high heat, both are not strong suits of most non-stick. Of course you can't use cast iron for acidic foods and stainless is tricky and you must use oil correctly to stop sticking, but both are very good for creating proper textures on food that need 'crusts' like steak, hash browns, grilled sandwiches, etc. Not related to this review, but if you like to cook, and haven't already, learn to use cast iron and stainless and get good products of each (copper inside of stainless for heat distribution).I use non-stick for things where non stick is important (like eggs) or when other characteristics, like heat retention, don't matter like Kraft mac and cheese (don't judge me), frozen corn/peas, warming bottled sauces and similar.The observations below are based on about 3 weeks of use. Some things that may appear 'negative' are generally assumptions on my part, and not misrepresentations in the listing.Things to know1- If you bought similar T-fal frying pans at Costco as I did, those pans are considerably heavier than the pans in this set, so heat retention in those pans are far better than in the pans in this set.2- I really like that the rivets are now teflon coated, this makes cleaning much easier. I mention the T-fal pans above that I purchased from Costco, I believe that they have the same coating, and I have had those pans for well over a year, and they clean VERY easily, better than either the Kirkland or the Circulon.3- These pans seem to distribute heat very well, but as soon as food hits the pan the, the lack of weight results in the pan cooling where the food is. This is why I rated heat distribution a 4 instead of a 5, and really is more of something to learn and understand than a negative.4- These pans seem to heat and boil water much faster than the two sets I mention above. This may be because of the heat distribution and the fact that not much energy is required to heat the pans themselves - just speculation on my part.5- Although I used Circulon for a long time, I find the ridges a negative in terms of non-stick performance anytime after the first few uses. Also, the ridges actually create inconsistent cooking in some uses, for instance, when cooking pancakes, you can actually see the ridge pattern in the pancakes instead of a consistent cook. Obviously the pans in this listing do not suffer from this as they have smooth surfaces.6- This set does not have a tall pan that I would call a 'stock pot'. Both of the sets that I mention above had a 8 to 10 quart tall pan that I will look to replace.7- The kirkland set had metal handles, so they could be placed in the oven without worrying. Although I think that the rubber handles on this set are rated up to some temperature, I still am not comfortable placing these in the oven. I knew I would loose this when I purchased these, and since I rarely use non-stick in the over, I wasn't too worried about it, but somethign to consider.8- If you hang your pans from a pot-rack, like I do, the handles are large, and the pans don't fit inside of each other really well. With the kirkland I could easily share one hook for two pans because the size and shape of the handles allowed for them to 'nest' on one hook, and the size of the pans, and length of the handles, allowed them to fit into each other well when hanging. Don't expect to be able to do this with these pans.9- This set does not have a large frying pan. I knew this and it didn't bother me because of the previously mentioned pans from Costco, but be aware that the size of the pans in this set are all relatively small.10- I would prefer that these pans be slightly heavier, but that is probably a subjective desire based on my experience and once I learn to account for the lack of weight in my cooking practices it will probably be OK.Overall I am mostly happy with the pans, and for what they are, they are very effective. I would probably not be happy with them as my only set of cookware because of the inability to put them in the oven and they characteristics I described based on the pan weight. If those things don't matter to you, I would rate these a 5.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 2, 2020', 'is_verified': True}]

title: GreenLife Soft Grip Healthy Ceramic Nonstick 7" and 10" Frying Egg Omeltte Pan Skillet Set, PFAS-Free, Dishwasher Safe, Turquoise
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars They are really non-stock', 'author': 'Consuelo T.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Love that food practically slips from the pan so it is so easy to cook on them and cleaning is a breeze. Also they are light and easy to handle', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 16, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The Last Non-Stick Pans You Will Ever Purchase', 'author': 'JK', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Over the years I have lost track of how many non-stick skillets I have purchased. It didn't matter how much they cost - in the end, they failed. On average, I probably spent $50 - $100 every year trying to secure a good non-stick pan.Then, my mom told me about GreenLife pans and sent me one. They are amazing and work time after time. Everything, even my fried eggs, slide off. However, I've discovered that by using a tiny drop of oil (light olive oil - not virgin), and I mean little (not more than 1/4 teaspoon is needed), no crispy film develops.I don't use EVOO with the pans. I've read some reviews which say it may stain the pan. I've had no problems using light olive oil.I also tried frying chicken with the larger pan yesterday and stir frying vegetables.It was okay! I (only dared) used medium heat only so it took much longer to cook than using my wok.My wok sticks easily when I cook chicken with it, but for this first use, I loved that it didn't stick with this pan at all!I unfortunately slightly overcooked the chicken, but found it still did not stick to the pan - yay!As it's not long since I've been using the pans, it will be interesting to see how long these favorable comments last!I do make sure I don't use EVOO or metal utensils, use low-medium heat only and I make sure I let pan cool before cleaning.Another tip I read and found useful was to use kitchen paper to wipe both sides of the pans after use and any unwanted dirt or marks come off so easily. Then I use a small amount of dish-washing liquid and water to clean with soft sponge after it has cooled.In terms of the vendor, I received these pans a week sooner than stated during ordering so shipping was fast!I was very concerned about buying ceramic products online for international shipping, but I couldn't find these anywhere in my country, so I thought I'd risk buying it here on Amazon. Out with all the teflon pans (which didn't seem as non-stick as these GreenLife ones anyway!) and at a reasonable price.As I say, it's early days yet though. It remains to be seen if the non-stick qualities fail after a few months (as it seems to have done for other buyers).", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 10, 2017', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Nice pans', 'author': 'LaDonna K', 'rating': 4, 'content': "I haven't bought myself pans in years but I wanted something stick free but safer than those teflon ones. Great though for the price point.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 27, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent skillets', 'author': 'Marilyn', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I like that the inside of the skillets are white and so slick. My mother's vision is not very good but she is enjoying cooking using these skillets.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 22, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars These Pans Are Great!', 'author': 'Sweet Angel', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'My local Publix sells Greenlife pans, and I really like them. I needed a new 10” pan after using mine for 8 years, saw the soft grip handle option here, and had to try it. I really like the feel of the handle as I’m cooking. I won’t lie, I’ve destroyed a few pans learning how to use them. Here is what I learned. First mistake, don’t use high heat with them. This lesson was hard to learn. It really doesn’t take a lot of heat to make these pans hot. Just above medium on my stove is enough to make it hot enough to fry with. If you go to a medium high or high heat on your stove, you will burn your food and ruin your pan. Stick to a low or medium heat. I also think the folks who were complaining of the handles melting were cooking on a high heat. Second mistake, don’t use any spray oils in the pan. Spray on oils like Pam will coat your skillet in an oil that will permanently stick to the ceramic, stain your pan, and destroy the natural non stick surface. Use regular oils like butter, olive oil, coconut oil or vegetable oil. Plus, just a tiny bit of oil will go a long way with the natural non-stick qualities of ceramic pans. If you over do the oil on too high a heat, you will destroy your pans. Third mistake, using metal tools on the skillet. I beat the hell out of my first skillet using a metal spatula. I switched to olive wood and bamboo tools, and they do great. They don’t scratch the surface at all. Fourth mistake, running water in the skillet while it is still hot. I ruined the surface by repeatedly doing that. I was thinking I needed to put it to soak, but learned that if I just let it cool, the food came right off when I washed it with a sponge and soap. I don’t have a dishwasher to know if that is good to do or not. Mine have always been hand washed. Are these pans going to last you the rest of your life? No, but they will last you several years if you use them properly, and at this price that’s not a bad deal.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 9, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars First actual nonstick pan ever', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I cook quite a bit and have owned several "nonstick" pans that needed oil or butter and still stole some of whatever I was cooking. title: SENSARTE Nonstick Deep Frying Pan Skillet, 10/11/12-inch Saute Pan with Lid, Stay-cool Handle, Chef Pan Healthy Stone Cookware Cooking Pan, Induction Compatible, PFOA Free (10-Inch)
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Sooo Non-Stick', 'author': 'Michaela Dotsch', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I've had this for a few weeks, and so far it's my favorite non-stick saute pan. A little water and soap, swish swish, and it's clean (because nothing sticks to it). The only *wish* I have would be an oven-safe version. If it wears out quickly I will come back and revise this review.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 27, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Used 40 times so far', 'author': 'DH2007', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'The thick bottom of this pan ensures even heat distribution, preventing hotspots and ensuring that your food cooks uniformly. The lids and handles have to be put together but they send a screwdriver to do the assembly (really easy).It\'s a bit on the heavy side, but I think that it will hold up longer because of that. They advise hand washing, which is fine if it\'s going to last longer that way.Fried up some ground beef it in for chili, and it heated very evenly, no sticking.I liked it so much I bought a set!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 6, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Beautiful Deep Frying Skillet That Handles Well', 'author': 'kenacious', 'rating': 4, 'content': "The pan is distinct looking, more so than the other standard dark brown-gray non-stick pan color. It is speckled and unique-looking. The faux wood handle is cool though evidently fake. I like that there are very few seams and nook/crannies that collect food debris, burnt stuff that makes it hard to clean. As noted in the description, the pan walls do not have rivets for the handle which makes cleaning this pan much more enjoyable. No more burnt schmutz around the rivet getting brown and nasty. The non-stick works well, I cannot complain about it. I like to turn my flame up to medium -high to almost high and it has held up without turning color on the cooking surface. It also has not gotten tacky/sticky from high heat use so far. Only time will tell. I will report back if it gets bad.We use the pan for stir-frying, making bacon, warming tortillas, pretty much everything. Nothing has stuck and it hasn't turned color. After much cooking in it, I will occasionally fry an egg without oil and it still comes out without sticking, though nothing makes things crisp up like a little oil in the pan. It seems to handle everything like a champ. It can go into the oven with moderate temps in the 300Fs. I haven't tried that yet, however. The lid fits well and works nicely. It has a round knob that screws into the lid so you do have to contend with the occasional loosening screw. I do prefer the metal U-shaped handles because of that. The drawback of the u-shaped handle is that you cannot lay the lid flat on its back like you can with the flat top round handle that comes with this one. It's personal preference.The pan is also lighter than my cast iron (as most pans will be) and we tend to use this more for everyday cooking though for searing meats and hamburgers, nothing beats the infernal heat you can inflict upon a cast iron pan.Overall, the pan seems much more high quality and unique than some of the common non-sticks out there. We are pretty rough with our cookware since they are used a great deal, so I will report back in a little while. It's a nice versatile pan for almost all of your cooking. Arnold', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I love to cook and I am ALWAYS looking for deep large fry / sauce pans that cook evenly and have no issues with food sticking to them with or without spray, oil or what have you.I have to say this is one of the best pans I EVER purchased online. This pan cooks food evenly, the entire surface heats thoroughly at the same temperature. The lid is heavy duty but not heavy. There is a pour spout that’s a perfect size. I will purchase more of these pans for certain….', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 2, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Loving my new skillet!', 'author': 'Danny', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I recently purchased the SENSARTE Nonstick Deep Frying Pan Skillet, specifically the 10-inch size, and I am extremely satisfied with my purchase. I appreciate the attention to detail in this aspect, as it adds to the overall user experience.Additionally, the SENSARTE Nonstick Deep Frying Pan Skillet is compatible with induction cooktops, which is a major advantage for those who have this type of stovetop. I remember buying a whole set of cookware for $30 when I was Young and starting out. It was all I could Afford. But you definitely get what you pay for with cookware. Get what you can afford, sure. But get one or two good quality pieces, in addition. They will become your go-to pieces. I will Buy more of these.. they are great quality for a reasonable price!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 28, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Compares to my favorite cast iron skillet', 'author': 'Maudie Bess', 'rating': 5, 'content': "There is a bit of a learning curve with this skillet. So, I'll share my experience that resulted in it becoming my second favorite skillet. First, read the instructions. Second, season the pan before using it like it's cast iron. For those who don't know this step. You rub the pan with oil and salt, and then heat it. Wipe with a soft cloth when cool. Third, add any butter or oil while the pan is cold and then heat it on medium before adding food. Then, adjust the temperature. Last, do not use dish liquid on the skillet. Wipe with a warm, wet cloth. I re-season all my skillets often. I recommend this skillet. Oh, and I like the draining lip on the rim.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 6, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars LOVE, LOVE, LOVE IT', 'author': 'John', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Absolutely non stick. I'm very happy with my purchase!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 29, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars superior value', 'author': 'Smudgemom', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'very reasonably priced, excellent quality. rated as one of best by independent reviewer. thought it might be cheaply made because price was so good- it’s very well made!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 4, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect little pan', 'author': 'KateLena', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I used to use teflon-coated pans but after living in a furnished place for a time, and using stainless, I bought new pans. This one is perfect, the right size for small meals, nice good weight, the heat is dispersed well, cooks well, and cleans up well. Trick I learned is to sit some water in the pan after it cools down a bit, and let it sit for an hour or so, and easy breezy removing everything that stuck to the pans. Use a bit of butter or cooking or olive oil and it cleans up very nicely. And to get it cleaned extra well, every so often I use Barkeepers Friend cleaner and it takes it back very nicely. I have a larger Cuisinart pan too, love them both. I cook everythin in them, rice in the small pan, and it cooks faster, spinach is perfect in the larger pan, do grilled chicken, vegetables, steak, making a cheeseburger with onions right now as I write this. It's perfect.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States June 29, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love this little fry pan!', 'author': 'Denver 5', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This little 8" mirror-finish pan is so pretty, I hung it on the wall. Very happy with it so far. Stainless pans require a technique for cooking that may be different from cooking in non-stick or cast iron. Heat up a couple tablespoons of water on medium heat. When that starts boiling, stir in a bit of olive oil and then add the eggs, all on medium or lower heat. Cover with a lid. Sometimes the egg sticks to the bottom shortly before being done. I remove the eggs, turn off the heat, and put in water to cover the bottom of the pan. Then I let the water and residual heat from the now-turned-off stove element soften the stuck on food. When cool, a non-scratch plastic scrubby cleans it to restore the lovely finish. I plan to use this primarily for eggs and vegetables. Very happy with it!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 11, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars No lid', 'author': 'Golfer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Pan is great but the features say it comes with a lid. It does not! I ordered 2 on separate occasions and NO lid. Luckily I had 2 perfectly fitting lids from other pans.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 15, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

Try them for yourself.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 1, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Nice Filler or Starter Set', 'author': 'Mike Downs', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'To alleviate some of the doubt the negative reviews might generate, you can never go wrong with cast iron. New cast should be brought up to temp gradually to avoid warping or breakage. If not thoroughly dried (towel then heat), moisture will creep through the seasoning and rust will appear--it is iron.I bought this as a filler set, small pans to fill in for the larger skillets. In the photo, the skillet on the right is the 10" from the set. On the left is an actual 10" skillet 30+ years old, complete with "10" clearly marked in the handle. By today\'s standards, it would be a 12".While using dish soap is OK with some and taboo with others, I\'m with the no soap crowd since dish soap is a degreaser, which softens the seasoning, which can also lead to rust spots from the moisture in the air. Instead, I clean my pans with baking soda as it not only cleans the pan, it removes left over odors, such as fish, then hand dry before putting it on the stove to heat through. If you want your cast iron to be non-stick, never use metal utensils as it scratches the seasoning the same as it would any non-stick pots or pans.Any oil is good for daily use, but once or twice a week (depending on use) I recommend using Crisbee Rub, which contains beeswax, for an ultra smooth surface. Keep in mind that pre-seasoned pans are not seasoned pans per se. Rather, they have an initial coating to protect them and get the buyer started. Still, with a little cleaning, they are good right out of the box for many uses where sticking isn\'t a concern.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 6, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars The "preseason" is a fad - sticky and rusty', 'author': 'Carson', 'rating': 3, 'content': 'This isn\'t my first rodeo with cast iron pans. This nifty little triplet come in different sizes, with the smaller two hardly being big enough to fit anything more than one or two fried eggs in. Oh, and they\'re pretty hefty (but manageable).Size often doesn\'t matter, it\'s what you can do or want to do with it, obviously. However, I used only the largest pan. They come "preseasoned" that makes it appear and the average person think that it\'s ready to use out of the box; but do not be fooled by this claim.I put it to the test and used the largest pan right out of the box - the meat was sticking and left an awful residue on the bottom of the pan. I scrubbed it until what seemed like my fingers would bleed and finally got it to a point where I thought it was clean. Onto the next trial!I stripped the pans. And then I reseasoned them quite a few times over a 12 hour period, and then once more the next day. Yes, the smell was not nice but I figured these seemed durable and well made so might as well give them a second chance. I tried the same meal later, unfortunately same issue - things sticking to the bottom and making it nearly impossible to clean.I\'ve never had a problem with cast irons sticking so much. Not sure what\'s up with these, but preseason or self season didn\'t seem to want to stick on the pan.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 11, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great for the price!', 'author': 'Jessie Klaiber', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'For the price I was expecting them to be cheaply made and likely need seasoned before use but they don’t! I was able to make sunny side up eggs WITHOUT busting the yolk and virtually no sticking 😍', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 21, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Do research!', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I switched over to cast iron entirely after learning about PFAS. these are great and come with nice instructions. Also buy yourself a conditioning oil to put on while you dry them, and while preheating the pans spread some kosher salt in the pan to draw moisture out before you cook. It will be as good as any nonstick, and will be much healthier for you and your family', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 22, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Nice pans for nice price', 'author': 'Ryan', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'We don’t like non stick pans so this was perfect! Highly recommend - excellent value.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 13, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Conflicted, but keeping an open mind', 'author': 'Christina', 'rating': 3, 'content': 'UPDATE, three weeks later: as long as you use a little oil these pans are a dream. I\'m still keeping my review at 3 stars though because the thermospot still doesn\'t do anything and I think thermospot does play into the price of the pans. Its just decoration for me at this point. I tried looking up more information about thermospot and there\'s really nothing to find about why it doesn\'t work. Oh well.--I bought these specifically for the thermo spot and nonstick capability. I was excited with the idea of knowing when my pan was ready and I was tired of having to use lots of oil on my old pans to cook something as simple as eggs. If you see in the first two pictures neither of those points delivered. Don\'t assume the worst yet though, keep reading...This was my first use of the pans. I did a cleaning with soap and water per the directions. I did NOT season as a couple of Questions I asked said due the material of the pan seasoning was not necessary. Seasoning made me nervous anyway as seasoning ruined the last nonstick pan I bought.I set the pan on the stove with low to medium heat and waited and waited and the thermo spot never went fully red, I could still see the squares in the circle. At that point I lowered the heat and put my eggs on, I could see them sticking right away, but I was in denial, hoping it would turn out right. It did not. The eggs were sticking, I was disappointed, and mad at myself because I already recycled the box the pans were delivered in (that\'s how much I believed in these pans didn\'t think about a return). It took me a minute to use a spatula to scrape off what had stuck (the best non abrasive method I could try).Then I decided to try again, because my breakfast sandwich was all ready except for the eggs. I wiped the pan with a paper towel before starting again. This time I decided to try with oil. I use a can of organic Extra Virgin Olive Oil that uses air instead of chemical propellants so the oil comes out as actual oil, usually a teaspoon or less sized amount. The thermo spot didn\'t turn fully red and again I had to make the decision myself. I was also impatient and anxious at that point, also hungry. I wanted my breakfast. This time, I\'m assuming thanks to the oil, it worked. The egg didn\'t stick. I was able to scramble the egg in the pan with the spatula, moving it around, not one sign of sticking. It was perfect. It was what I was expecting for the first try.Where I\'m giving these pans the benefit of the doubt:- Perhaps on the first try I let the pan get over heated, as I waiting for the thermospot to go fullu red- Perhaps on the first try all I needed was oil as well- Perhaps I need to do more research on how the thermo spot worksMy life experience, let alone education never taught me about pans or nonstick pans. When I was taught to cook I was taught to use a lot of oil or butter in the pan, which I stopped doing years ago because its not healthy. I\'ve lost almost 100lbs, these days I rarely eat foods with butter and when I use oil I stick to the air spray can because it yields 0-1 calories for a quick two second spray.If its just an issue of needed a little oil I can live with it. I do think its odd since the directions say "a touch of butter or oil may be used as flavoring to please your taste", that implies the butter and oil are optional. The directions don\'t say the butter and oil are required. Its fine because like I said I can use the oil and I can even learn how the thermo spot works.Not having the box to return the pans is also a factor of not initating a return. I don\'t keep every box I get when I place online orders. They get dropped off for recycling. The nearest store I could buy a box is over 20 miles away and I\'m risking buying a box that might not even be big enough. I\'m definitely not going to spend $6 or $7 on a Post Office priority mail box either. Unless Amazon has started providing free shipping material for customer to use for returns, a return would just be too much of a hassle right now. Not to mention you can\'t get free UPS pickup anymore and I don\'t live locally to a UPS store, I\'d still have to drive far off for a drop off. Just a big hassle all around.So I\'m keeping an open mind. I am going to try the pans again later. I will update this review if anything changes.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 8, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars I LOVE THESE PANS!', 'author': 'basscatt', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'These are much heavier than the regular T-FAL pansand the definitely distribute the heat more evenlyLOVE THEM!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 24, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

I was very impressed with this product.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 3, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Replace your toxic Teflon pans', 'author': 'Kathy B.', 'rating': 4, 'content': "I purchased this pan after throwing away all of my Teflon pans when I realized that my nickel allergy reared it's ugly head when I was ingesting the toxic metals from older Teflon pots/pans. My itching has stopped.This is a very durable fry pan with resemblance to cast iron, including in it's weight. The heat distribution is even and it gets plenty hot. Neither the lid knob nor the pan handle get hot during cooking so you are able to handle either while cooking. This is a great feature. I was used to using pot holders to remove the lid but it is not a problem with this. You will not be able to use this like a Wok as it is just too heavy.My only complaint is the cleaning. Yes, it is nice that you do not have to settle for just oiling a cast iron pan where you are unable to clean with soap. This this, you can clean it in the usual way. I use a non-abrasive Teflon-safe sponge/scrubber or nylon scrubber scroungy. The pan looks very clean when I'm finished but when I go to use it the next time, it appears that anything that settled inside the very small pores of the pan, didn't come out with soaking in hot water and scrubbing with soap.My recommendation is try not to brown or burn anything and you should be fine. Once something is browned, you will see it's residue after cleaning, and in the right light and the right angle. I am so picky when it comes to using clean cookware. However, I have no problem using my outdoor grill which I am sure is loaded with residue. Therefore, I have just convinced myself to pretend I am barbecuing. I won't die from that. LOLI would still recommend this pan. Very strong, durable, and appears will last years and years. Also, it saved my sanity from a year's worth of itching.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 23, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Heats evenly, so easy to wash. title: imarku Cast Iron Skillets, 12 Inch Cast Iron Pan, Professional Non Stick Frying Pans Long Lasting Nonstick Frying Pan Nonstick Pan, Stay Cool Handle, Easy Clean, Best Gift
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Changed my life in the Kitchen!', 'author': 'Jeanna Waggoner', 'rating': 5, 'content': "So now that I have this pan, I no longer begrudge cooking. It cooks so evenly and is non stick and easy to clean. I love the textured surface that keeps the food from sticking. I've used it for stir fry, meat for tacos, eggs over medium, omletes, sautéing vegetables, searing a potroast. It would work for anything beautifully that you want to cook in the skillet. I have noticed that it does cooker hotter than my old aluminum pan. Heat distribution is better so im using a little lower heat in this pan which is good since it uses less energy. I won't be putting this in the dishwasher because I don't do that with my pots and pans I feel like hand washing them helps them last a lot longer. If you want to put in dishwasher it is pretty large, just be aware of that and it might rust. It is super easy to clean because of the nonstick feature and so it's not a big deal. Clean it ,dry it and put away. I leave mine on the stove top since I use it daily. I doubt you'll regret if you buy this, especially if you cook at home a lot.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 17, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Jon stick', 'author': 'Brandi', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This pan is legit! It looks and feels very much like a cast-iron, heavy too.… Evenly cooks and absolutely no stick! Even with eggs, that’s right; even with eggs!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 10, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars FINALLY a true non-stick pan', 'author': 'Michael Baluyot', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I\'ve been searching for years for a good pan to make eggs, steaks and general purpose frying. I\'ve tried copper pans, "diamond" infused pans, ceramic coated pans, and always got the same result - sticking and difficult cleaning. I\'ve done research on the "Hexclad" line of pans, but they seem waaaaay too pricey. $160 for a frying pan? No thank you. So I came across this pan, and the reviews seemed favorable. The original price is supposedly $100, but got it on sale for $59. I was skeptical and had low expectations, but when I used it, it blew me away. Eggs did NOT stick. Steak cooked beautifully with great crust with minimal oil. Vegetables cooked perfectly. Then after the pan cools, all you have to do is wipe it with a paper towel and you\'re good to go for the next meal. I think the key is to follow the instructions to "season" the pan before using it for the first time. Put some high temperature oil (like any vegetable oil, but NOT olive oil) in the pan and put on low heat. Then evenly spread the oil over the whole pan while it\'s on low heat with a paper towel. In this way it is similar to a cast iron pan in the way you have to season the surface. However this pan is a fusion of cast iron and traditional non-stick pans, and thus has the best features of both. It is a bit heavier than traditional non-stick pans, but not as heavy as cast iron. After several meals prepared in this pan, it seems to be well built and sturdy and will be able to be used for a long time in the future. If you\'re looking for a great non-stick pan, your search is over. Get this pan especially if you see it on sale. You won\'t regret it.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 11, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Amazing!!!!', 'author': 'Josh Pollitz', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I use this pan for everything! I bought one for a friend as a gift and then couldn’t help but purchase one for myself after hearing how great it was for them!Cooks evenly, earns very fast and clean up is extremely easy! I hardly have any stickage, and with a tiny bit of olive oil spray (tiny tiny bit) absolute nothing will stick! Great product and it’s the only pan I use these days!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 27, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Nice, heavy pans!', 'author': 'Honu', 'rating': 5, 'content': "The pans are quite heavy and heat evenly. I've used the small pan a few times. It is small, but works well for eggs, which is why I bought it. I like it!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 12, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "4.0 out of 5 stars It's good, will sear with extreme heat.", 'author': 'dukester', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'It is almost as heavy as my cast iron about the same size. Frys really well, fish, chicken really crispy.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 29, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Best pans', 'author': 'Kg', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I actually didn’t realize I ordered cast iron but glad I made the mistake. These are the greatest non-stick pans. I love them. After use just an easy wipe in the sink and ready to go again. They are a little heavy being cast iron. Attractive copper color handle.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 19, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Best Nonstick I Have Used', 'author': 'IBUPNORTH', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I've used these pans daily for two months now and continue to be impressed by the nonstick cooking surface. While I would say it is average at best for browning meat, it may be that I haven't completely learned the best heat and time required for the different meats. Don't get me wrong, it can brown meat fabulously but you may need to adjust your past ways.Browning meat aside, these are well built pans. They are considerably heavier than the nonstick pans you may have been using but much lighter than cast iron. They appear two be a cast iron bottom heat surface with a nonstick cooking surface seamlessly mated together. The handles appear to be solid - maybe aluminum - and are securely fastened by two hefty rivets.The cooking surface is very slippery which probably necessitates the dimpled surface. In fact, the nonstick is so slippery, you could simply wipe the skillet interior clean immediately after cooking (the warmth helps) and you wouldn't know you had just cooked in it.I can't speak for the durability, but after two months of daily use they still look like new. I do recommend highly these pans if your budget allows it.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 5, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars A Need Or a Novelty?', 'author': 'My Own AMZN', 'rating': 3, 'content': "I already have an 8-inch cast iron pan but when seeing this pan on sale during the most recent Amazon Black Friday sale, thought I'd pick it up and see if it lived up to the claim of a cast iron pan that is also non-stick. Included in the box is the pan and instruction booklet.Upon taking out of the box, the first noticeable features of this pan is the stainless steel handle and the honeycomb surface. The main draw of the pan is the honeycomb surface as that is what gives the pan the non-stick feature. Instructions said to wash and then season the surface of the pan with some cooking oil. I didn't use as much oil for a regular cast iron pan but used a paper towel to spread the oil over the honeycomb area and rest of the top pan surface.Another thing easily noticeable is the pan is a bit lighter than my regular cast iron pan. I weighed the difference and this pan was about 1 lb lighter. I decided the best way to see if the pan works well for me is to try cooking in.The first meal I prepared was a fried egg. It felt strange not adding any more oil than usual. As for the egg, it did cook and I could slide the egg around. In other words, the non-stick did work.The second meal I used the pan for was to sear a pork chop. When using I noticed that holding onto the handle felt a bit awkward. The handle isn't perpendicular to the pan. It is at a bit on an angle, which puts a bit extra pressure on the wrist. Also, I noticed that the pork chop, which would normally easily fit in my regular cast iron pan didn't quite fit all the way. I think because the shape of the pan's sides is curved as opposed the flaring out like regular pans. I did my best to sear the pork chop. The sear turned out okay. Because I used less oil than normal, the sear wasn't as much. Also, noticeable was the there wasn't the crispiness in the vegetables I cooked with the pork chop. To pork chop didn't stick to the pan.The third meal I cooked was some salmon. I figured since this is non-stick, the salmon would be a good test. Once again, I didn't use much oil. After cooking, the salmon didn't stick to the pan but some of the skin and fish meat did. This sticking could have perhaps been avoided had I added more oil. But I thought one of the benefits of this pan is no need for much oil as otherwise, then why not just use a regular cast iron? After use, the pan was easy to clean with a rinse and wipe.After making these three meals with this non-stick cast iron pan, I decided to return and stay with the old fashioned cast iron that I already own. Perhaps I should have used higher heat (the instructions said to not use too high heat while leaving the pan empty, especially when new) and more oil. But if so, then is this really that much different than a regular cast iron as if a regular is well seasoned and used with enough oil, that pretty much non stick also.Here is what I like and dislike of this non-slip cast iron pan:Likes:- attractive look- adds non-stick via honeycomb surface- lighter in weight than traditional cast iron pan- might be healthier requiring less oil to cook with- easy to clean- doesn't rustDislkes:- angle of handle gave extra pressure on wrist when holding- surface area seems smaller than regular cast iron- miss the oil flavor in foodsThis non-stick iron cast iron pan with the honeycomb non-stick feature might work well for some. But for me, I'm sticking with the old.I give the imarku Frying Pan - 8 Inch Non Stick Frying Pan 3 stars.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 1, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The best!!', 'author': 'Jeri', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'These are the best frying pans I have ever had! I’m actually excited to cook with them because everything I’ve made turns out great!specially my omelets. Since it’s cast iron, I was concerned that they would be heavy, but they aren’t at all. The handles don’t get hot either, which was another concern. I usually don’t write many reviews, but these pans deserve it.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 24, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

title: HexClad Hybrid Nonstick Frying Pan, 8-Inch, Stay-Cook Handle, Dishwasher and Oven Safe, Induction-Ready, Compatible with All Cooktops
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars This thing is EXPENSIVE', 'author': 'Blu-Ray', 'rating': 5, 'content': "My wife wanted something like this pan for Christmas. When I looked at alternatives the prices were not much better. So I surprised her with this pan. She flipped. It was exactly what she wanted. Now she's cooking like a demon, using this thing every chance she gets. It cooks steaks like nothing else. Great sear and crust at high heat. This pan was designed for MEAT. Add some butter and wow. Tender steak. It cleans up very easily with a wipe in the dish water and the cooking finish seems indestructible. Clever design. The ridges keep the coating from getting scratched by keeping the utensils away from the coated surface. Good engineering. The only item that scratches is the LID. Very annoying. That brand new surface has some scratches in it already. UGH. Still, the pan is worth the price, especially for me because I'm the one eating that great food.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 9, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Best Cookware Of My Life', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I want to sing the praises of this incredible cookware. I started off with the purchase of this pan with lid. I thought the 14 inch pan might be too big but I was wrong. It fits nicely on the stove and can cook anything because of the size. The first thing I noticed was the even heat distribution. I made breaded boneless chicken breasts. In all other pans, even when the oil was hot, there was sticking. Not with this incredible pan. I put the chicken breasts in, let it brown a while and then just jiggled the pan a little. The chicken slid around much to my joy and I had beautifully browned meat that was so easy to turn over. I wish I had known about this cookware 3 years ago because I invested in 3 separate types of pans, all which failed after a year and had to be given away. This cookware is worth every penny you pay for it.The next pan I bought was a large dutch oven with a lid. I made a white sauce first. I've never had a pan like this. As soon as I mixed the melted butter and flour together, the roux bubbled beautifully from one edge of the pan to the other--no hot or cold spots. Perfect roux!My next pan will be the large roaster. Looking forward to that for sure. Every time I cook with these beautifully made quality pans I feel such appreciation for them. Even though the instructions say you can use metal utensils, I still am careful with them. The eggs just slid out of the pan and onto the plate.I think with these pans IT\'S IMPORTANT TO READ THE LITTLE MANUAL THAT COMES WITH THEM BEFORE YOU USE THEM. There are some recommendations there that will make these pans last a lot longer. They recommend that you coat the inside of each pan with cooking oil on low stove-top heat for two minutes...let cool and then wipe off. I did this and the oil did indeed soak into the pan like it was supposed to, making it VERY non-stick. My guess is that this might need to be done from time to time. Also, they recommend that you don\'t take a hot pan right off the stove and put cold water into it...it may scald. Things like this are important to know. So be sure to read your manual.I took one star off because I think the knob handles on the glass lids are weird. They are wood (looking) and then have this rubber leaf-shaped thing that goes on the end. My rubber ends keep coming off. Why was the lid handle not just rounded on the end to keep things simple?
