reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars I absolutely love these pans!', 'author': 'Brandy', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I absolutely love these pans! They are very well made, contain no forever chemicals (PFAO/PFAS), very easy to clean, and cook evenly. The 12 inch pan is much larger than you think as the sides allow for more surface area comapred to traditional pans. They are well worth the money and belive Hestan has a life time guarentee on their pans which means the cost upfront will save you in the end!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 7, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars A joy to use', 'author': 'George K', 'rating': 5, 'content': "These skillets are totally worth their price - I already own a non-nonstick Hestan and loved its looks and how easy it was to clean, but after doing my research and having had enough with 'high quality' non-stick pans from Calphalon and Zwilling, I decided to splurge for this set (it's actually a steal, compared to the price you'd pay if you were to buy two individual Hestans). title: Hestan - NanoBond Collection - Titanium Stainless Steel 8.5-Inch Frying Pan - Toxin, PFAS, & Chemical Free Clean Cookware, Induction Cooktop Compatible
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Awesome cookware for a bad cook!', 'author': 'JPDMyers', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Two months ago, I bought the 8.5” pan as a test before investing further in the Heston Nanobond line. I’d been wanted to ditch my non-stick cookware for several years for health reasons but couldn’t find the right fit. I’m spoiled by growing up cooking with only non-stick cookware. And I’m NOT a good cook so I tend to overheat pans & burn food. AND I sooo dislike cleaning up after cooking that I’d prefer to do it later (like the next day). I’m possibly the worst case scenario for testing any cookware line. I’d honestly much rather enjoy being served nice meals in restaurants. But, I’m immunocompromised so COVID changed all that. So, I’ve needed to up my game & learn to cook decently.I first tested several brands of stainless steel cookware. It was a total nightmare for me to clean. I then tried out ceramic cookware but found it to be too heavy for my arthritic joints. After reading about and researching Hestan’s Nanobond’s titanium coating, I thought it sounded promising & ordered this pan. Besides, the design of all of Hestan’s cookware is simply gorgeous.This Hestan Nanobond pan turned out to be AMAZING. My 1st test was fried eggs that turned out perfect with no sticking and easy cleanup afterwards. I’d read to heat the pan first, then add the oil/butter next & let it heat, and to then add the eggs. That definitely works to make the surface as close to being non-stick without actually having a non-stick coating. I’ve used it repeatedly for sticky foods like fried eggs, scrambled eggs, grilled cheese sandwiches, etc. with thrilling results. Best of all, it’s easy to clean afterwards.The Hestan Nanobond cookware is fantastic & suits my needs perfectly. I’ve now bought many more of the pots and pans in all shapes & sizes. I’m thrilled with the good looks & performance of the Nanobond line, the ease of cleaning up afterwards, and the titanium coating’s overall forgivingness for bad cooks. I accidentally added ground sausage needing to be browned for a casserole directly to their still-warming 3.5 quart sauté pan. The sausage stuck immediately to the bottom & I knew I’d really screwed up. While stirring the rest of the meat with only a silicon spatula, however, the stuck remnants surprisingly released completely from the bottom! I then decided to go ahead & try baking the entire casserole in the covered Nanobond pan in the oven instead of dirtying up a casserole dish. The casserole turned out fantastic with perfectly browned sides & bottom. The servings easily released from the pan without falling apart. And the very baked-on food remnants STILL cleaned up easily. The beautiful design of Hestan’s cookware really makes it equally appealing for stove/oven to table presentation. I’m now totally in love with the Hestan Nanobond line!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 7, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great brand', 'author': 'june', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I have two nano bond pans from them and both are my two favorite and most used. They clean great. You don't need non-stick if you have these.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 28, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars This is a high quality pan! Expensive but will last forever!', 'author': 'Charlie', 'rating': 4, 'content': "I just got rid of my nonstick T-Fal professional pan and that was great but the coating was starting to come off...Lasted just about maybe a year or year + 1/2...So I was getting tired of buying a new pan constantly.While this is not a non-stick pan, it is solidly built, and the nanocoat looks fantastic, and the rivets are not sticking out inside the pan.You need to warm up the pan and I like to do the water test to make sure the pan is hot enough.Be prepared to use oil and/or butter otherwise you will have food stick.I had to practice with eggs and finally got it figured out to where I can cook a over easy egg w/o making a mess on our electric range.Cleanup is pretty easy, soap + water.I believe if you have food stuck, just soak it and then clean.For anything that blemishes the pan, I think you can buy barkeepers friend and rub it out (cheaper than buying Hestan's polishing compound).If the price was lower, I would jump on the larger pan for sure...This is perfect for cooking a couple of eggs...Just wish it was a little cheaper.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 27, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars This pan is non stick as long as you follow directions', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'The media could not be loaded. This pan is a beautiful little gem. Feels nice in hand and completely non stick if you follow directions and heat it until water drops dance and scatter. Add oil and cook away!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 1, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '1.0 out of 5 stars Not worthy.', 'author': 'Sebas', 'rating': 1, 'content': "I recently purchased an expensive pan, and I have to say, I'm thoroughly disappointed with its performance. Despite the hefty price tag, the pan fails to deliver even the most basic cooking capabilities. Food sticks to the pan, and it cooks unevenly, leaving some parts burnt and others undercooked.I've tried using different oils and heat settings, but nothing seems to prevent the food from sticking or ensure an even cook. It's incredibly frustrating to spend so much money on a pan that doesn't perform as advertised.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 25, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '2.0 out of 5 stars sticks', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 2, 'content': 'Well made frying pan. We purchased the pan to fry eggs. The first time we used it the eges did not stick.Subsequent egg frying they stuck to the bottom of the pan regardless of how much butter was used to prevent sticking. Not worth the money.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 6, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Best pan ever!', 'author': 'Naser Ali Abbas Altaib', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'The media could not be loaded. This is the Hestan NanoBond 8.5” that I purchased last Oct 2022. After over 8 months of daily usage, the pan is still shining, easy to clean, and nothing sticks if you just preheat your pan properly before adding your fat. The pan is still as GREAT as new, if not BETTER, it’s the best durable high-quality elegant pan!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States June 5, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars DERAILED REVIEW —— Not perfect but I like it', 'author': 'Bobbler', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'I bought the 8 inch pan.. I am hesitant to buy the larger skillets if they are going to be super thin like the 8 inch is.BOTTOM LINE:I think I’m going to love this pan for scrambled eggs, and I don’t know what else.. I plan to try a reverse sear with salmon or a hamburger.. I usually slow cook vegetables in an enameled cast iron sauce pan, so I don’t have to worry about salt and other seasonings leaching the SS.. But I suppose I will try some vegetables in the nano bond titanium (as a little browning is supposed to add a layer of flavor.. but I suspect browning anything is less healthy).STICK, OR NOT TO STICK?Mystery solved.. I was perplexed by so many reviews complaining about things sticking to the titanium nanobond, because my scrambled eggs were sliding around, almost like a nonstick pan. I just watched a video comparison of three different stainless steel pans.. The Heston nanobond, and demeyere (both of which I have cooked scrambled eggs on).. In the video they got the pans hot until the water drops danced around, which I think of it as a trick that allows you to cook scrambled eggs in cast-iron.. Plus they used what looked like some kind of vegetable oil.. And the egg was stuck in the pan bad.. I use butter at a low temperature (which I believe is appropriate for eggs), and the eggs don’t stick at all..LEACHING INTO FOODI’ve always heard that titanium is extremely non-reactive, but I have been UNABLE to find any information (other than manufacturers claims) whether titanium cookware will leach anything into food while cooking (ie: acidic foods, like tomato paste, or how it’s well known that salt will pit stainless steel).. Titanium is supposed to be completely safe for humans, so we can only hope if anything leeches it would be pure titanium (manufacturers tend to be untrustworthy, I can only hope in Italy they have tighter regulations for such things than in America).. If you search the Internet you can find where testing was done with SS pans.. Some manufacturers claim you can cook tomato red sauce in them (even though tomatoes do leech from SS)..SUPER THIN?When I say super thin, perhaps I’m spoiled by using expensive aluminum clad cookware from other brands that have a hefty amount of aluminum.. Because of the high price of Heston nano bond cookware, they should pop for thick enough aluminum layer to where we should have to wonder if it’s enough.. And to be clear I don’t know how thick the aluminum layer needs to be to do. It’s job..The thin-ness of the pan makes me wonder if it would be prone to warping (with my other stainless steel pans, I clean them while they are hot, but I am fearful to put water into these thin nano bond skillets).. NOTE: I don’t put a lot of cold water into a hot pan, rather a little bit that steam cleans most of the pan (none of my pans have ever warped).HEAT MOMENTUM:The other problem with extra thin aluminum cladding is heat momentum.. Heat momentum is one of the reasons cast-iron pans work so well for certain things (such as putting a frozen hamburger patty, and getting heat momentum to create the seer.. instead of the frozen patty immediately cooling off the pan which destroys the seer). In my particular case, using the control freak induction burner that has a built-in temperature probe, it will probably compensate by instantly turning the power up (which I hear it doing when I take a little off, to try to maintain temperature).. I doubt the thin aluminum will work in this instance, if you’re trying to cook a frozen steak or anything substantial without cool in the pan off..NON-STICK:I have not used nonstick pans for decades, but I have been cooking scrambled eggs in aluminum clad stainless steel pans for years.. And for the past year. I’ve been using Demeyere SS skillets, which have a treated SS surface that concentrates the chromium and nickel and removes the iron (it makes the stainless steel, more stainless steel, and it does stick less than regular SS, but not by much)..[Again contrary to what many reviews are saying], when I cooked scrambled eggs in the Heston nanobond it felt like nonstick to me. There was an obvious non-stick quality even compared to my demeyere). Like my demeyere pans, I expect I will have to occasionally use the special cleaner, or barkeepers friend, to get rid of the haze/seasoning that develops (this is expected)..Likewise cleanup was very easy (like I would imagine non-stick would be).TOO—LIGHT—WEIGHT?I know other reviews think it’s thick/heavy, but it is by far the lightest pan I have ever held in my hands (and I’ve used a few different brands of aluminum clad stainless steel pans).. I realize titanium is light weight, but the nano bond is a very thin layer of titanium (presumably over stainless steel)..The pan is so light weight that it’s causing the problem with my control, freak induction burner.. The 8” or will sit flat by itself, but because it’s so light weight, and the handle is relatively heavy, it will not sit flat on the induction burner for preheating, because there is a temperature probe in the center (that has a lightweight spring)..And (when cooking anything sensitive to uneven heat) you very much need to preheat pans on an induction burner, because the nature of induction heats the pan itself so there is always a hot ring in the center of the pan that matches the induction ring (preheating for a while lets the heat spread out)..BOTTOM LINE: I was able to preheat the pan to cook my scrambled eggs, but one end of the pan was about 1/8” off the induction burner (and induction burners are sensitive to this.I WOULD HATE: to try to preheat the 8” pan for a seer on this induction burner (the 1/8” in the air might end up a huge problem at high power settings)..COOKING TECHNIQUES:There is technique to consider in whether eggs or anything sticks or not..For scrambled eggs I use low heat (228F.. since my induction burner controls the temperature).. and I use plenty of butter (I am convinced, low carb is healthy, and butter and egg yolks are healthy fats).. my eggs were sliding around the pan like the nonstick advertisements..CLEANUP:My experience with cleanup was like you would imagine nonstick. But I’ve seen many reviews complain about food sticking to the pan (I can only assume they were using high heat, and maybe little or no oil).. I can’t say for sure, but I know with my other stainless steel pans anytime something sticks, I just put a squeeze of dish soap and a little water and come back in an hour (or the next morning).. If I’m in a hurry, I’ll turn on the burner for a few seconds so warm soap will work faster.. Then whatever was stuck on usually falls off.. Sometimes I use vinegar (I don’t know whether dish soap vinegar would be more effective)..', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 20, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Very high quality in ALMOST every area.', 'author': 'Teddy', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'Pros: the finish looks beautiful as it’s slightly a smoky grey color which is very smooth and though not nonstick is less sticky than other stainless steel pans I’ve used. Good weight, feels sturdy and i love the flush rivets. Heats up quick and the high heat resistance is great so it works I’m pretty much any cooking environment other than a microwave.Cons. Mostly small nitpicks but for an expensive pan small can be big depending on your taste. Pricey. On my induction top at least the pan bottom warps very slightly so as thin coat of oil tends to pool towards the outer edges of the pan, this pretty common in a lot of pans but i do wish at this price it could be avoided. The handle feels high quality but could be slightly more comfortable if the part that rests against your palm was just a bit wider.Overall: If you can deal with those nitpicks this will make a great pan for small tasks like a grilled cheese or an omelet etc. and last a long time. happy cooking!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 31, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Excellent for searing', 'author': 'L. Bencze', 'rating': 4, 'content': "Yes, food will definitely stick to this pan; no doubt about it. But it's not that hard to clean out. Most importantly, the pan will not pick up any staining. My wife uses it for searing steaks. She puts it in a hot oven. It's perfect for this. So its searing abilities justify the purchase. Other pans, like Swiss Diamond, are much better for cooking eggs.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 11, 2023', 'is_verified': True}]

You buy nice things , You take care of Nice things so don’t throw your hate towards the company that gave you the option to have something so elegant and will last a life time ‘Providing you Care for them’ .All the very best to all that have these , And Happy Cooking 🧑\u200d🍳', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 11, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Well made and pretty', 'author': 'Tiffany Sanders', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I noticed the poor reviews revolve around the heat patina that forms on the copper after use, as well as the food sticking to the pan despite adding oil. To use steel pans, one must learn the steps: 1. Heat the pan first 2. Add the oil once pan is hot, let oil warm up for a few seconds 3. Add food.I have used a pot and my large pan from this ten piece set so far; cooked ground beef and rice, veggies like mushrooms, onions, garlic, and bell peppers so far, as well as made creamed spinach. I have not experienced any sticking whatsoever and find the pans cook my food more evenly with less risk of burning. These are the best pans i have ever used! If you don’t want the copper to change color, then you shouldn’t buy a set with visible copper parts, otherwise you can condition it to remove the natural patina that forms from heat exposure. I personally like the patina, it doesn’t bother me. I would recommend this set to anyone who cooks regularly and wants to do it the way the pros do it.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 14, 2022', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Disappointed so far - updated APRIL 7, 2022', 'author': 'Eflows414', 'rating': 3, 'content': 'I have decided to get rid of my nonstick Calphalon pans..I love them but the coating comes off and I"m very careful with my pans. I decided to try Hestan. First thing I cooked was scrambled eggs. I oiled the pan well but the eggs stuck really badly and was hard to get out. I forget what I cooked next in it but whatever it was, it was fine..so I tried eggs again, this time using olive oil to coat the pan. It was slightly better but the eggs still stuck to the pan however the pan cleaned up much easier. I\'m hoping it\'s just a matter of getting used to these as I want to get more pcs. This one has just been my trial piece. It is a beautiful pan, I will say thatApril 7, 2022 I thought I would add a little update. I don\'t use this pan that often, but I have cooked scrambled eggs a few more times...first coating the pan with olive oil, getting the oil hot before adding the eggs and then turning the heat down. They still stick but not as badly. I soaked the pan in hot water and it came clean easily. I will need to polish the copper but years ago when I had Revere ware copper bottom pans, I had to polish those as well. I hate not having it be a non stick pan but I spent a lot of money on the Calphalon only to have the nonstick peel off....so that\'s a waste. I never wash my pans in a dishwasher so that doesn\'t bother me either.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 2, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Cooks great, looks horrible', 'author': 'Belize Bradley', 'rating': 3, 'content': "My pots and pans are on display on a hanging rack so appearance is not as important as functionality but still important to me. This cookware looked horrible after the first few uses. I love the way it cooks but hate the way it looks unless you want to polish it after every use. It's also very heavy - so heavy I cannot manage the sautee pan with one hand. I had such high hopes for this set as it got great reviews and looked stunning out of the box (last photo).", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States July 25, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '2.0 out of 5 stars Beautiful until you use it. Photos are after one use.', 'author': 'Matt D', 'rating': 2, 'content': 'I haven’t cooked with high end cookware before and I’m tempted not to. This is a beautiful piece of cookware but…. It’s not non-stick or dishwasher safe. I did like the heat distribution but cleaning this thing is a chore. I only bought this one pan to test and I’m sorry I spent so much on it. Once you use it the beautiful copper tarnishes. It still works but the beauty is gone unless you polish it. Gonna try another brand that had a copper core but is dishwasher safe. This is a good pan. Just don’t buy it because it looks good. It won’t after you use it once.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 10, 2022', 'is_verified': True}]

title: T-fal Specialty Nonstick Fry Pan Set 3 Piece, 8, 9.5, 11 Inch Oven Safe 350F Cookware, Pots and Pans, Dishwasher Safe Black
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great pans', 'author': 'Providential', 'rating': 5, 'content': "These pans are tremendous at their price point, and work perfect on my gas oven. I love them.Pros:-Amazingly nonstick. I wanted a quick omelette for my first test. I only had to give the pan two shakes to finish my eggs. After letting the eggs heat up to firm on the bottom I gave the pan one shake to cause one side to fold over, and one final shake to flip it over and finish the other side. The omelette easily slid out onto my plate. I wiped out the pan with a paper towel, and it looks like new. That's true nonstick. No tools, no cleaning, the pan does all the work.-Inexpensive. There are 2 schools for nonstick pans. One says you should buy a really expensive, maybe a ceramic Le Creuset type pan, which will last a long time and give the best experience. The other says you should go with something relatively inexpensive like this T-Fal set, because you know over time someone in your family is going to be an idiot and scrape the coating off your pans with metal utensils. I'm in the latter camp, so I absolutely love this set.Cons:-None. As said, so long as you're in the school where you'd prefer inexpensive nonstick pans, these things are wonders. Sure they don't retain heat like a big ceramic, sure a heavier pan could distribute heat better. But these are amazing at their price point, and their heat distribution is way better than you'd expect.Overall:This is my go-to for nonstick pans. Get something inexpensive, and in 5+ years when they're starting to get scraped up from misuse, you don't feel bad about replacing them. My mom's the type to always go for the heavy ceramic nonstick, and it kills her every time she has to replace one - but that doesn't stop her from damaging the coating with metal implements all the time either! I'd rather use my T-Fal, it makes me happy.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 10, 2020', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Wonderful pan set, the best', 'author': 'Cherished', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This skillet set is excellent. It's durable, anti-scorching, non stick, and cooks your meals with an even temperature. I'd buy this set again and do recommend. Regarding the red dot heat indicator, it does not activate when the pans are hot. I even turned off my kitchen lights to see if there was a faint light, but nothing. Otherwise, the pans are amazing and I do recommend. 👍", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 5, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars well made', 'author': 'Danny', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'fun to use', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 17, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Nice pans', 'author': 'Postal Suzi', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'Used the smallest fry pan to fry eggs... seasoned the pans according to manual directions. Did not use commercial cooking spray (all of the cooking website reviews said not to) used canola oil, lightly. Everything went okay until it was time to flip the eggs.... they stuck just enough to break the yolks... but then slipped right out of the pan. Clean up was simple and easy. These pans cost $37.42 and for 3 non stick fry pans... that is a good price. I am replacing my Circulon fry pans after 10 years because the anodized coating is coming off. Checked many cooking sites and reviewing sites.. and bought these because they had good reviews at a price I was comfortable with. Preformed better than the "copper" and "diamond" brands and at a better price (from Amazon).I did have some problems registering for warranty... the model/serial number on the box was damaged. The product registration form would not accept any of the numbers I tried and I could not find the exact product combo on the T-fal website. I finally emailed customer service at t-fal.com and sent them a photos of the box info panel and fry pans and received a reply that says my product has been registered.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 18, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars At this price is essential.', 'author': 'RC G.', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Very good value. Lightweight with nice handles. Keep a star screwdriver near in case the handle gets loose. I'd buy these again.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 27, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars As expected', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Good products. Fast shipping.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 21, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars PFOA free, cheap and high quality...', 'author': 'Muttley', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I bought this set after my previous similar sized pans wore out completely. I have always been concerned with the safety claims related to teflon (PFTE) and thus before turning back to them, I tried ceramic options as an alternative. However they turned out to be such under-performers, with food sticking all the time and causing permanent stains which looks (and probably is) burnt. Besides, those alternatives, that are sold with greener and healthier claims, are also questionable due to the possibility they might be leeching heavy metals to the food.Besides, recently, I have come across reports saying that the nastier effects are mostly due to the chemical called PFOA rather than the actual teflon material which is PFTE. PFOA has been shown to cause cancer in experimental models but it is almost entirely gone after the pans came to their final state of manufacturing. Yet again, even those who work in teflon industry (so getting much higher exposure than general household user did not suffer an increased cancer rate according to WebMD) The good news is that for most modern models PFOA is removed from the manufacturing process and this set is among them with no PFOA to worry about. The other chemical which is the main ingredient of teflon is PFTE and it can start fuming out at very high temperatures (higher than most normal cooking procedures) and the only adverse effect that has been shown after massive exposure (which is unlikely in household settings) is some flu like symptoms. After these data, I obtained from various sources, I decided to come back to teflon again.However despite all those claims, I recommend potential buyers to limit teflon use as much as possible and use stainless steel cookware everywhere possible (if sticking is not a major problem for what you are cooking). Additionally I recommend not to use the pans when they start showing signs of wearing out. I believe that precautions would make me safer for the known and unknown effects and yet allow me to enjoy the convenience teflon has over other so called non-stick stuff. (Please make your own research for complete peace of mind rather than taking my word as true)Finally, I particularly liked this product due to its decent price-tag ($23 for 3 pans as of august 2014), even cooking and the company reputation (T-fal). I have used many different brands and T-fal has prevailed in most cases. If you are in the market for a decent set of small to medium sized nonstick pans then this product is a real good option', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 6, 2014', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars Great pans, but don't stack them without insulation. Privets are good.", 'author': 'KH', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I love these pans. They heat evenly, handles are not hot and the non-stick is amazing. Just don't stack them together without something between them. The bottoms of these pans are very abrasive with any movement. Get some cheap silicone privets and put them between the pans when storing. And don't use anything metal or abrasive to clean them and they will last forever. Enjoy your omelets and easy cleanup!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 8, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Most used pans in our kitchen', 'author': 'Jerm Addams', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'My wife and I were looking for a pan to use strictly for making our dogs meals and took a chance on these and be honest, they ended up being our most used pans . They wipe clean very easily , depending on what you’re cooking and for those tougher , greasier meals , they come easily clean . We have literally abused these, as we are cooks, and really enjoy being in the kitchen, and these have been a great addition to our cast-iron pans we have used the most for years.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 27, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Very good', 'author': 'daniel schultz', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'They seem to hold up.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 3, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

title: imarku Non Stick Frying Pans - 8&10&12 Inch Cast Iron Skillets Professional Cast Iron Pan Dishwasher Safe Nonstick Frying Pan Set, Detachable Handle
reviews: [{'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars The BEST non-stick I've used in my life, and I've tried them all!", 'author': 'Stormy', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'These are seriously the best non-stick pans I have ever used, with nothing that even remotely compares. They basically have all of the pros of true non-stick (like ceramic) and seasoned cast iron, without the cons. I love how non-stick ceramic pots and pans are, but even following the care instructions to a "T" (handwash only, only use silicon utensils, etc.), they end up scratching horribly and with time, things begin sticking. I feel like the only solution is to replace them about every 1 - 2 years, which feels wasteful and expensive to me.I love the idea of cast iron and being non-toxic, but the reality can be a pain. They require a lot of re-seasoning to maintain their non-stick coating, are incredibly heavy, bulky, and if you cook anything fishy or acidic in them, they need a good washing and re-seasoning after. I work full-time and have young kids and while I love cooking, I just don\'t have time or energy for the upkeep of cast iron.Then I randomly stumbled across these. They had excellent reviews and really intrigued me. I\'ve owned them for a couple of months now and cannot be more in love with them. I scoured all of the questions/ answers and reviews and couldn\'t quite sort out if they need to be seasoned. Apparently they don\'t. They use a cast-iron non-stick coating, according to the literature these come with. They do recommend using non-abrasive utensils and cleaning methods, although after weeks of heavy heavy use, these don\'t seem to scratch. Granted, I\'m not using metal or anything just in case, but still, my ceramic ones began scratching almost immediately.If you can believe it, these are even more non-stick than quality ceramic pans that cost three 4 times as much. Seriously absolutely nothing sticks to these. I flipped a really cheesy quesadilla poorly the other day, and a bunch of the cheese spilled out. Even with a thick layer of shredded cheese and some chicken, it just glided around the pan. I later did it on purpose because who doesn\'t love fried cheese? No oil or anything, and once it was properly fried on the bottom, it released no problem. The little bumps on the bottom of the pan also seem to really help with even temperature distribution. Everything I cook is cooked perfectly and evenly. There don\'t seem to be hotspots with these pans like there have been with every other type of pan I\'ve used. The texture on the bottom also creates a fun sear on things, with a bunch of little round circles.These seem to heat up more quiclky than cast iron, but maintain steady heat even better than cast iron. You don\'t need to heat these pans as hot as other pans, at least in my experience. They heat very quickly and while I used to use "high" on my stovetop frequently to get a good sear, even on my cast iron, with these they can burn things on high. It\'s a bit of a learning curve, but for whatever reason, these heat up more quickly and evenly than any other pan I\'ve used, so babysit your food when you\'re first using these to sort out the best cooking temperatures.Cleanup is so easy too. Per the care guidelines, I don\'t introduce extreme temperature differences, so let these pans cool for at least 15 minutes after use, and seriously running it quickly under water releases everything. Unlike traditional cast iron that rusts, I can leave these wet after and they air dry, with no rusting. They don\'t seem to hold onto grease, but just in case, I do use a little soap and a non-stick safe cleaning pad and rinse well after. They don\'t seem to hold onto stinky smells like fish either. These are much less porous than regular cast-iron. While heavy-duty, these are also significantly lighter than traditional cast iron too. My thin, weak wrists don\'t feel like they\'ll be dislocated moving these particular pots around.Finally, I do like that the handles are removable, but likely won\'t use that feature often. It\'s not that they\'re difficult to remove, but it does take a few steps and removing a screw (and hoping I don\'t lose it!) to do so. I\'ve removed the handles a couple of times when moving something from the stovetop to the oven, but prefer to leave the handles alone. I also wish they had lids, but it\'s not the end of the world that they don\'t. My skillet lids from a different set mostly work with these, so I can make it work on the rare occasions I need a lid. Tomato-based items don\'t seem to impact these either like they did my traditional cast iron.All in all, get these pans! Whether your a novice in the kitchen or highly experienced, you will love this set! All of these sizes seem to work well for our family of 4 (plus frequent company).', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 16, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Nonstick Cast Iron Frying Pan Set!', 'author': 'abhildo', 'rating': 5, 'content': "The three different sizes (8 inch, 10 inch, and 12 inch) are incredibly versatile and cover all my cooking needs. The nonstick coating works like a charm, allowing me to cook with minimal oil and making cleanup a breeze.The best part is the removable handle, which adds a whole new level of convenience. I can use these pans both on the stove-top and in the oven, thanks to the easily detachable handle. It's a very convenient feature that saves space and makes storage a lot more straightforward.The cast iron construction ensures even heat distribution, making for perfectly cooked meals every time. I appreciate the durability of the pans, as they feel robust and built to last.I've used these pans for frying, sautéing, baking, and more, and they've exceeded my expectations in every aspect. This set is a real game-changer in my kitchen, and I can confidently say it's worth every penny.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 4, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars My favorite pans set', 'author': 'Khanh Nguyen', 'rating': 5, 'content': "The media could not be loaded. I've been using my new pans for 15 days, and I'm absolutely loving it! Yes, they're a bit heavy, but that's a small price to pay for their durability and quality. The non-stick surface is a dream - no scratches at all, even with daily use. The different sizes are perfect for everything from small breakfasts to large dinners, and the detachable handle is such a smart feature. Cleaning is easy (they're dishwasher safe, but I prefer hand washing to preserve the non-stick). Overall, this skillet set is a fantastic addition to my kitchen, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for high-quality, long- lasting cookware.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 7, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent Cast Iron Pans', 'author': 'JPS', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I've always sworn by cooking with Cast Iron. these pans are excellent yet not too heavy like traditional Cast Iron is. They come pre-seasoned, have excellent heat distribution, non-stick and super easy clean up. I'd highly recommend.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 23, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars So far I’m very pleased', 'author': 'Bubba Johnson', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I have a 12 year old set of nonstick from JCPenney that is still “functional” but the pieces I use regularly are failing and needed an update. When I ran across this cast iron + enamel + nonstick + macro-texture surface set, I had to try them. VERY PLEASED so far. At this point, they have exceeded my expectations; appearance is excellent with the wood handles and the non-stick is impressive. Heavy ? Yea, but that is a bonus and not a shortcoming in my opinion. Durability ? Too soon to tell; it’s only been a month, but no problems so far. Heat transfer is good overall but a little slow (completely expected for CI) and they nicely brown everything I have thrown in them on med-low heat over a gas flame without major hotspots or any local burning. They do not give a completely even heat surface, but it’s pretty good and a very good compromise between cost and functionality. If I really get bored, I may get out the thermal imager and quantity what I already know by use.I would really like to see the set expand. No, not pots, there are already 100’s of functional small, med., large, and stock pots for boiling stuff where non-stick is almost irrelevant. On the stove, I could use a bigger / deeper pan with a helper handle and after that I think a griddle pan would also be nice in this set.Adding a non-stick surface to enameled cast-iron cookware is as obvious as putting butter on toast but surprisingly this is the first set I have seen with it ? Maybe I am an ignoramous ? Putting the textured surface in there is brilliant ! Thin wall cast iron is a fresh idea (as far as I know) also. Putting all this together at once is a lot. If the durability is reasonable, this could really take off.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 1, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars So far I am impressed', 'author': 'A. Hill', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'I am nothing more than a home cook, but these pans have been very nice. They are heavy, handles can be removed, easy to clean and seem to be very durable and stick free. For the price I think they are worth it. I may purchase another set.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 5, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Best nonstick pans I’ve ever had', 'author': 'Sam', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'These are by far the best non stick pans we’ve ever owned. Very well made. They are cast iron so have some weight but that is what makes them cook so well. It’s the best of both worlds! Even cooking and everything slides out. Beautiful looking as well. The wooden handles are the cherry on top.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 8, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love these!!! My new favorite', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': "These pans are amazing! If you follow the care instructions, you will do great with these! I seasoned them with oil and I hand wash them with minimal to no soap. They wipe clean after each use. The nonstick quality is great, I have cooked many different dishes and haven't had an issue with anything sticking. Cast Iron pans are known to be 'heavy' but these pans are much more lightweight than your average cast iron. As far as temp distribution, I can't say that they are any different than a normal pan. One side gets hotter than the other, but I also have an old stove, so that could be why too. Love that the handles remove so you can put them in the oven or store them easier.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 2, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars update:', 'author': 'Dan Krueger', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I have been using imarku pans daily for 10 months. Great product! Today I noticed one rivet holding the handle to the pan was loose on the 8" pan. Searched and finally found customer service number however after 3 attempts all i get is a recording saying no one is available call back later. I will continue to try but beware when purchasing. If a problem arises your 1 year replacement warranty not be any good.update: i spent a total of 4 hours talking with Amazon trying to contact the manufacturer. None of the websites or phone numbers amazon gave me were legitimate. Finally amazon offered me a refund. If anyone has a problem with these frying pans I recommend going straight to amazon request a customer service supervisor. Reference my review and request a refund. This will save you hours of jumping through endless hoops. I only gave the pans 5 stars hoping more of you will see this. Pans are very good customer service with the manufacturer stinks!!!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 8, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Heavy', 'author': 'ShirE', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'My husband really love these pans easy to clean I think the quality is good', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 28, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

title: All-Clad HA1 Hard Anodized Nonstick Fry Pan Set 2 Piece, 8, 10 Inch Induction Oven Broiler Safe 500F, Lid Safe 350F Pots and Pans, Cookware Black
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars New All Clad non-stick frypans', 'author': 'kirk gittings', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'So far so good. We are replacing a couple of older, well worn, 8” and 10” non-stick frypans that served us well. The weight of these is what we expect from A/C. But we haven’t tested them yet and will update this as we do.As per the handles, what the heck is the big deal! We have 30 A/C pots and pans and they all have the same handle. It has never been an issue. My wife is a lifelong professional chef and chef educator and never an issue. Until I read these reviews I had never heard a complaint.After using them for a week (my wife is a retired professional chef and is ALWAYS cooking-and we have over 30 All-Clad pans), we found them perfectly functional and a huge bargain. We have no complaints of the evil handles. They work well as all AC handles do and the NS surfaces as well. Nothing to add to the above except that they are not showing any signs of wear at all after a few months. But we take care of our pans! No overheating, no metal utensils and no scrubbing with abrasives. We like them enough that we just bought a 12” pan from this same line.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 4, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars You'll notice a difference from regular frying pans", 'author': 'kathy hatcher', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'The best addition to my cookware. And the food slides off with no sticking, and these pans are super easy to clean!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 29, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great non stick pans', 'author': 'Bill Ferrie', 'rating': 5, 'content': "So far I've been very pleased with these pans! It's great for eggs, heats quickly and evenly, and cleans easily. Make sure you follow the directions for cleaning or you may get a faint plastic smell on your first couple of uses.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 1, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Not as thick as original', 'author': 'Roger X', 'rating': 4, 'content': "We bought a full set of this cookware several years ago. We use them every day and they are excellent. High quality. easy to clean. Look nice. But the small pan was burned and had some things stuck to it It was scraped with a metal spatula and now didn't look so good. I ordered a replacement. It came and weas the same size. Looks nice. But it is not as thick and slightly lighter weight. The metal is just a little bit thinner. I don't know if this is for all the newer ones or just what we ordered from Amazon. But being the smallest pan it's not that important", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 31, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars These were better than expected.', 'author': 'Mr. Mac', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This is a heavy-duty pan -- almost like cast iron including the weight. They sit very flat and the nonstick is really non-stick. I have fried eggs wi.th just a brushing of oil and they slide around as if floating in oil. They are super easy to clean. Wiping with a paper towel will almost clen the pans. I find the heating the pan just higher than the cooking range for few minutes improves the evenness of heat for uniform cooking.The main negative is the handle. It is strange. It is U-shaped on top and narrows at it gets closer to pan. It is awkward. It is similar to a Cuisinart frying pan handle which has a U-shaped handle, but it widens as it gets closer to the pan which works better with your hand while holding the pan. It is also long. All Clad needs to rethink this handle design.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 23, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The best non stick surface', 'author': 'e han', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I am giving this product five stars. First let me say the pot handles suck. They are weird awkward and it is a terrible design. However, the surface of these nonstick pans is absolutely incredible. It is a hard surface. It is not coated with any weird chemicals and nothing sticks to it. As long as you take your time and heat slowly, I have had absolutely no problems with this. It is perfect for sautéing tofu and getting a nice crunch on the outside without using any oil I would highly recommend these pans even though the handles are awful, the most important part is the nonstick, right?', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 3, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Nice pans', 'author': 'Robin', 'rating': 5, 'content': "All clad does not disappoint. All Clad sells some to fit their cookware.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 23, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Best pans I’ve ever owned', 'author': 'Vwelyn', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This set was a bit expensive, so I was hesitant to buy them- but they’re great. Although I do have a gripe with the handle, I don’t think it’s enough to warrant taking off an entire star rating.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 24, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great for cooking perfect omelets', 'author': 'Susan', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Cooked with one of these pans on a trip to my brother's house. Fell in love with them, and had to buy my own. They made perfect, browned on the outside, a bit runny on the inside omelets that turned well on his electric-burner cooktop. So-far, they don't work quite as well on my induction cooktop. I need to experiment with the heat, etc.Cleanup is so much easier that with my stainless still skillets.Won't know about scratch resistance until I have used them for a year or so. I did purchase silicone pan protectors to place between them when I stack them for storage, to minimize scratching, and my wooden and plastic spatulas shouldn't cause abrasion.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 8, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

title: OXO Good Grips Pro 8" Frying Pan Skillet, 3-Layered German Engineered Nonstick Coating, Dishwasher Safe, Oven Safe, Stainless Steel Handle, Black
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Top Choice for a Nonstick Pan', 'author': 'MADPWR', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This review is for OXO Good Grips Pro 12" Frying Pan Skillet, 3-Layered German Engineered Nonstick Coating, Dishwasher Safe, Oven Safe, Stainless Steel Handle, Black. I purchased this for a house member who really likes nonstick cookware. I ordered this one, because Cook\'s Illustrated America\'s Test Kitchen rated it the best. It\'s a very nice pan, and we have used it many times so far. The nonstick surface is holding up very well, and it is definitely nonstick. We have cooked eggs, meat, chicken, fish, and other items in it. Nothing stuck to the pan. We only hand wash it, and we only use non-metal utensils with it. The weight of the pan is good, and the handle is comfortable and ergonomic. All-in-all this is a great pan if you are looking for something nonstick.A side note about nonstick pans:I am generally not a fan of nonstick pans. I don\'t like cooking with something that is a part of planned obsolescence. All nonstick cookware slowly starts to wear down with use. It is just the nature of it. So, eventually all nonstick cookware has to be replaced, as eventually it will lose its nonstick properties. This brings me to the other part that I don\'t like. Nonstick cookware uses chemical products to make it nonstick, and those chemicals wind up in your food. Reports claim the chemicals are safe, but you have to judge your level of confidence in the reports. I don\'t see a benefit to having added chemicals in my food. Also, you can\'t use metal utensils with nonstick pans, as the metal will damage the nonstick coating. This generally means one set of non-metal cooking utensils and a separate set of metal utensils to use with your standard cookware. So, I have two sets of cooking utensils. Also, different nonstick cookware will have different maximum temperature ratings. This pan is rated up to 430 F degrees. If you go above that you breakdown the chemical nonstick coating, which not only ruins the nonstick coating, but it also puts those chemicals into your food. I once had a different brand of nonstick pan many years ago that I cooked an omelette in. The nonstick coating had broken down and left all sorts of black flakes on my omelette, so both the omelette and pan went into the garbage. Personally, I prefer to go with a high-quality, multi-clad, stainless steel set of pots & pans that I can use any utensils on that I like and will last me forever. However, if you are going to purchase a nonstick pan this one is an excellent choice because it is a good pan and at a good price point for replacement.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 23, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great non stick!', 'author': 'Mason', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Great pan, super nonstick. I don’t plan on it lasting forever, and don’t expect it to. Super light, great heat distribution and so easy to clean. Use the right utensils (silicone or others meant for nonstick- not stainless) and it will prolong the life of this pan and keep plastics out of your food.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 21, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Elevate Your Cooking with Professional Quality!', 'author': 'Steven', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'As a passionate home cook who values performance and convenience, the OXO Good Grips Pro 12" Frying Pan Skillet has become an essential tool in my kitchen, earning a glowing 5-star review! This skillet combines professional quality with user-friendly features, making it a standout choice for all my cooking needs.The 12" size of the OXO Good Grips Pro Frying Pan is perfect for preparing family-sized meals. Its generous surface area allows for even cooking and ample space to toss and stir ingredients.The 3-layered German engineered nonstick coating is simply impressive. It performs flawlessly, ensuring that food doesn\'t stick to the surface, and making it a breeze to clean after cooking. I can cook with confidence, knowing that my dishes will turn out perfectly and cleanup will be a breeze.The stainless steel handle provides a secure and comfortable grip. Its stay-cool feature allows me to handle the skillet with ease, even when cooking on high heat. The handle is also oven-safe, adding to the skillet\'s versatility.The performance of the OXO Good Grips Pro Frying Pan is exceptional. It distributes heat evenly across the surface, preventing hot spots and promoting consistent cooking results.The skillet\'s construction is top-notch, with attention to detail evident in its design and build. The durable materials ensure that the pan will withstand regular use and maintain its quality over time.I love the dishwasher-safe feature of the skillet, making cleanup a breeze on busy days when I don\'t have the time for handwashing.The black color and sleek design add a touch of sophistication to my kitchen. The OXO Good Grips Pro Frying Pan looks as good as it cooks!In conclusion, the OXO Good Grips Pro 12" Frying Pan Skillet is a must-have for any home cook seeking professional quality and user-friendly features. Its generous size, exceptional nonstick coating, comfortable grip, even heat distribution, oven-safe handle, durable construction, dishwasher-safe feature, and stylish design make it a standout skillet for all your cooking adventures. Elevate your cooking with the OXO Good Grips Pro Frying Pan Skillet - it\'s a game-changer in the kitchen!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 3, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Well-constructed and excellent non-stick performing frying pan', 'author': 'BillF', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'The Oxo Good Grips Pro frying pans are the top non-stick frying pan recommendation from America’s Test Kitchen, and rightfully so. The pans are surprisingly light but very robust, well balanced, and the non-stick surface performance is excellent. The pans heat up quickly and evenly with no hot spots. The handle is stainless steel and very sturdy. Because stainless steel is a poor heat conductor, the handle stays cool and you do not need pot holders or a silicone handle cover to grab it.I purchased the 10” and 8” versions of the pan. These frying pans do a great job of cooking anything and everything. Especially breakfast eggs and potatoes which are the main reason I needed them. I am treating the new pans with kid gloves, making sure to only use non-stick coating safe utensils (wood or silicone). As well as thoroughly cleaning, and drying them after each use. Make sure to not use dish washing liquid that contains bleach or citrus additives as these will break down the non-stick coating. I am hoping to get many years of “non-stick” use out of these pans.I needed a lid for the 10” Oxo Good Grips Pro frying pan to cook breakfast eggs. Previously I had used a general-purpose lid with the 1.5" to 2.0" silicone edge. Although that worked, the silicone edge tended to accumulate grease from the oil/butter used to cook the eggs and was difficult to keep clean. And so I was looking to obtain a new lid.Luckily the B08X6VQ6QS 10" Ozeri Tempered Glass Fry Pan Lid (part number GL3-26) perfectly fits the 10" Oxo Good Grips Pro frying pan. I measured the diameter of the Oxo 10" pan at exactly 10.75". The Ozeri lid is specified to be 10.7" in diameter. This results in this lid being a perfect fit for the 10" Oxo Good Grips Pro frying pan. The attached photos show what a great fit this lid is for the 10” Oxo Good Grips Pro frying pan.The silicone rim on the Ozeri lid is much smaller (only 0.5") than on the general-purpose lids (1.5" to 2.0"), and so I am hoping it will be easier to keep it grease free. One minor issue with this Ozeri lid is that the steam vents are on the side edges and not on top. This results in the lid getting “fogged” up a little bit more than those with the steam vent on the top. Hence visibility into the pan while cooking is a little bit less, but that is not a big deal since you can still generally see inside there.I did not purchase the B08X6CKMS8 8” Ozeri Tempered Glass Fry Pan Lid (part number GL3-20) but it is specified at 8.3” diameter. I have measured the 8” Oxo Good Grips Pro frying pan diameter at 8.3”, and so this lid should fit well.Note: the Ozeri lids are delivered with the knob put in backwards. This is done on purpose to create a lower profile lid for easier shipping. They even included a note saying as much, and that all you need to do is unscrew the knob as shipped and re-install it in the correct position. See attached photo.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 12, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Great pan, however...', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'Bought this pan almost 2 years ago. Performed like a champ up until about 3 or 4 months ago, when its non-stick surface began breaking down. Now its half usable (surface area wise). Although, in reality its unusable, and should not be used, nor any pan, once the non-stick surface has been compromised for health reasons, I\'ve read.I\'ve decided to purchase another as the length of time before failure (as compared to other reviews) was not bad and all during its time, it performed great. It was also a breeze to clean, requiring very little effort.Things to take note and pay attention to are the other reviews that say how to use the pan, which I will state as well as they are, I feel, were key to its duration and performance.*Side note, I have an LG electric glass-top stove.DO NOT use high heat - I actually cut my heat level down by half or more in everything we cooked in the pan. I feel I should have been doing prior to this pan as its probably what warped my others over time that weren\'t as solid as this one. Out of the 10 levels, with increments our stove went to, the highest we went on our stove was 3.0. MAYBE 3.6 or 3.8 but rarely. I thought this was going to be too low and although took a little longer, not much, to get going, it was perfectly fine and had all the heat it needed. Most of the time we had it around 2.4-2.8. If I have had translate to a dial stove, then med to medium low(?). It does a good job of heating hence why, once it gets going, its good to go. You don\'t need the extra heat. It\'ll cook or boil. Again that\'s for our stove, so take it how you will. For trial and error, start on the low go up from there, but again, not too high.DO NOT use metal or even a hard plastic utensils. The surface does seem to scratch pretty easily. I feel we may have accidentally broken this rule a few times before catching ourselves, which probably contributed to shortening its life. This is why I\'m giving this pan another go. Definitely keep to wood or silicon spatulas, etc.DO NOT use brillo or other harsh scrubbing pads. If the pan is still performing well and needs that extra "elbow" grease try this tip first - Put some water in the pan, bring to a boil or just under (again, with a heat setting comparable to heat for cooking. NEVER high.) and then use your surface safe spatula or scraper to gently remove the food. This method will pop or break that stubborn seal the food has on the pan. This works 9 times out of 10 for any pan, I\'ve found.Hope this helps. I\'ll update my review depending on how the 2nd pan performs and trying to be extra diligent this time.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 14, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Premium non-stick pan at a reasonable price.', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This was featured in America\'s Test Kitchen as their "best value" pick and I agree. There are cheaper pans, but the OXO product is dependable and solid. Try this: take your current non-stick pan and heat it to 350 F and crack an egg right onto it. Dry. No butter, oil or non-stick spray. Make yourself an over-easy egg. Did it release, or make a mess? ATK claims they do this 50 times per pan in their stress test. I tried it, and it works perfectly every time. I didn\'t realize you could cook eggs without a thick layer of non-stick spray, but this pan does it with ease. The handle is comfortable and makes it easy to manipulate. It\'s my new \'go-to\' pan when it\'s time to make breakfast.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 9, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great pan to cook eggs', 'author': 'bella', 'rating': 5, 'content': "The pan is very slick and supports cooking eggs with no problems. It's also very lite weight and easy to clean. Non-Stick pans should be replaced every couple years so there is no need to spend an exorbitant amount of money on something that you're going to toss in 2 to 3 years.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 14, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Agree with Testers', 'author': 'Lux Camper', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This is the best non-stick skillet I've had. America's Test Kitchen voted it best in 2 tests, years apart. I must agree. After throwing away my 4th non-stick, this lives up to expectations. Heats well, handles well, and is very non-stick that has not begun to degrade after a few months.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 18, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars A winner', 'author': 'M. Glish', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I have a variety of cookware and in general I don\'t care about "non-stick". But I make omelettes on weekends and that requires a non-stick pan with gently curved sides. I had an expensive carbon steel frying pan that I seasoned with great care and rarely got an omelette that would just slide out of it.Finally I decided to look for an inexpensive non-stick frying pan. There were some good choices from higher-end companies but I didn\'t to spend a lot just to cook omelettes on weekends. After some research and previous good experiences with this brand, I took the plunge.I\'ve made three out of three perfect omelettes with this pan and I\'m very happy with it. I doubt I will challenge the durability of the non-stick surface, so I don\'t care about that. What I do care about, other than its cooking capability, is the handle. It feels great in the hand and doesn\'t get hot during the amount of time that is required to cook an omelette.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 18, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great pan', 'author': 'JRiley', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I never use non-stick products but I’m sure glad I gave this pan a try. I needed a 12” skillet for some recipes I saw on ATK and I love it. I bought the Lodge Manufacturing Company tempered glass lid here on Amazon and it’s a perfect fit.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 4, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

I will be buying the same exact model tefal large size and sauce pans for sure.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 30, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Quality pan', 'author': 'WA-man', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I have bought numerous commercial or chef-grade pan sets for many hundreds of dollars.
