Highly recommend!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 24, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars 12inch pan', 'author': 'Bozskills', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This is an excellant frying pan,for the price. The construction is far superior to those cheap granite stone. The pan is heavier than those other pans so does not warp when heated up.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 11, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Everything about this skillet is great!', 'author': 'Gail Horst', 'rating': 5, 'content': "We had a skillet that the finish was coming off the bottom of it. Love the "New pan" feel!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 22, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

title: Rachael Ray Brights Nonstick Frying Pan / Fry Pan / Skillet - 12.5 Inch, Blue
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars You win this time, Ms. Ray...', 'author': 'Igniz', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I don\'t really care for brands most of the time. If I like the look of the product, or the reviews of the product sit right with me, I will most likely purchase it. So, I didn\'t really care that these skillets are "Rachel Ray."I bought them for the color and the size. I was looking for small, non stick skillets to replace my worn out ones and in that regard they are awesome. I cook daily, at least 2-3 times a day on medium, low heat only. Nothing sticks on em. I cannot say if they are dishwasher safe as I don\'t remember if it said that on the product description, but cleaning them is really easy. I pre-rinse with hot water and remove whatever grime or oil was left after use with the spraying hose, I then just simply use the soft side of the sponge to clean the skillets cooking side, and use the rough side to clean the rest of the skillet. The no stick coating still remains solid. Do not rinse the skillets right after cooking. Let them cool down or it may warp your skillets.The color of the skillets... Its soo nice. I purchased the orange ones. At first, it was a really bright orange color that pop\'d. Now, its a lighter shade of orange mixed with the brighter orange color and it just looks great. The only way I can describe the color is by relating it to the color of cream filled orange Popsicle. As you bite into the Popsicle, the cream mixes with the orange and it produces this delicious lighter shade of orange. Idk, it just works, haha.I really only use the smaller of the 2 skillets as I bought the bundle that has the 9 and 11 inch, or something along those lines. I felt there was no need to use the larger one as the smaller one is able to cook everything I need.The handles on the skillets are pretty solid too. Good grip and feel heavy (the skillet as a whole.) The rubber does not get hot when picking up the skillets.Would definitely purchase again. Don\'t care for the name, but these are great.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 23, 2019', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars You can't go wrong ordering this pan!", 'author': 'IC girl', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Well made will definitely order more, worth every bit of money, cooks evenly, cleans up easily!!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 26, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars Don't watch any of her stuff...but Rachael Ray's pans are superb", 'author': 'Chase', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I don\'t know much of anything about Rachael Ray, other than the fact she has a chicken stock which I\'ve used before and programs with her are typically on at medical facilities, but her brand does make some top notch pans for the price range. I first bought a Rachael Ray 10" pan (orange handle) in 2017 because the wifey wanted a small pan that wasn\'t plain black (she\'s Mexican, so it ain\'t a kitchen without some color). That pan performed so well (even heating, easy to clean, nothing sticks) it became her favorite (mine too, beating out the Tfal) but, it\'s a 10" pan so it had its limitations.Our larger pan, no idea what brand it is or how long we\'ve had it, is just a food magnet. Anything you cook on it, no matter how much spray you use, it would be left with a coating of food. I told the wife we should get a new pan, another Rachael Ray, and she scoffed, "Pans are too expensive, we\'ll wait for a sale". Yeah, we both work so a $24 pan (when I bought it) is SUPER expensive...well, I bought the pan (in a pretty blue) and even though she was slightly annoyed I bought the pan even though she said not to, her tune changed immediately after trying it out. It totally outperforms its $24 price tag and absolutely NOTHING sticks to it. We both love this pan and I\'ll def look into buying a Rachael Ray wok if mine ever gives up (I\'m Asian and it\'s not a kitchen without a wok).', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 27, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars It's a perfect size for two people", 'author': 'RStein', 'rating': 5, 'content': "We are empty nesters and don't cook big meals much anymore. This pan works perfectly for small meals. Two pork chops, two chicken breast, 4 eggs for breakfast or to sauté a few vegetables for a side dish. It cleans up well, is oven safe and easy to store due to its size and weight. I love the red color! I would recommend this to others.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 18, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Nice pan (needed replacing though) but no lid', 'author': 'arseattle', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'We bought this skillet to supplement the entire set that we purchased a week earlier. (We like having one larger pan in our set.)When the pan arrived, the non-stick finish had a few little tiny imperfections; 4 or 5 tiny little bubble-like spots in the surface . . the type of thing you\'d almost think you could pick off with your nail. Since this was brand new, we decided to have it replaced and amazon.com, of course, instantly sent us a return label and shipped another one off.The second one arrived and it had no marks at all. The pans have a bit of heft but they\'re not particularly heavy; they feel well made and the handle is really comfortable. I\'d almost forgotten what it was like to cook in something that\'s really non-stick, after all these years of facing surfaces on our old cookware, and true to its word, nothing sticks on this pan.We\'ve only cooked a few things so far but it\'s been a pleasure using this cookware.There are two thing that bother us, though. (Not including the fact we needed a replacement*)The first thing is that there\'s no lid for the pan and none of the lids from the cookware set fit on the pan. As far as I can tell, there\'s no lid even available . . that\'s too bad \'cause all the other pans have lids and it puts some limitations on usage. Second, since the surface can be scratched, it would be nice if they shrink wrapped the pan so that nothing could mark it up. This was just wrapped in paper in a box.I\'ll update this someday, when we\'ve had some time to really cook with it.*So far this is a solid 4-star pan. Normally, I would take a way a star because the first one was scratched but I\'m in a generous mood. REALLY generous, in fact, \'cause when we received the full cookware set, of the same style, the smallest pan also had a tiny imperfection in the surface. They couldn\'t just replace the small pan so we had to send back the entire set. The next set that came had the exact same thing; there was one tiny little spot in the smallest pan . . . we picked it off and, though you can just make out where it was, it doesn\'t seem to have penetrated the actual non-stick surface. We\'ve decided to cook with it for a while and then reevaluate in a few months. If that spot shows any signs of problems, we\'ll return the one pan via the warranty. Still, when you purchase these pans, take a really close look at the surfaces. (That said, the small pan has been perfect so far . . . non-stick eggs every morning!)UPDATED: January 10, 2013Just thought I\'d check in on this review. We\'ve taken care of this pan (and the whole companion set that we bought at the same time) as best we could. We haven\'t put it in the dishwasher and only use softer utensils and sponges. We\'ve also never used it on really high heat. The non-stickiness has remained as new. There are no scratches or pieces starting to wear off and show up in the food. It still distributes the heat nicely and we have no complaints about cooking in this pan. That said, there are a couple of things we\'ve noticed. First, like a couple of other people mentioned, the outside of the pan (particularly on the bottom) can get nicked up a bit, especially if you\'re stacking pans. The finish still looks great but I can see you have to be careful about knocking these around too much. The only negative thing is that the pan warped a little bit after a few weeks of use. Again, we haven\'t ever used high heat but, though not dramatic, there is definitely a little bit of "non-roundness" to the top of the pan now. As I mentioned, though, we have a full set of these also and no other pots or pans have warped at all; it could just be this particular one.All in all, we still love the pan. I\'ll check in again after a year . . see how it holds up.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 12, 2012', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The size is pretty large', 'author': 'Linda W.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I love Rachel Ray products. reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Finally, a pan that works!!', 'author': 'Errol Carlstrom', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I threw out my old pans & use this for everything! title: 11" Nonstick Frying Pan with Lid - 11 Inch Nonstick Skillets with USA Blue Gradient Granite Derived Coating, Heat-resisted Silicon Handle, PFOA &PFOS Free, Induction Compatible, Ideal Christmas Gift
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Nonstick Excellence!', 'author': 'L. M. Czechowicz', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I was on the prowl for a new skillet, as my last one, of the granite variety, had lost its nonstick ability. I've been through a ton of skillets for the same reason: Tfal, Cuisinart, Calphalon, GraniteStone, etc. I was intrigued by this one because it had tall sides, a lid, and was blue. When it came in, I discovered it actually has mermaid type scales on the side and color shifting glitter on the outside as well. It's really quite pretty. But I didn't buy it for beauty. I bought it because I was tired of scraping burnt cottage cheese out of my granite or cast iron skillet every morning. No matter what temperature I used or what time I added it, the cheese in my eggs always stuck. Not any more! Not only did it not stick, but all I had to do to clean it after I was done was use a dry paper towel and it was spot free (see my first photo). The surface is much less textured than granite or cast iron. I'm exceedingly impressed...and happy I won't be soaking skillets anytime soon!There are many other benefits of this skillet in addition to it being completely nonstick. The deep sides are truly deep, as you can see in the photo of the glittery scales, it holds a lot of food. I have a bad habit of flipping food out of more low profile skillets, but have not had that problem with this one, which means less time scrubbing my stove top clean. The lid is also a nice little piece of engineering as the rubber around the ring helps prevent moisture from bubbling out or over the sides hither, thither, and yon. Instead it escapes from two specific places marked on either side of the lid (photo 3). Unlike the metal rimmed lids that have scalded me in the past, I can turn the lid so that steam escapes where I want it and I can attend to other pots and pans on the stove without worrying about being burned. It's sturdy, but not as heavy as cast iron. It heats evenly and the handle never gets hot. It comes with a Phillips screwdriver so you can attach the handle. All in all, I'm very pleased with my purchase and have found no cons. I can't wait to see what else I can cook in it.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 6, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great Pan', 'author': 'joeglo', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'We really like this pan. It is easy to clean and it looks great. Be careful with the small handle because you can get burned if not careful. The long handle is no problem. Great pan to own.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 18, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Not just a pretty face', 'author': 'O', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Don't be misled by the GERMAN THERMOLON and USA BLUE in the marketing text. This product is manufactured in China.That said, it's a great product. I love the way it looks, and it's a joy to cook in. Time will tell how it holds up to wear, but after a few days of heavy use, it's as good as new and my new go-to for cooking anything I don't need to pop in the oven. The non-stick is very slick, and gives a good sear. The lid fits well, and the silicone edging seems sturdy - I'll stand it on edge while I'm cooking, and it hasn't warped yet. Only minor hot-spotting on a gas range - gets up to temp quick, and the heat is impressively consistent for how light weight it is. Not cast iron level, obviously, but it's on par with our Calphalon pan of similar diameter that weighs twice as much.So far I've used this to brown ground meat, saute aromatics, make gravy, cook burgers, simmer broth, make french toast and omelettes (no stuck egg residue, perfect bake/steaming in the pan with lid on the stovetop), and heat syrup (swirls and pours out cleanly, no stirring implement necessary). Quality cooking, easy clean up. Love it.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 26, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars I think of reasons to use this frying pan!', 'author': 'M. B. Buffaloe', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I have never gotten excited about using a frying pan before, but these make me look for reasons to use them! I really don’t fry an awful lot, but when I do, I can’t wait to get out my beautiful blue frying pan! When I realized that the nonstick coating was failing on 2 of my old skillets, I started shopping around in stores and here on Amazon. Many of the reviews for these Ailwyn frying pans were over-the-top, so I ordered both the 9” and 11” pans. Oh my goodness! These are the perfect frying pans, for so many reasons! They are deep enough to fry just about anything and to make recipes with lots of ingredients. Nothing!! sticks to them. They are the most wonderful nonstick pans I’ve ever had! They distribute the heat evenly, and do well at both very low and very high temperatures. I have been frying chicken for over 40 years, but I made my best fried chicken ever a couple of weeks ago, and the only thing that was different was this frying pan! My husband isn’t the biggest fan of fried chicken, but he was going back for seconds! I can’t recommend these pans strongly enough. Don’t be put off by the color — the pans may look frivolous, with their pretty blue color, but they are hard-working and the best frying pans you’ve ever owned! Almost forgot — the lids are wonderful, too! Clear so you can see through them, and they lie flat for a good seal. They have that wonderful steam hole that every good frying pan lid should have! I really only have one complaint — I wish they made a slightly larger frying pan, too, for the times I’m frying food for a crowd! Ailwyn, if you could make a 12-13” frying pan, you’d make me very happy! Now, what can I fry next?', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 24, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Well-made pan, pay close attention to instructions!', 'author': 'Brenden C.', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'Very nice pan, seems to be pretty good quality. Kinda hefty but it’s a larger pan so makes sense. Non-stick seems to work fine but you need to be a lot more careful and read the instructions that come with it to make sure you don’t put in the dishwasher and don’t try scraping at burnt on food immediately you need to get it under warm soapy water sooner than later or else it can effect the coating. One thing that was nice was it came with its own screwdriver even though I personally have plenty, however, what did bother me is it came with two screws and a bunch of different washers and there was nothing I could find that told me what I was supposed to do with any of them. The screw itself was pretty self explanatory but I wasn’t sure if the other was needed elsewhere or if it was a spare and also I had no idea if I was supposed to use a washer, multiple washer, if it was up to preference, etc. Not sure if there was just another instruction book that didn’t get put in or if that’s just how it is but very confusing either way. Other than that, overall pretty solid pan. Looks nice, very versatile as you can cook anything from a simple grilled cheese all the way up to like a stir fry or even some type of sauce based meal if you choose, and non-stick seems like it should last quite a while if I take care of it right.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 10, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars I love this skillet!', 'author': 'Shelby S. Great quality.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 10, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Color looks different in person.', 'author': 'Shawnna', 'rating': 4, 'content': "To be clear, this is a beautiful skillet. And it does!At any rate, I am very pleased with overall aesthetic, HOWEVER, it looks more purple I the picture to me.In person, it's black with a pretty, twinkly sapphire blue sheen.Very nice but not purple like I thought.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 28, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love it', 'author': 'Jani Downhour', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Breakfast every day', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 24, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

title: Merten & Storck Pre-Seasoned Carbon Steel 10" Frying Pan Skillet, Cast Iron Lightweight, Durable, Sear Grill Broil Fry, Indoor Outdoor Cooking, Easy to Clean, Oven Safe, Induction, Steel Handle, Black
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Being a lover of cast iron pans, I love these pans even more. Seasoning is necessary for both.', 'author': 'Judy L.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I have been a user of cast iron pans for over 15 years. Many of the cast iron pans I have are very old, and were crusted pans that I had to strip the crud off them and season them before they could be used. Some are newer preseasoned pans that I often stripped the seasoning from them to season them again.When I discovered the carbon steel pans, I was intrigued as these pans are much lighter than cast iron. As a point of reference, I also have a number of Le Creuset and Staub pans and Dutch ovens that I love, but are also very heavy and relatively expensive. Before buying, I usually do research to find out about products I am not familiar with.In my research, I found out that materials used in carbon steel and cast iron pans are basically the same except that carbon steel contains 99% iron and 1% carbon vs. cast iron that contains 2%-3.5% carbon and less iron. The additional carbon causes cast iron to be more brittle, so pans are made thicker to help prevent breakage which also makes them much heavier. Since both have a high iron content, they must be oiled to prevent oxidation and rust. Both have pores that absorb oil when heated, hence the creation of the non-stick properties through "seasoning", but the pores in carbon steel are microscopic and much smaller than the pores in cast iron. Because of this, much less oil should be used to season carbon steel than cast iron. If you use too much oil, or do not remove the excess oil as the pans cool, you will end up with a sticky residue on the pan. This is true for both carbon steel and cast iron, and both require some simple maintenance by heating them and coating them with oil after each use. I, personally, use Crisco All Vegetable shortening.A couple reviews mentioned flaking of the surface after use. These pans come preseasoned and coated with a layer of wax to prevent oxidation (rust). The layer of wax must be cleaned off per the instructions before the first use. This is done by washing them in warm soapy water and wiping them with a scrubby sponge to get all the wax off. If this isn\'t done, the wax will flake off when used the first time.At this point, I truly love these pans and will likely sell some of my treasured cast iron. So, what do I love about these pans. 1 - They are so much lighter in weight than cast iron. 2 - These pans are nonstick with the seasoning already on the pans and only gets better with time and proper seasoning after each use. 3 - Carbon steel, as well as cast iron, will continue to look like new if cleaned and seasoned after each use. 4 - Heats and cools much faster than cast iron. For both, medium to medium high heat is all that is needed. 5 - Can be used on the stove and in the oven as well as an induction cook top. 6 - Since carbon steel cools faster than cast iron, it is less likely to burn foods that are not immediately removed. 7 - Nest together well and take less storage space than most other pan. 8 - Can stack together and use metal utensils without the fear of scratching them.In conclusion, I would definitely recommend these pans if you are willing to take the time to maintain them. If you can do this, they will last for years to come.UPDATE 03/31/22:I have 3 of these pans in 8", 10", and 12" sizes, and the two pictured are the ones I have used the most. In the last 4 weeks, I have used these pans quite often, and so far, they are totally non-stick and have not changed in color as I expected them to. Maybe it is something in the way I take care of them. After using them, they are washed with soap and water without any scrubbing. I totally dry them by heating them on the stove to open the pores of the pan, and then add a very small amount of Crisco oil on a paper towel to coat them with oil. After a couple more minutes of heating, I use a paper towel to remove any excess oil. As they cool, more oils beads on the surface of the pan, and this is again wiped off. Before I store them, I wipe them again with a kitchen towel. Although I fully expect these pans to change color over time, it\'s possible they stay looking nice by not letting excess oils stay on them. I do know that leaving excess oil on these pans or on cast iron pans will cause a sticky residue to develop. Built up oils on these pans or cast iron will cause them to look really cruddy and will reduce the nonstick capabilities of both.UPDATE 4/07/22:Today, I found out something about carbon steel pans the hard way. Cooking acidic foods in a carbon steel pan removes the seasoning. I made brats with sauerkraut in one of my carbon steel pans. I browned the brats, and then added the sauerkraut to the pan to heat it with the brats. The pan was fine until I cleaned it and found that part of the seasoning was gone. The pan was down to the bare grey metal in spots. Although this doesn\'t damage the pan, it has to be heated, oiled, and cooled a couple of times to season it again and regain the nonstick qualities of the pan. I also want to mention that when searing meat, you need to get a good sear on the meat before turning it. If you don\'t, the meat will stick.UPDATE 5/13/22:I have added pictures of my 8" and 10" pans that have been used quite a lot since I got them a couple of months ago. I am extremely happy with the nonstick quality of these pans and that they are so very much lighter than my cast iron pans. After every use, I season them as described previously, and so far they haven\'t changed in color. Personally, I believe this is because I don\'t let the oil burn on the pan when I season it as I have also found this to be true with my cast iron pans. All of my cast iron is an even dark black color and also nonstick. In the past, I have had a couple of cast iron pans change color when oil had been left on it for too long and burned. Although the color of the pans will get darker with use and seasoning, I don\'t think they have to become ugly if the patina is developed evenly.I hope this review was helpful for you. I will update the review if my opinion changes.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 16, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars So slippery that it's hard to flip food! How to Keep it Non-stick/UPDATED", 'author': 'dsk', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'UPDATE 12/20/2024:I loved the 10" skillet so much, I bought the 12". They are my goto skillets, without a doubt. I use them daily, many times more than once per day. These are the only pans that I use to make eggs. So, my Merten and Storck fry pans have been used dozens and dozens of times. I\'ve ordered an induction range which will arrive day after tomorrow. These pans will work great on the induction cooktop. I\'ll update with info on how they do with induction and how I have to adapt.I was making tuna patties tonight in the 12" pan. To this day, both pans are non-stick, and I mean so darn slippery that it takes a spatula plus another implement on the other side to flip anything. Even fried eggs just slide around. The pans are almost too slippery.I detailed how to season the pans to keep them nonstick in my original review. I\'ve learned that after reheating and rubbing oil on them a few times that it becomes unnecessary. They\'ll stop soaking up the oil. When you see this, then simply wash them under hot water (when they\'ve cooled down) and dry. I rarely use dish detergent. I have a BLUE 3M scrubber that I use. I only use the BLUE, because it\'s non-scratch. If I think the pan needs more, I\'ll put a very small amount of Dawn on the scrubbing pad, wet it in hot water, wash, rinse, and dry. That\'s all there is to it. I\'ve had no issues with rust. My pans hang on the wall. You can see where oil has polymerized in a couple of places on the cooking surface. This is correct and what it\'s supposed to do. Don\'t scrub it off! It\'s a part of the seasoning. There are 2 things I never do:1. I never soak the pans.2. I never run cool or tepid water into a hot pan to clean it. I always cool them down. Original review:I\'ve read reviews where people think these pans are coated with a nonstick material; they aren\'t. I\'ve also read that you should treat them like cast iron; you DON\'T. Here\'s the right information.First, the pans may have a bluish hue. It\'s not from an applied finish. When you heat carbon steel, you get blue heat marks. Certain metals will so this when heated. You see it more readily in silver colored pans and it\'s natural.These pans are extremely preseasoned. I fried eggs over easy this morning, and they slipped around the pan so much, I had a hard time turning them! This is how you want these pans to perform. I have a carbon steel wok (that was Not pre-seasoned) and I\'ve never had one thing stick in it.Unlike cast iron, you should wash your COLD carbon steel pan, using dish soap, rinsing well. Never ever put a hot pan in cool water; it\'ll warp.After washing and drying, sit your skillet back on the stove. Turn it on to medium-low. Heat the pan. When the pan is hot, use a paper towel to apply cooking oil. You can use olive oil. I think a higher temp oil is better, like corn or vegetable oil. Don\'t let the pan overheat. Just rub the oil around. You\'ll see it disappear into the pan. When the pan isn\'t taking anymore, turn off the burner. After the pan cools, simply wipe off any excess oil and put it away.That\'s all there is to it. Don\'t put in the dishwasher. Just hand wash with dish soap, dry it, heat on a burner and apply oil. It\'ll stay extremely slick.BTW, if you buy a pan that isn\'t seasoned, it\'ll come with a coating of shellac on it to protect against rust. You have to heat it on high heat and burn the shellac off, scrubbing the soot. When you\'re done, the pan looks like these pans, black with a bluish hue.The 10" skillet is a nice weight without being too heavy. The metal handle doesn\'t get hot when cooking on the stove. These are very nice pans!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States July 17, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love my skillet!!!', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I wish I had ordered this skillet a long time ago. I ordered the 10 in pan skillet. The size is prefect for me. It's not to heavy yet not lite weight. Only cooked in it once so far but it was a great cooking experience. It cleans like a charm as well. Yes, I will be ordering other pots and pans from this company. Thanks you.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 9, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Nice carbon steel pan, but not a replacement for cast iron', 'author': 'Joe Abraham', 'rating': 4, 'content': "Love: lightweight, perfect size, safe surface, pre-seasoned, sturdyNot love: seasoning easily removed compared to cast iron.This carbon steel pan is quite useful for many dishes and works well. You need to maintain the seasoning on the pan surface with some care - it's not as robust as cast iron. It also doesn't hold much heat like cast iron, so you are constantly fiddling with the flame to keep it cooking but not burning, but it does a decent job of distributing the heat.With regard to seasoning: if you cook tomato anything, bye-bye seasoning. Any acidic food is a no-no unless you're ready to re-season.Cleanup: highly recommend the method of scrubbing it with coarse salt and a paper towel. This is safe and removes the gunk while leaving the seasoned layer alone. Try to keep water and soap away from your carbon steel pan! Make sure it's absolutely dry and protected with oil before you put it away for the night. Otherwise you'll see a lot of rust in the morning!Generally - you'll almost always want to use some kind of fat or oil to cook with.Also, because it's lightweight, you will still have to go to the gym to pump iron!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States June 29, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Well seasoned out of the box', 'author': 'Kevin', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I've only used it a few times, but eggs slide around well. Worth noting if you're used to Teflon coated pans you might have some trouble. When new, Teflon pans are so non-stick you really don't need any fat in them. Cast iron, carbon steel, and stainless all rely on sufficient fat to make them work. You should also get them a bit hot before you drop the fat in. In a 10in pan like this, I use almost 2 tablespoons of butter before dropping in a few eggs for frying. With this pan, they slide around like crazy when I jiggle the pan.This is my first carbon steel pan. I notice they're very much like cast iron in a lot of ways, but much better in two important characteristics.The first is that they are much lighter. This is obvious, but after using cast iron for a while it's easy to appreciate how much easier it is to flip food with a simple motion of the pan rather than needing a spatula.The second is that, unless most cast iron on this price range, the carbon steel pan is smooth. This makes it super slick when you use it right.Last, like others have noted, you need to take some care when you're done to make sure it keeps working. It becomes second nature after a while. Most of the time I just wipe it out with a paper towel till it looks clean. If there are stuck on bits, I'll use hot soapy water till it's clean and then heat till dry then do a super thing oil coating and let it smoke for a little. Stays slick and is pretty easy.Unless you warp the pan, you can always sand it down and reseason as though it's new. It's also cheap enough that you can probably toss it an replace it if you absolutely must.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 25, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Cooks great', 'author': 'Mykel', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I’ve used cast iron for over 30 years. Recently I used a carbon steel skillet at a restaurant and decided to try one out. This one comes preseasoned but it cooked off after the first few uses. We didn’t die so there’s that. I’ve treated it like my cast cookware and washed with water, heat to dry, then wipe with avocado oil. After daily use for several days it has a nice patina and my eggs don’t stick. I did notice that after dropping a frozen sausage patty on the hot pan that the patina dissolved in the spot. Lesson learned, but it didn’t stick. I’m using wood and plastic utensils only.CAUTION: THE HANDLE GETS HOT. I checked with my temperature gun and with the pan at 300, halfway up the handle was over 200.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 10, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Seasoned cook- this pan is my favorite', 'author': 'Jennifer L. Menke', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I have all kinds of great cookware. Until recently, my favorite pan was an antique cast iron that was a bit lighter weight than other pans it’s size (well know brand called Favorite). Cast iron, for me however, isn’t great for eggs and other stuff I’d typically use a nonstick pan for (teflon, etc). My CHEAP WOK, however, does an amazing job on eggs… so I decided to go with carbon steel like the wok. The higher end brands of carbon steel were still too heavy for my liking though (Mauviel, etc). So I started looking on amazon and found this pan. It is EXACTLY what I wanted and I have used it TO DEATH. Eggs are a dream. I am so happy to FINALLY be able to get rid of my teflon once and for all. The weight, the handle, the seasoning (and the price!!) make this pan a no brained.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 14, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Amazingly non-stick, out of the box!', 'author': 'ERIC ADAMSON', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Gave it a light scrub with a stainless steel scouring pad & a dot of detergent, to remove any wax or other rust protective coatings. Expected to have to reseason, but no worries -- we were off to the races, slippin' & slidin'! I love the entry level price, and feel that this item delivers excellent value.The toughest thing is shifting gears from cast iron. Heat transfer is similar, but heat retention is much lower, creating a tightrope walk between maintaining temp and overheating the skillet. Nothing too rough, just requires awareness.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 5, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Better than regular "non-sticks"', 'author': 'Bronwyn Leroux Writing', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Wanted a pan that provided non-stick without any aluminum content and this works. I\'ve had the pan for about 9 months now and eggs still slide out like they did when new. Pros are I can see this pan lasting way longer than regular non-sticks, healthier option, works with induction stove. Cons are making sure you clean it and season it after each use - which really takes about five minutes, including time to heat pan for oil.Don\'t let seasoning put you off getting a carbon steel pan - really easy - when pan cools, clean it with some kosher salt and paper towel (although I occasionally use water and detergent), rinse out, let air dry, put on stove and heat for about 3-4 minutes medium high heat. Then turn heat off, add about a quarter (money_ sized drop of grapeseed oil, swirl around to get coverage over whole pan, then wipe off excess oil and you\'re done.I considered the Lodge equivalent of this pan at the time, and bought both to compare because I prefer made in USA. Ultimately went with this one though primarily because it was lighter and larger than Lodge. However, if I could pick up a heavier pan, I would\'ve gone with Lodge. As you can see in pics, Lodge heavier because steel is thicker. And while this says "Germany" on cardboard that came with Merten pan, if you turn it over it is made in China. Other comps I noted are base of Lodge seemed better, handles were about the same (both quite long!), finish on Lodge pan was rougher, while that on this pan is smoother.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 3, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Awesome lightweight pan', 'author': 'Kimberly', 'rating': 4, 'content': "We've been using this pan daily for over a year and it's a great addition to our otherwise cast iron only house. It's obviously much lighter weight than a similar sized cast iron. We didn't trust the pre-season (who knows what it was made of!) so we stripped it off immediately and began the seasoning process from scratch. We still haven't achieved an all-over even seasoning, probably because we use a steel spatula most of the time which scratches and wears on the surface, and therefore it isn't perfectly non-stick, but that's okay. My husband, bless his heart, sometimes puts the pan in the sink and allows water to sit on it which produces rusty spots pretty quickly, but they're easy to remove. For the most part, we treat the pan like cast iron - after the pan has cooled, clean with hot water only (no soap unless we really have to, or we will boil water in the pan to loosen gunk), evaporate over a hot burner, apply oil to the hot pan, and then let cool.The first photo shows the pan after cooking ground beef, the second photo is after cleaning with just water and then oiling.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 27, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars It’s my kind of pan', 'author': 'Cara', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'So very happy with this very versatile pan great for pancakes, omelettes or a little bit of stirfried vegetables so easy to flip over what’s inside The pan and it doesn’t stick. Seriously Best pan I’ve found in a long time.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 6, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great little omelette pan.', 'author': 'John L Adams', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Perfect size for a single omelette in about 4 or 5 minutes with sauteed mixed peppers, onion and mushrooms and one slice of bacon. One large or two small eggs whipped with a little milk. Has really made my breakfast decision really easy! My wife loves them. Wish I had gotten this years ago.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 21, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The best pan for pancakes', 'author': 'Haley McDole', 'rating': 5, 'content': "We absolutely love this non stick pan. It's perfect for pancakes. We use it at least once a week. Easy to clean. Lightweight. It is a small pan so easy to store. Durable. Just buy it !!!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States July 19, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars This pan is ALMOST perfect. ALMOST', 'author': 'Changing Fate', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'I make a lot of omelets, as in almost every day I am making one for me. I have used this pan to make them for years now and I wanted to point out a couple of issues that may not be readily noticeable. But first I will talk about the plusses to this item. First, the price is really good for what you get. The surface of the pan has been easy to clean and since mine gets daily use I would say overall it holds up pretty well to the many times I use it. But there are a couple of issues that should be noted.The first, if you will look at the pictures of this pan, you will see the handles are attached by screws. The Screw heads are inside the pan. These Screw heads are not Copper stick free screw heads, therefore if you make thick pancakes or thick omelets like I do, the egg will stick to these screw heads every time. Every Time. I have to spray these screws with Pam in order to use these without it sticking which kinda makes them "almost non-stick" instead of truely no-stick.Second, the hinges are weak. the hinges are made of the flimsiest of all flimsiest metals. The pan surface itself will outlast the hinges by a long shot. Since I use mine to make omelets, having the hinges is important in that it makes it really easy to flip the pan. What should last me many many years only last a few.All that being said, if they would fix these two issues, either construct these with the handles incorporated in the metal and affixed internally and make hinges that are truely made to last, I would easily pay double for one. It does a good job for what I need it to do and would be a tremendous product if they addressed these two issues.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 21, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Works as advertised.', 'author': 'Stephen Worley', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Have used this item quite a number of times. Cooks pancakes quickly. Do not place your burner above Medium heat as the pancake mix will burn. Low heat baking is better and will provide a better outcome. One thing I noticed is that the longer this pan is one the stove burner, the faster the pancake mix cooks. So, you must pay attention to the heat of the pan when cooking. That is my two cents worth. I highly recommend this product for single pancake cooking. From my standpoint, it works as advertised.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 5, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Okay', 'author': 'Allyn L', 'rating': 3, 'content': "It's not quite what I hoped, but it's okay. Heats and cooks quickly. Seems flimsy.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 27, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Easy to use', 'author': 'kai', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This pan is small, but perfect for regular sized pancakes and omelettes. Even grilled cheese sandwiches. I only have used the pan for omelettes, but as long as you spray with nonstick spray and flip quickly, your eggs will turn out perfect! Also, make sure you cook the first side long enough to ensure that the heat contained in the enclosed pan has almost fully cooked the eggs, so they won't be super runny when flipping them. I haven't had any issues with the hinge, but I could see it being somewhat weak after a while of continued use. I don't use mine very often. Maybe once every couple of weeks. Good luck!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 30, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Fun to use!!', 'author': 'Vickie', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Fast delivery. Not hard to use, only use up to 3egg omelet otherwise gets messy. Doesn’t stick slides right out!! Grilled cheese too!!!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 11, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars It is a great pan but.....', 'author': 'Joy', 'rating': 4, 'content': "This is a great pan for something you need to flip like pancakes or eggs or burgers whatever, however do not buy the claim that it is so stick free that you can make pancakes without any oil. I tried every possible way to do this without oil, adhere to the instructions and it made an absolute mess, first side sticks, and when you try to flip it you get a big dripping mess of pancake batter streaming out of the pan and onto your stove. In order to get it to flip without oil you have to try to loosen it up with a spatula before flipping and what's the point if you need to use a spatula on this. However if you put a little oil before you put the pancake batter in, it will flip properly, sometimes with a little jerk down motion will make it drop. You don't need a lot of oil just a few drops swirl it around and you're good to go. Because this does work with oil I'm keeping it as it is a very nifty tool in the kitchen. It is also why it's not getting five stars.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 5, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '1.0 out of 5 stars So wrong', 'author': 'PhotoGraphics', 'rating': 1, 'content': 'Whenever I have seen any item, no matter what it is, that has the As Seen on TV sticker I know it’s going to go badly. This thing was no exception, so why would I have bought it anyway? I had one and only one task for it in mind, and that so seldomly durability was not that important to me. My one use for it was to make one large pancake for myself for breakfast onto which I could put a fried egg or any other topping of my choice. So my first question, one that any manufacturer of such a product would have in big bold letters, was what is its diameter. Nowhere on their ad page could I find one word about that, only that it is “large” and that it is two-inches thick. I would never in my life expect to make a pancake two inches thick so I don’t know why I would want to know that.IT GOES DOWNHILLThe breathless worded ad copy continued in the royal tradition of the seen on TV tradition, including the extensive use of the word copper as if it has a health benefit. Okay there are some claims about wearing a pure copper bracelet that some say to have magical qualities but are you ready for the honest truth now? There isn’t evidence of an ounce of copper in this thing, it is only a copper colored non-stick coating, or at least supposedly non-stick. As if that farce wasn’t enough they actually go on to say, or make you think they say, that it is made from titanium encrusted with diamonds. That is so funny I can hardly type the words without laughing. No, it is aluminum with a copper colored coating. The cleverly worded fine print is that it has a “diamond sparkle look coating”. And the wording “titanium ceramic” seem to be some well disguised trademarked terminology. So much for believing what you see on TV.QUALITYIt doesn’t sound right to use the word quality in a sentence describing this thing, but to be fair it only cost twenty bucks, about what a cheap frying pan cost at the discount store. I always suggest to read the one star reviews first and this is a great example of that, they are spot on accurate and you know they aren’t planted by employees of the maker. They all point to the extremely bad hinge design that is uses two pop rivets that are almost guaranteed to break. Even being really careful with it it’s just not designed well. Yes but isn’t it true that I went ahead and bought it anyway? I admit to that, but I said earlier that I expected to use it maybe once or at the most twice a month, and the only thing that attracted me over an ordinary frying pan is I am really bad at turning pancakes over and the best ones are cooked equally on both sides. I didn’t want yet another electric appliance because most of them don’t heat 100% evenly anyway, this held the promise, weak as it was, that it could spread the heat more evenly on my electric stovetop and I told myself that if I wait until the pancake (or even an omelet) as half cooked it shouldn’t leak out if I flip it over really fast. That idea sort of works but if I can’t see the food cooking I would have to experiment many times to get it even half right. One detail I did not like was that the rivets used to attach the handles are prone to having food stick to the crevices, which would make it a chore to clean it.SIZE MATTERSMy opening thought was about the diameter. Not trusting gadgets like this I had high hopes that they weren’t trying to pull another fast one on me and that it wasn’t anywhere near as big as they make it look. My instincts were right, I had hopes this would make one pancake that’s big enough for an adult, that would be about nine inches, but no, the maximum working area inside the pan is only a meager five inches. Using their directions it would take me about five minutes to make one five inch pancake. If I wanted four of them, which I guess is a full stack, it would take me at least 20 minutes to make breakfast for myself. On the same subject, since the pan tapers down to around five inches it is smaller than the smallest burner on my stove, which means the rising heat would eventually scorch the entire pan.THE FINE PRINTHere’s the shocker. Cleverly hidden inside the box, looking like one of those warranty sheets that no one ever reads, on the reverse side is a contract. No seriously, it is a lengthy legal contract that tells you that you already agreed to a long list of terms and conditions when you pressed the “buy” button, including giving up your legal rights and having to pay your own costs for any legal action. I have never seen anything so audacious on any product in my life and that instantly dropped their rating to zero and I put the thing back in the box and returned it. As public notice I do not accept or agree to any conditions they say I agreed to by buying this thing and by accepting my return Gotham Steel/Emson has agreed to my terms which will be available to them upon written request. On every count this is thing is rejected.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 15, 2023', 'is_verified': True}]

reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars T-fal Signature Nonstick Cookware Set: A Kitchen Game Changer', 'author': 'James Cumbee', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I recently acquired the T-fal Signature Nonstick Cookware Set from Amazon, and I can't express how much it has transformed my cooking experience. It has elevated my cooking game without breaking the bank.In conclusion, the T-fal Signature Nonstick Cookware Set has become an integral part of my kitchen. It has simplified my cooking routine, allowing me to create delicious dishes with ease and convenience. Whether you're a seasoned chef or a beginner in the kitchen, this set is a five-star investment that will undoubtedly enhance your culinary adventures. I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone looking to upgrade their cookware.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 9, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great quality', 'author': 'Mandi', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'These pans are great quality for the price. Sturdy but not heavy. Cook well. Easily cleaned. Love them so far!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 1, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars No stick video attached- shot with one hand (the other held camera)- no butter or oil used!!', 'author': 'Jeneane Vanderhoof', 'rating': 5, 'content': "The media could not be loaded. I had T-fal when I got my first apartment- it was given to me as a gift and my first complete set of cookware ever. So when it came time to purchase a new cookware set, I went through Amazon and saw T-fal- for everything you got in the twelve-piece set, and you couldn't beat the price- and I knew it was top-of-the-line cookware (in my opinion), from previous use.Everything I needed was in the set- except for the bigger cooking pot. So I bought my birthday present for myself. And yes, cookware is a gift item, in my opinion, even when bought for the home- because it is so nice. And there was nothing more that I wanted than some good cookware to make my life easier- and nicer- to make better food for my loved ones.Let me tell you about the video I made to illustrate my point- of how T-fal is top of the line, high quality made and no other line can give you what T-fal does, at the price- Please excuse that I had to make the video by myself. And I had no stick to hold my phone- only one hand and the other- and these old hands have nerve damage and problems so know that I tried my best.I mixed an egg and poured it into the bare pan- meaning no butter, no oil, just the egg mixture (which was only eggs beaten in my mixing cup). Watch as I cook it (one-handed, the other videoing), and how nothing sticks, it all came up great-- you can see for yourself how nothing sticks!!And, in the video- look and see that there are no signs of oil, butter, or anything that could help the egg not stick. (And excuse the large scraper- while I could have used the one that came with the set- I figured instead of unpacking it, I'd use the one that we had out). All that is there to help prevent sticking is the wonderfulness of T-fal's non-stick technology. Honestly, it was all amazing- to again cook with T-fal and see the wonders of great heat distribution (which also helps the non-stick), along with the non-stick elements.Had I known what would happen next, I would have kept the video rolling but one-handed and all, I quit as early as I could- not knowing how to edit videos either (yet). But I took the pan to the sink to wash it- all I really needed to do- and did- was take a paper towel and wipe the access off. And then it was sparkling clean- nothing left to wash. The picture I included after the video was the pan after it was wiped out with a paper towel, no other cleaning was needed (or done). Especially since no butter or oil was used. And even though the egg was a little bland without anything to grease the pan- I added a little salt and thought how much better my health would be- without clogging my pores with oil and butter.All the T-fal in the set are that amazing. And while I would add more photos of it- the pan is the smallest of the set that I used- all the others look as they appear online in photographs- you don't really need my extra photos because they look the same at home as they do on Amazon.I think the set I had was great for me when I was younger- because at that time I hadn't mastered cooking in a way that made me want to be patient- cook right- and spend the time doing it. Youth can be that way. This is why this set is great- it makes up for the error of youth and the impatience- because that is normally when you are going to get things that stick to the pan- with that kind of attitude. So if you are looking for anyone's set of first cookware- you have found it.But now I take the time to cook and do it well. Even master complicated dishes that take a long time.- however, I want some good cookware to do this. T-fal is still the best for me. Also- for those health issues I have- I would like to cut out added butter and oil- especially when I use it just for the non-stick element and the recipe would be great, still, without it. As you saw in my video- no butter or oil is needed.I am so happy that T-fal has stayed affordable, and even become more affordable over time. This whole set was an amazing price- I didn't pay more than $10 per item- with all that was included- which is amazing when you look at the quality. A small pan that works this well should see for over $20 on its own.Thanks to T-fal for being such a large part of my life- and making it so much easier with the best cookware ever!Please note: I shot the video with one hand to work on everything, the other was on the camera. Sorry I'm not really set up to make great videos- wish I was but I tried my best to show how great the pan is. Also, the second photo shows it after cooking the eggs in the pan and I used a paper towel to wipe out whatever didn't land in the bowl. What was left- a clean pan needing no further wash!!Addition to Review on 11/13If you watched my video, you see that I used a metal spatula- which isn't the best idea with T-fal. If you want to keep the great results of the pots and pans, use the included plastic spatulas and spoons- While nonstick seems like magic, it needs to be treated well to keep working. I just wanted to add this- so people don't follow my bad example. My husband actually reminded me of this, after seeing the video and chiding me on my bad decision, so I don't ruin our new pots and pans (and my birthday present to myself). Isn't that the reason we keep em' around ;)?", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 27, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "4.0 out of 5 stars decent product, but not great. I'll explain", 'author': 'Kaniki', 'rating': 4, 'content': "I bought the black 12 piece set. I have only cooked with them once so far and made eggs in one and cooked maple flavored sausage links in the other. Here is my impression of them. First, the final impression in short and to the point, then why I felt that way..The cliffnotes (short) version..Nice lids that fit on both, the pots and pans.. decent handles on the pots and pans, but not great.. easy to dent pots and pans.. very very cheap utensils.. Ok for single person, couple, or starter set.. Not great if you have kids (you know that they will get damaged 10 times faster with kids around) or if you like caramelizing things like meats to make gravies to stews.. OK for the price but not worth retail. Non stick works, but dont expect the slide around egg effect like you see on TV.. Made in china..Full, Description version of my review...The 3 utensil pieces (spoon, flipper, etc) do work, but I'll be honest, I have bought some in the past at the dollar tree, that were, yes you guessed it, a dollar, and they were made much better. The ones included do work but are not very strong, nor do I think that they will hold up to much use over time. But hey, you didnt buy this set for the utensils, you bought them for the pans, so what do you expect. they will work fine until you get to the store (or order off the net) to buy better ones.The lids to the set are pretty well made. they have plastic over the handles will keep you from burning your hands if you have to remove the lids and feel like it will hold up OK over time. there is a plastic, or silicone spacer between the handle rivets and the glass so that should help protect the glass from breaking due to the metal up against glass. Also, the lids fit perfectly on both, the fry pans and the pots, so you have a way to cover both without having to worry about splatter.. Just cant do both at the same time obviously.Now for the pots and pans.the handles feel decently made. Not great, but pretty good. On a scale from 1 to 10, 10 being great, i would give the handles a 6.. maybe 7 if i was feeling generous. They feel like they will hold up to normal use with no problem, but dont try to abuse them or you may have problems. and it may not be the handles fault, it may be the pot or pan part itself.The Nonstick coating works good from what I have seen so far. I cooked eggs in one, and did not need to use any butter to keep them from sticking. The eggs did not slide around like you will see them do on TV, but they did not stick either. They came right up with no problem and did not break the yolks either. The sausage links I cooked in the other pan never stuck either. I washed both out and dried them by hand and you could not see any kind of mark like they were ever used. so the coating did not peel at all, nor did cooking the food leave any marks.Now for the bad.. the aluminum that the pots and pans are made from is not extremely durable. When taking them out of the packing, one of the pots hit up against the flat pan, and guess what.. It dented.. Yes, that little hit was all it took. I have other good quality pots and pans with non stick coatings that are made out of aluminum too, and they can get hit 5 times harder and not dent.. The aluminum in these is a bit of a softer aluminum, so you have to watch or expect a lot of dents in your pans. But on the positive side of that, because of they way and type of aluminum that they are made out of, they are also light.. it is kinda like comparing whipped cream cheese to brick cream cheese.. one is much softer and lighter.. that is these.Another downfall, which I was not happy to find out, was that they were made in china. I did a search on amazon for american, or USA made pots and pans.. These were at the top of the list. Obviously I should have checked into it a little more and not trusted amazon to be accurate here, and for that reason, I did keep them, after all, they will work fine for what I want, but just to be clear.. China made, not American!!!One things that I never see that I would like to point out though, especially for first time buyers of non stick cookware. Non stick does have its advantages, like not having to use any kind of grease or oils when cooking, but at the same time, there is one major flaw to non stick coatings.. you can not brown food.. I have heard it as browning, glazing, caramelizing, etc. These cook the food fine, but you know how you take a roast and brown or caramelize a roast so that it gets that nice brown glaze in the bottom which is really good if you plan on making home made gravy, or for flavoring the stock in a roast so the flavor goes into the other foods when you cook a roast.., From what I have seen, any non stick pan i have ever used sucked at giving any kind of that browning or caramelizing. It cooks the food with not problem, but you dont get that bit that makes good flavoring or gravy material. If you plan on it, get a pan that is non stick for that purpose.. then after you do the initial caramelizing of the meat, then put all that in these pots if you want. but that is one major draw back to non stick coatings on cookware.Overall, they are not bad, but not great. They will work fine for a single person, or for a couple. For a decent first set, they are not bad either. If you are someone that gets their pans knocked around a bit (maybe put it in the sink then put stuff on top and clean everything later), then expect to get a lot of dents in these over time. Considering that you get these for under $10 per piece, they are not bad for the price, but i would say average priced for the set. I would not pay anywhere near the retail price for these because they are not worth that much, in my opinion at least. If they were more expensive, i probably would have given a 3 start instead of 4, but I tool price into consideration vs quality when I gave it 4 stars. In the end, it all depends on how you cook as to if these are good for you. Personally, I'll take my old club aluminum pots over these any day of the week.. but that is just my opinion. But also, luckily for me, these are for someone else, not for me, so i dont have to worry about it. :)........................................Update on info about them...according to the manual, they are good for gas, spiral or solid electric, ceramic (radiant) and halogen rangetops.also, the temp rating on them for the oven is.. 350f/175c with plastic handles or stainless steel handles with silicone inserts. 450f/230c for full silicone handles. 500f/260c for handles made completely out of aluminum or stainless steel. cookware with soft touch translucent portions is not oven safe. and never use them in the broiler.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 18, 2014', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The Ultimate Cookware Set for Every Kitchen!', 'author': 'Atahan D.', 'rating': 5, 'content': "The T-fal Signature Nonstick Cookware Set is a game-changer in the kitchen. From the diverse selection of pans to the impeccable non-stick ProGlide interior, cooking and cleaning have never been easier. The Thermo-Spot Technology is ingenious, eliminating any guessing about when the pan is ready. Whether you're sautéing, searing, or simmering, this set guarantees even heat distribution for consistently delightful meals. Plus, the durable design compatible with almost all cooktops and oven safety up to higher degrees adds to its versatility. It is a must-have set for both novice and seasoned chefs. Highly recommended!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 29, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars So far so good!', 'author': 'Amanda Weisbrod', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I’ve had these pans for about a month now and I really dig them. They’re easy to clean, get the job done, and are affordable. I haven’t put mine through the dishwasher even though they are supposed to be dishwasher safe because I ruined my last set of Cephalon pans that way 😬', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 17, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great set!', 'author': 'Rapeseed', 'rating': 5, 'content': "These pans are wonderful. Just great all around. Tops in every category. If you're looking for a great cookware set, look no further. I absolutely recommend these. Very nice!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 28, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Heats Up, Cleans Easy', 'author': 'J Mac', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I bought these pots and pans to use with a cooktop stove. hoping they would live up to previous reviews. I prefer cooking in stainless steel, even though food always sticks to the surface. I never leave stuck-on food to sit in the pan. It is not terribly difficult to clean, even with hot water alone. This set looks nice and shiny. The weight feels durable enough for me. The pans have that magnetic bottom layer expected for induction cookware. It heats up much faster than previously owned ones without it. However, non-stick it is not. The sausage and egg I fried in this small pan stuck like glue right away and started to burn quickly even with an oil coating. (I probably had the heat too high.) What I expect of stainless steel. Overall, I am satisfied with the set and plan to keep it. I'll just try lowering the heat to prevent sticking.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 27, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Me encanta', 'author': 'Estefany María', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Las ollas son muy buenas, el tamaño es adecuado, las comidas se cocinan más rápido que con mis antiguos calderos y se lavan mucho más fácil. Trae un instructivo muy claro sobre cómo cuidarse y trae utensilios de plásticos para no rayar la superficie.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 24, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Wonderful Set', 'author': 'Terrie McGhee Bedgood', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I love this set and highly recommend. I have ordered other sets made by T-fal and I'm always more than satisfied. Highly recommend.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 6, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

I usually buy packages of 3 chicken breasts, and the 10-inch nonstick skillet I usually use has very low walls and is filled to the brim when I want to fry the 3 breasts at one time. But the 3 breasts fit great in this pan, and no splattering of grease like in my other shallower skillet. This has definitely made this my new favorite skillet. Other little things I like: It's not too heavy but is heavy enough. The see-through lid has a steam vent hole. The handle is very ergonomic and easy to hold onto (same for the handle on the lid). This has become my new favorite skillet. Very pleased with it.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 14, 2023', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Best Pan Ever!!!!', 'author': 'JC', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This is hands-down the best frying pan I've ever used. It's very similar to a cast iron skillet, but less upkeep.I love the handle on the lid as it makes it easy to remove without burning your hand. The handle on the pan also has a temperature gauge which I really appreciated.Red means it's cold, white means it's hot.so many perks to this pan including an easy pour spout on both sides which is great for draining grease or excess liquid.I would give this more than 5 stars if I could. Complete game changer in my household.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 23, 2023', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Decent pan', 'author': 'Lisa Love', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'This is a decent pan. I prefer this smaller size since large pans are to much for me to clean and handle in general. The taller sides help keep the grease inside instead of splattering all over the stove. I like the temperature indicator on the handle (red for cool, white for hot). The nonstick coating works well. And I like that this comes with a lid. I look forward to seeing how well it holds up over time.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 29, 2023', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars THE PERFECT SIZE NONSTICK PAN -- FOR EVERYTHING', 'author': 'TRIPLE CCC', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This is a fantastic pan. It’s wide enough to make anything I want in it; and it’s deep enough to make anything I need in it. I can cook steak, chicken, fish in it. Because it heats up so quickly and well, I can sear steak in this pan. Because it has a fantastic non-stick surface, I can cook delicate fish in it.I make a lot of rice dishes, but none of the nonstick skillets I have are deep enough to comfortably make rice for more than two people. The Vinchef is deep enough for me to make any rice dish, from risotto to paella — without the rice sticking — for six people.I can make all sofritos in this pan, even if I’m going to then transfer the sofrito to a stockpot full of black beans and water. I can also use the Vinchef as a wok. And yes, the Vinchef is deep enough to fry plantains in it. Or chicken, or fish sticks, or whatever suits your fancy.And let’s not forget pasta sauce. To really make pasta the way it’s made in Italy, you need to finish cooking the pasta in the sauce. The Vinchef is big enough so that I can now throw my pasta in the sauce, with a little pasta water, and finish cooking it in the bubbling sauce.I also love the two pouring spouts on the lip of the pan, and the super cute handle on the lid!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 1, 2023', 'is_verified': False}]

title: MsMk 10 Inch Frying Pan Nonstick with Lid, Induction Fry Pan with Lid, Titanium and Diamond Non Stick Coating From USA, for Induction, Ceramic and Gas Cooktops, Oven Safe 10 Inch Skillet Nonstick
reviews: [{'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars It's larger than you think", 'author': 'Lois', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This pan is surprisingly deep, and really a perfect size for a 2 person family. We have an induction range (altho this would work with any type stove), and had bought the 12 inch, which we love. I thought the 10 inch wouldn't be used much, but I'm putting the 12 inch away. These handles are not just super sturdy, they don't get hot sitting on the cook top for a while. It works well even for searing, for a stick free pan. The glass lid is durable, and this pan is reasonably priced for its quality. I highly recommend, and no one compensated me for this review.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 1, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Well made, good value.', 'author': 'taylor', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Three months use and it has taken the number one spot over my Le Creuset and a non-coated Calphalon for ease of use. Quality construction, good handle, good lid, good rivets. Lightweight material but thick enough to dissipate gas heat. Did not bother to season it. Cannot evaluate surface life span, but no hint of even faint scratches after about 30 meals. I start with a light touch of olive oil, use silicone tools and hand clean. Do not know how it will clean up with seriously burnt-in food.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 15, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars The steam vented lid fits perfectly & my sunny sude-up egs slide off!', 'author': 'Jack Broderick', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Cooks my breakfast special flawlessly with effortless clean-up. Note: Remember to allow pan to cool prior to washing!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 28, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great value', 'author': 'Lisa Leonard', 'rating': 5, 'content': "The size is perfect and it's nonstick is is incredible food slides right off its cost more but we fill the quality is well worth it will buy more pans and pots from the company indeed", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 24, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Not a good first impression. But was happy with the replacement.', 'author': 'Lyndon', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'The media could not be loaded. This is an update to my original review.After receiving my replacement pan I very carefully looked it over for any damage or flaws and did not see any, initially. However, I can find flaws on anything I look closely at. I did eventually find one, but this little blemish did not bother me like the gouge on the first one I received. There was a minor "nick" on the edge of the non-stick at the outer rim of the pan. (see added photos)Let\'s get the thing that I didn\'t like out of the way. The lid. I was cooking on a low heat and burned myself when taking the lid off. A different handle would be nice. One that doesn\'t carry the heat like this one does. Also, there is a pocket between the glass and the rim that will hold liquid. It is a real pain to try and get it clean and dry.Okay, now for the good stuff that I did like. In my testing I tried both an induction cook top as well as a gas stove for my experimenting. I tested for heat distribution, discoloration, slipperiness, flatness and over-all cooking performance. First I just wanted to break in the pan to heat and check how well it boils water on the induction. The boil was rather quick. About 4 minutes from tap water to begin boil at a 320 deg cook top setting. The boil was pretty even and extending to the outer parts of the pan surface pretty well for a medium priced pan. No discoloration that I could see. Of course I wasn\'t applying a tremendous amount of heat.I rinsed the pan out and wiped it dry. Clean and dry within a few wipes and seconds. Nice. Then I made some taco meat. See the video I added showing a low flame and spread out heat dispersion. I Like it. The pan performed well without any meat sticking or burning. Sliding stuff out of the pan into a container is a challenge. Everything slides to the edge and wants to all come out at the same time. So I needed to get a very wide container and it still wanted to dump all over the counter. I think the sides might be a bit steep in my opinion. After that I rinsed and dried and again, zip-zip, clean and ready for some Chorizo y Juevos. The meat cooked great, just as the ground beef did. Nice and low, even heat. Then I transferred it to a standby skillet so I could wipe the inside and do 8 scrambled eggs. No surprise at this point that the eggs scrambled up nicely for such a large quantity at once.I mixed in the chorizo and then into a container. Yep, again, food dumped on the counter because I did not have much control pouring it out of the pan.I then dunked the mostly cooled pan in a sink of dishwater, wiped it out with a sponge, short rinse and quick dry. All in all a good cooking experience. The pan is a keeper for me as long as it doesn\'t fail later by losing its surface or having the bottom warp. The base of the pan did discolor slightly from the gas stove but I had expected that and I did get a little scratching from the stove grates, but that\'s expected too.If you are willing to expect a pan be delivered with some blemishes or even not just "perfect", then I would say this pan works well otherwise. Blemishes, lid and pouring lose a star. Other than that I am so far happy with it.Original review...What I expected was a really nice pan in a quality and new condition. I was excited in waiting for it but I was quickly disappointed by what I saw when I took it out of the box.Take a look at the photos I included. There was a very noticeable blemish on the base that I saw almost immediately. When looking closer I saw that it was a gouge of sorts. If you look closely at the zoomed photo you can also see a bunch of other scratches around the gouge as if it were mishandled prior to packaging. There was absolutely no damage to the box it was packaged in. So the only other way it could be this way is if it was produced this way.I cannot even try it and give an honest impression of what it is like to cook in it. I felt the gouge and it is quite apparent that it is going to scratch the cook top surface I would be placing it on. The base is also rather rough feeling aside from this gouge. I expected it to be smooth as satin to the touch from the description in the ad.If the pan is already damaged before I can even have a chance to try it, then what is the point of even moving forward to see what the performance of this skillet is?I\'ll spend the week to try and contact the manufacturer about this issue and see what they say before boxing it back up and returning it. Not sure if I want to exchange it. The quality issues could be an ongoing thing with this brand. Hopefully they are responsive to my contact attempt.I\'m really sorry I had to review it this way. I was really hoping to love this frying pan. But it is what it is and now I need to do something about it, darn it.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States April 26, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Just as advertised', 'author': 'Barbara Walkley', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Even cooking; easy to clean', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 22, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect size and easy to handle', 'author': 'KR Johnson', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This skillet is the perfect size.
