title: Merten & Storck Pre-Seasoned Carbon Steel 10" Frying Pan Skillet, Cast Iron Lightweight, Durable, Sear Grill Broil Fry, Indoor Outdoor Cooking, Easy to Clean, Oven Safe, Induction, Steel Handle, Black
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Being a lover of cast iron pans, I love these pans even more. Seasoning is necessary for both.', 'author': 'Judy L.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I have been a user of cast iron pans for over 15 years. Many of the cast iron pans I have are very old, and were crusted pans that I had to strip the crud off them and season them before they could be used. Some are newer preseasoned pans that I often stripped the seasoning from them to season them again.When I discovered the carbon steel pans, I was intrigued as these pans are much lighter than cast iron. As a point of reference, I also have a number of Le Creuset and Staub pans and Dutch ovens that I love, but are also very heavy and relatively expensive. Before buying, I usually do research to find out about products I am not familiar with.In my research, I found out that materials used in carbon steel and cast iron pans are basically the same except that carbon steel contains 99% iron and 1% carbon vs. cast iron that contains 2%-3.5% carbon and less iron. The additional carbon causes cast iron to be more brittle, so pans are made thicker to help prevent breakage which also makes them much heavier. Since both have a high iron content, they must be oiled to prevent oxidation and rust. Both have pores that absorb oil when heated, hence the creation of the non-stick properties through "seasoning", but the pores in carbon steel are microscopic and much smaller than the pores in cast iron. Because of this, much less oil should be used to season carbon steel than cast iron. If you use too much oil, or do not remove the excess oil as the pans cool, you will end up with a sticky residue on the pan. This is true for both carbon steel and cast iron, and both require some simple maintenance by heating them and coating them with oil after each use. I, personally, use Crisco All Vegetable shortening.A couple reviews mentioned flaking of the surface after use. These pans come preseasoned and coated with a layer of wax to prevent oxidation (rust). The layer of wax must be cleaned off per the instructions before the first use. This is done by washing them in warm soapy water and wiping them with a scrubby sponge to get all the wax off. If this isn\'t done, the wax will flake off when used the first time.At this point, I truly love these pans and will likely sell some of my treasured cast iron. So, what do I love about these pans. 1 - They are so much lighter in weight than cast iron. 2 - These pans are nonstick with the seasoning already on the pans and only gets better with time and proper seasoning after each use. 3 - Carbon steel, as well as cast iron, will continue to look like new if cleaned and seasoned after each use. 4 - Heats and cools much faster than cast iron. For both, medium to medium high heat is all that is needed. 5 - Can be used on the stove and in the oven as well as an induction cook top. 6 - Since carbon steel cools faster than cast iron, it is less likely to burn foods that are not immediately removed. 7 - Nest together well and take less storage space than most other pan. 8 - Can stack together and use metal utensils without the fear of scratching them.In conclusion, I would definitely recommend these pans if you are willing to take the time to maintain them. If you can do this, they will last for years to come.UPDATE 03/31/22:I have 3 of these pans in 8", 10", and 12" sizes, and the two pictured are the ones I have used the most. In the last 4 weeks, I have used these pans quite often, and so far, they are totally non-stick and have not changed in color as I expected them to. Maybe it is something in the way I take care of them. After using them, they are washed with soap and water without any scrubbing. I totally dry them by heating them on the stove to open the pores of the pan, and then add a very small amount of Crisco oil on a paper towel to coat them with oil. After a couple more minutes of heating, I use a paper towel to remove any excess oil. As they cool, more oils beads on the surface of the pan, and this is again wiped off. Before I store them, I wipe them again with a kitchen towel. Although I fully expect these pans to change color over time, it\'s possible they stay looking nice by not letting excess oils stay on them. I do know that leaving excess oil on these pans or on cast iron pans will cause a sticky residue to develop. Built up oils on these pans or cast iron will cause them to look really cruddy and will reduce the nonstick capabilities of both.UPDATE 4/07/22:Today, I found out something about carbon steel pans the hard way. Cooking acidic foods in a carbon steel pan removes the seasoning. I made brats with sauerkraut in one of my carbon steel pans. I browned the brats, and then added the sauerkraut to the pan to heat it with the brats. The pan was fine until I cleaned it and found that part of the seasoning was gone. The pan was down to the bare grey metal in spots. Although this doesn\'t damage the pan, it has to be heated, oiled, and cooled a couple of times to season it again and regain the nonstick qualities of the pan. I also want to mention that when searing meat, you need to get a good sear on the meat before turning it. If you don\'t, the meat will stick.UPDATE 5/13/22:I have added pictures of my 8" and 10" pans that have been used quite a lot since I got them a couple of months ago. I am extremely happy with the nonstick quality of these pans and that they are so very much lighter than my cast iron pans. After every use, I season them as described previously, and so far they haven\'t changed in color. Personally, I believe this is because I don\'t let the oil burn on the pan when I season it as I have also found this to be true with my cast iron pans. All of my cast iron is an even dark black color and also nonstick. In the past, I have had a couple of cast iron pans change color when oil had been left on it for too long and burned. Although the color of the pans will get darker with use and seasoning, I don\'t think they have to become ugly if the patina is developed evenly.I hope this review was helpful for you. I will update the review if my opinion changes.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 16, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars So slippery that it's hard to flip food! How to Keep it Non-stick/UPDATED", 'author': 'dsk', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'UPDATE 12/20/2024:I loved the 10" skillet so much, I bought the 12". They are my goto skillets, without a doubt. I use them daily, many times more than once per day. These are the only pans that I use to make eggs. So, my Merten and Storck fry pans have been used dozens and dozens of times. I\'ve ordered an induction range which will arrive day after tomorrow. These pans will work great on the induction cooktop. I\'ll update with info on how they do with induction and how I have to adapt.I was making tuna patties tonight in the 12" pan. To this day, both pans are non-stick, and I mean so darn slippery that it takes a spatula plus another implement on the other side to flip anything. Even fried eggs just slide around. The pans are almost too slippery.I detailed how to season the pans to keep them nonstick in my original review. I\'ve learned that after reheating and rubbing oil on them a few times that it becomes unnecessary. They\'ll stop soaking up the oil. When you see this, then simply wash them under hot water (when they\'ve cooled down) and dry. I rarely use dish detergent. I have a BLUE 3M scrubber that I use. I only use the BLUE, because it\'s non-scratch. If I think the pan needs more, I\'ll put a very small amount of Dawn on the scrubbing pad, wet it in hot water, wash, rinse, and dry. That\'s all there is to it. I\'ve had no issues with rust. My pans hang on the wall. You can see where oil has polymerized in a couple of places on the cooking surface. This is correct and what it\'s supposed to do. Don\'t scrub it off! It\'s a part of the seasoning. There are 2 things I never do:1. I never soak the pans.2. I never run cool or tepid water into a hot pan to clean it. I always cool them down. Original review:I\'ve read reviews where people think these pans are coated with a nonstick material; they aren\'t. I\'ve also read that you should treat them like cast iron; you DON\'T. Here\'s the right information.First, the pans may have a bluish hue. It\'s not from an applied finish. When you heat carbon steel, you get blue heat marks. Certain metals will so this when heated. You see it more readily in silver colored pans and it\'s natural.These pans are extremely preseasoned. I fried eggs over easy this morning, and they slipped around the pan so much, I had a hard time turning them! This is how you want these pans to perform. I have a carbon steel wok (that was Not pre-seasoned) and I\'ve never had one thing stick in it.Unlike cast iron, you should wash your COLD carbon steel pan, using dish soap, rinsing well. Never ever put a hot pan in cool water; it\'ll warp.After washing and drying, sit your skillet back on the stove. Turn it on to medium-low. Heat the pan. When the pan is hot, use a paper towel to apply cooking oil. You can use olive oil. I think a higher temp oil is better, like corn or vegetable oil. Don\'t let the pan overheat. Just rub the oil around. You\'ll see it disappear into the pan. When the pan isn\'t taking anymore, turn off the burner. After the pan cools, simply wipe off any excess oil and put it away.That\'s all there is to it. Don\'t put in the dishwasher. Just hand wash with dish soap, dry it, heat on a burner and apply oil. It\'ll stay extremely slick.BTW, if you buy a pan that isn\'t seasoned, it\'ll come with a coating of shellac on it to protect against rust. You have to heat it on high heat and burn the shellac off, scrubbing the soot. When you\'re done, the pan looks like these pans, black with a bluish hue.The 10" skillet is a nice weight without being too heavy. The metal handle doesn\'t get hot when cooking on the stove. These are very nice pans!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States July 17, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love my skillet!!!', 'author': 'Amazon Customer', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I wish I had ordered this skillet a long time ago. I ordered the 10 in pan skillet. The size is prefect for me. It's not to heavy yet not lite weight. Only cooked in it once so far but it was a great cooking experience. It cleans like a charm as well. Yes, I will be ordering other pots and pans from this company. Thanks you.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 9, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Nice carbon steel pan, but not a replacement for cast iron', 'author': 'Joe Abraham', 'rating': 4, 'content': "Love: lightweight, perfect size, safe surface, pre-seasoned, sturdyNot love: seasoning easily removed compared to cast iron.This carbon steel pan is quite useful for many dishes and works well. You need to maintain the seasoning on the pan surface with some care - it's not as robust as cast iron. It also doesn't hold much heat like cast iron, so you are constantly fiddling with the flame to keep it cooking but not burning, but it does a decent job of distributing the heat.With regard to seasoning: if you cook tomato anything, bye-bye seasoning. Any acidic food is a no-no unless you're ready to re-season.Cleanup: highly recommend the method of scrubbing it with coarse salt and a paper towel. This is safe and removes the gunk while leaving the seasoned layer alone. Try to keep water and soap away from your carbon steel pan! Make sure it's absolutely dry and protected with oil before you put it away for the night. Otherwise you'll see a lot of rust in the morning!Generally - you'll almost always want to use some kind of fat or oil to cook with.Also, because it's lightweight, you will still have to go to the gym to pump iron!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States June 29, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Well seasoned out of the box', 'author': 'Kevin', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I've only used it a few times, but eggs slide around well. Worth noting if you're used to Teflon coated pans you might have some trouble. When new, Teflon pans are so non-stick you really don't need any fat in them. Cast iron, carbon steel, and stainless all rely on sufficient fat to make them work. You should also get them a bit hot before you drop the fat in. In a 10in pan like this, I use almost 2 tablespoons of butter before dropping in a few eggs for frying. With this pan, they slide around like crazy when I jiggle the pan.This is my first carbon steel pan. I notice they're very much like cast iron in a lot of ways, but much better in two important characteristics.The first is that they are much lighter. This is obvious, but after using cast iron for a while it's easy to appreciate how much easier it is to flip food with a simple motion of the pan rather than needing a spatula.The second is that, unless most cast iron on this price range, the carbon steel pan is smooth. This makes it super slick when you use it right.Last, like others have noted, you need to take some care when you're done to make sure it keeps working. It becomes second nature after a while. Most of the time I just wipe it out with a paper towel till it looks clean. If there are stuck on bits, I'll use hot soapy water till it's clean and then heat till dry then do a super thing oil coating and let it smoke for a little. Stays slick and is pretty easy.Unless you warp the pan, you can always sand it down and reseason as though it's new. It's also cheap enough that you can probably toss it an replace it if you absolutely must.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 25, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Cooks great', 'author': 'Mykel', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I’ve used cast iron for over 30 years. Recently I used a carbon steel skillet at a restaurant and decided to try one out. This one comes preseasoned but it cooked off after the first few uses. We didn’t die so there’s that. I’ve treated it like my cast cookware and washed with water, heat to dry, then wipe with avocado oil. After daily use for several days it has a nice patina and my eggs don’t stick. I did notice that after dropping a frozen sausage patty on the hot pan that the patina dissolved in the spot. Lesson learned, but it didn’t stick. I’m using wood and plastic utensils only.CAUTION: THE HANDLE GETS HOT. I checked with my temperature gun and with the pan at 300, halfway up the handle was over 200.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 10, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Seasoned cook- this pan is my favorite', 'author': 'Jennifer L. Menke', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I have all kinds of great cookware. Until recently, my favorite pan was an antique cast iron that was a bit lighter weight than other pans it’s size (well know brand called Favorite). Cast iron, for me however, isn’t great for eggs and other stuff I’d typically use a nonstick pan for (teflon, etc). My CHEAP WOK, however, does an amazing job on eggs… so I decided to go with carbon steel like the wok. The higher end brands of carbon steel were still too heavy for my liking though (Mauviel, etc). So I started looking on amazon and found this pan. It is EXACTLY what I wanted and I have used it TO DEATH. Eggs are a dream. I am so happy to FINALLY be able to get rid of my teflon once and for all. The weight, the handle, the seasoning (and the price!!) make this pan a no brained.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 14, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Amazingly non-stick, out of the box!', 'author': 'ERIC ADAMSON', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Gave it a light scrub with a stainless steel scouring pad & a dot of detergent, to remove any wax or other rust protective coatings. Expected to have to reseason, but no worries -- we were off to the races, slippin' & slidin'! I love the entry level price, and feel that this item delivers excellent value.The toughest thing is shifting gears from cast iron. Heat transfer is similar, but heat retention is much lower, creating a tightrope walk between maintaining temp and overheating the skillet. Nothing too rough, just requires awareness.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 5, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Better than regular "non-sticks"', 'author': 'Bronwyn Leroux Writing', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Wanted a pan that provided non-stick without any aluminum content and this works. I\'ve had the pan for about 9 months now and eggs still slide out like they did when new. Pros are I can see this pan lasting way longer than regular non-sticks, healthier option, works with induction stove. Cons are making sure you clean it and season it after each use - which really takes about five minutes, including time to heat pan for oil.Don\'t let seasoning put you off getting a carbon steel pan - really easy - when pan cools, clean it with some kosher salt and paper towel (although I occasionally use water and detergent), rinse out, let air dry, put on stove and heat for about 3-4 minutes medium high heat. Then turn heat off, add about a quarter (money_ sized drop of grapeseed oil, swirl around to get coverage over whole pan, then wipe off excess oil and you\'re done.I considered the Lodge equivalent of this pan at the time, and bought both to compare because I prefer made in USA. Ultimately went with this one though primarily because it was lighter and larger than Lodge. However, if I could pick up a heavier pan, I would\'ve gone with Lodge. As you can see in pics, Lodge heavier because steel is thicker. And while this says "Germany" on cardboard that came with Merten pan, if you turn it over it is made in China. Other comps I noted are base of Lodge seemed better, handles were about the same (both quite long!), finish on Lodge pan was rougher, while that on this pan is smoother.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 3, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Awesome lightweight pan', 'author': 'Kimberly', 'rating': 4, 'content': "We've been using this pan daily for over a year and it's a great addition to our otherwise cast iron only house. It's obviously much lighter weight than a similar sized cast iron. We didn't trust the pre-season (who knows what it was made of!) so we stripped it off immediately and began the seasoning process from scratch. We still haven't achieved an all-over even seasoning, probably because we use a steel spatula most of the time which scratches and wears on the surface, and therefore it isn't perfectly non-stick, but that's okay. My husband, bless his heart, sometimes puts the pan in the sink and allows water to sit on it which produces rusty spots pretty quickly, but they're easy to remove. For the most part, we treat the pan like cast iron - after the pan has cooled, clean with hot water only (no soap unless we really have to, or we will boil water in the pan to loosen gunk), evaporate over a hot burner, apply oil to the hot pan, and then let cool.The first photo shows the pan after cooking ground beef, the second photo is after cleaning with just water and then oiling.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 27, 2024', 'is_verified': True}]

title: USA Pan 5-Ply Stainless Steel Chef Skillet, 7-Inch
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect size for 1-2 person household', 'author': 'Bird Mama', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This pan is great for sauteing veggies, sauces, and preparing eggs. The sides are slightly curved so whatever you're cooking stays where the heat is. It is a bit more expensive but well worth it for the quality, cooking outcome, and ease of cleaning.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 1, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Well worth the price!', 'author': 'Kurt', 'rating': 5, 'content': "We got the 8inch USA Pan Stainless Steel Chef Skillet. Normally I wouldn't buy such as expensive piece of cookware but it turned out to be well worth the money! I am by no means a chef, but maybe with this skillet there’s hope! The pan is wide enough and deep enough for a one-pan dish without worry of overflowing. The pan is super shiny, even after a couple of washes and a burnt sauce incident (again, not a chef). Although it is heavier than it looks, it is quite sturdy and well made. I’ve only had it for a couple of days now, but made quite a few meals already. We have an electric stove top that’s infamous for not heating our pans evenly, burning some parts and not heating others at all. That was not the case at all with this skillet! We made pancakes in it and they turned out wonderfully golden brown and not half-cooked like with our other pans. My fiancé accidently cooked some vegetables in a sauce a little too long that wound up burning quite badly. I wasn’t too happy that she almost ruined our brand-new and quite frankly, expensive pan. After a quick soak though, it was as good as new! Not a speck of burnt residue or discoloration at all! I was amazed. After scorching a chicken dish, my fiancé and I learned that we do not need to use as high heat as with our other pans, which is nice. Like I said, the pan is heavier than it looks and quite deep for a pan of its size. We got adventurous and used it to try our hand at frying (this time shrimp tempura), which was catastrophic with other pans. Because the skillet is so deep, we were able to fit enough oil and shrimp without spattering and making a mess. The oil stayed at a constant temperature and they turned out wonderfully. After mastering the temperature difference (you’d be surprised), we also used less oil and butter because nothing stuck and so much healthier for us. The pan is still as shiny as when we first got it, after all of our mishaps. We just soaked it in warm water with some soap for a while and most of it came off under the running water! We didn’t even need to use a scrubby sponge (which I don’t recommend on any pan, reason we are buying a new one). I do wish for the price we paid, that it did have a lid, but they are sold separately unless you buy the whole entire set. (Which may wind up on our wedding registry though). If the rest of the set is as well made as this skillet I would definitely highly recommend the entire set. Overall, I can’t say enough awesome things about the USA Pan. It was the first USA Pan we’ve ever bought and it’s safe to say we’ll definitely buy some more in the future!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 9, 2014', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Works great but smaller than expected', 'author': 'Promila', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'Pan is great but has smaller cooking surface as compared to other pans of same size. Size is the only reason giving it four stars. Heat distribution is uniform, makes one egg nicely but two eggs crowd the pan and makes a thicker egg. Cooling and cleaning is easy, easily washes in dishwasher too. We have been using this pan for some time now and still has the same original color and looks new.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 29, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars USA PAN ROCKS!', 'author': 'Hutchison C.', 'rating': 5, 'content': "USA Pan is the best! The quality can't be beat. They cost a couple of dollars more because they are made in the United States but they are worth it. I wish they had not closed down their pots and pans line on their website. I have ordered directly from them in the past but had to get this pan through Am*z*n. A true classic.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 22, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars Best pan I've owned so far!", 'author': 'J. Moreno', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Hello all, I have purchased this pan less than a week ago and received it Friday (7/17/15). This is my first stainless steel pan. I decided to purchase this particular pan because:1) Price ($30?!?! What?!)2) 5 ply (Again, what?! For only $30??)3) Made in U.S.A4) I needed something small for eggs!In the past, I have tried cooking with non-stick pans and Lodge cast iron pans and with both I have failed miserably. I know what you\'re thinking, how did I fail to cook on cast iron?! Well, everything just burned on the pan for me despite proper care. When I purchased this pan I found it interesting that similar pans by competitors cost nearly 3 times as much and they might not even be made in the U.S.A!Since this is my first stainless steel pan, I looked up "how to cook with stainless steel" and most of the websites I read expressed to use the water droplet test to find out when the pan is ready. You\'ll know when you pan is at the right heat when you place some droplets of water in the pan, they come together and form a "ball" and just moves around the pan without evaporating. This is when you know when your pan is ready for butter/oil! (Thanks paleoleap.com!) Once I found the right temperature (about 3.2-3.4 on my electric stove) I made some delicious eggs. I even made scrambled eggs the way I like them for the first time in my life. I have never been able to make scrambled eggs on any other pan. When I was done, the pan came out fairly clean, I just had to wipe it down with soap, water and my sponge.One of the other reviewers wrote that it takes a minute or two to release the food. I didn\'t understand what that meant, but after cooking on it for a couple times, I know what it means for the pan to "release the food." It does take a minute or two for the egg to become free to be turned. I made the mistake of using a metal spatula at first and it did scratch the pan slightly, but not so badly that the pan became ugly. I ended up purchasing Epicurean Gourmet Series Utensils, Medium Turner, Natural/Black Nylon to compliment the pan (it\'s also made in the USA!!) and it has done a wonderful job thus far.To summarize, this a low cost, high quality pan that cooks great food. I highly recommend this pan to anyone who wants the quality of All Clad, but at a reduced cost!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States July 21, 2015', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Very nice quality pan.', 'author': 'Storybook Kitten', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I really like this pan. I made pasta with shrimps and food did not stick. The toasted bits on the pan were nicely toasted and added to the flavor of the food. Nice size for one or two people servings. It\'s perfectly heavy and very solid. Cleaning is a breeze. I only wish I had an option to buy a lid for it. This is a 9" inch pan.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 13, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '1.0 out of 5 stars Poorly balanced, not a flat bottom, tips over, hard to clean', 'author': 'music lover', 'rating': 1, 'content': "Don't understand all the great reviews for this pan. It's a nice shape and size, but everything else is extremely disappointing. Bottom is not flat and the handle tips the pan over whether there is something in it or not, so it wobbles on the burner. The bottom is higher in the center, which is easy to see when you put a little water in a dry pan and watch it make a donut pool around the dry center.I have nothing but stainless cookware and know how to cook in these pans, but after one simple saute, the inside finish of this was ruined: no shine, rough areas on the sides, a lot of effort with gentle, non-scratch cloths, but could never get it clean. A complete waste of money.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 17, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '2.0 out of 5 stars Extremely difficult to clean, not counter balanced well..', 'author': 'Dallas Electronics Fan', 'rating': 2, 'content': "I like the size and that the supplier advertises this as made in the US. I don't know if that means the steel is domestically produced or if it's only formed and assembled in the US. The term 'Made In The USA' is tricky. Buyer beware.Full disclosure: any criticisms I have about this could be due to my lack of knowledge of the finer points of cookware and cooking. I'm not a 'foodie' and use this for two things primarily: eggs and mushrooms. Many other reviewers seem to be happy with this.First thing I noticed is that the pan is not well balanced. The handle is too heavy relative to the pan. When clean and empty, it barely sits flat. Blowing on the handle is enough to tip it. This isn't as much of an issue when counter weighted with food. Regardless, I prefer a more well balanced and stable design for the peace of mind.In comparison, I also have 'vintage' stainless steel cookware passed down from my grandparents and Emiril stainless steel/copper bottom cookware. Both are very well designed, counter balanced well, very safe and effective to use, easy to clean.Cleaning: this pan is a nightmare to scrub clean. Scrambled eggs are the worst. In spite of preheating and using cooking oil or sometimes a small amount of butter to coat the pan before use, removing the debris afterward is beyond even a steel wool brillo pad.I finally bought a small chain-mail scrubber but even with that, it takes at least 10lbs of down-force and a good 1-2 minutes of scrubbing to remove debris and then a follow up with a brillo pad for good measure. I've also tried soaking it with dish soap for hours and even overnight. Even that barely loosens up the debris.My other stainless steel cookware cleans up easily. It requires a soak sometimes but nothing more than that. I don't know why this is so difficult. I've used a lot of cookware over the years and never had an issue like this. I suppose a metallurgist would have to explain.Bottom line, your experience may be completely different. Aside from the two issues I have with this, it is well made and should last indefinitely short of it being physically damaged. If the supplier addresses the two issues above (different steel alloy?) and the balance issue, I'd give it 5 stars. As-is, the best I can do is 2 stars.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 9, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars They make good products!', 'author': 'Michael J. Gorga', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'I prefer to buy US products, which almost impossible since china owns most of the US. US Pan makes some good, although expensive, products. I have 3-4 different ones and like the heat distribution of these - as well as them being stainless steel and not aluminum, which IMO, should not be used to eat off of, let alone cooked in.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 15, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Great little pan, but not heavy enough', 'author': 'Kasi623', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'The media could not be loaded. I love the size of this little pan and it cleans up easily and nicely. The only negative is that either the pan needs to be heavier or the handle needs to be slightly lighter because the pan tips even with food in it. I still like it and use it, but I have to be sure to move ingredients away from the handle side if I don’t want it to tip on the burner or counter.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 4, 2023', 'is_verified': True}]

title: HOMICHEF 11 Inch Nonstick Frying Pan Glass Lid - 11 Inches Frying Pans Nonstick with Lid Induction Compatible - Nickel Free Stainless Steel Omelet Pan Nonstick - Nonstick Fry Pan Vented Glass Lid
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Sturdy', 'author': 'Leslie', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I was at that place where you know you need to throw away your old nonstick pan & look for a new one & I usually shop locally so I can see how they feel in person. I have been cooking on this pan for two weeks now and throwing everything I could at it. I am not a big fan of non-stick pans but decided to try this one just to see if the claims were true. I was surprised to say the least. I am using an induction stove and just getting the hang of it so I am warry of the types of pots/pans that can be used. The thickness of the bottom provided quick heat up and even distribution of the heat. I overloaded a batch of Italian sausage to see if the cooking was even. Since the \u200bsausage is fatty in nature, I used almost no olive oil in the pan and there was absolutely no sticking. Clean up was almost too easy with a rinse in warm water. The real test came with scrambled eggs and a tiny pat of butter on the pan just for flavor. The eggs cooked up nicely and evenly in a timely manner. The eggs were done to perfection and slipped right out of the pan onto the plate. Clean up, again, was warm water! I would recommend this pan to anyone who likes a sturdy, well-balanced cooking vessel.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 21, 2019', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Works great !', 'author': 'Lisa Monfort', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'great pan', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 27, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '1.0 out of 5 stars Ok', 'author': 'Heather', 'rating': 1, 'content': "So far they heat evenly and quickly. title: T-fal Specialty Nonstick Sauté Pan 12 Inch Oven Safe 350F Cookware, Pots and Pans, Dishwasher Safe Black
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Outstanding multipurpose pan!', 'author': 'KH', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This 12" everyday pan from T-fal exceeds my expectations. I love the handles having a heat safe covering, a feature difficult to find on a pan like this. The instructions say you can use the pan itself in the oven to 350 degrees F, but this is not a pan I would ever consider for the oven. If you\'re looking for a pan to put in the oven this may not be the choice for you with the covered handles (I recommend cast iron for combo of stove and oven cooking if you\'ve got the strength for it). If you just want to use it on your stove top I highly recommend this pan.I have substantial injuries to my upper body and some carpal tunnel as well. What I was most pleased with was that the pan is substantial, but light. The lid is definitely the heavier of the two pieces, but not horribly heavy by any means. It cooked quite evenly and cleaned up like a breeze using one of those newer silicone "sponges" for dishes. I also like the cool touch handles and the matte finish on it very much. The small vent in the lid is a nice touch as well.I feel it\'s an affordable item for those who want consistent results in their cooking coupled with easy clean up. Recommended!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 14, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Well made. Should last many years with the proper use and care.', 'author': 'Allworkandnoplay', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'The T-fal 12" Deep Everyday Pan with Lid, model #: A8428464 (Discontinued by manufacturer) is well made and I expect it to last for many years given proper use and care. I am guessing that most of the negative feedback regarding warping is from overheating the pan. The only drawback that I\'ve noticed to date is that it slides too easily across a glass top stove. I hope that the following answers some of the questions that you may have.*Manufactured in China.*Non-stick interior.*Non-stick exterior.*Silicone handles (Oven safe to 350°F/175°C).*Tempered glass lid with steam vent.Use and care instructions before first use.*Wash in warm soapy water, then rinse and dry with a soft cloth.*It is recommended to "season" the pan prior to its first use. To season, wash the pan thoroughly and dry. Heat pan on low for 30 seconds, remove from heat and put one tablespoon of cooking oil in pan. Rub oil over the entire surface of the pan with a paper towel. Repeat every 10 dishwasher cycles or if accidental overheating occurs.General recommendations*Use only low to medium heat only (including to boil water). High heat will damage the pan.*Never let the pan boil dry and never leave an empty pan on a heated burner.*Never cut food directly in the pan or gouge the non-stick surface.*Non-stick cooking sprays are not recommended and and can leave an invisible buildup on the surface that will affect the pans non-stick properties.*Let the pan cool before cleaning to prevent warping caused by extreme temperature shock.*Avoid any extreme temperature changes.*Wooden or plastic utensils are recommended.Oven and broiler use*Always use potholders when moving the pan in and out of the oven.*This pan is oven safe to 350°F/175°C.*Do not use this pan under the broiler.Helpful hints on lid use*When removing the lid during cooking, tilt the lid to direct the steam away from you to avoid burns.*Keep hands and face away from the steam vent.*Do not place a hot lid under cold water as the temperature change may cause the glass to break.Handles*Handles can become very hot under certain conditions. Always use potholders when taking in and out of the oven.Cleaning*Hand-washing the pan and lid is recommended (Because of the short handles, it easily fits in the sink).*Always wait for the pan and lid to cool before washing to prevent warping (This is extremely important).*Wash pan and lid in warm, soapy water using a cloth or soft sponge.*Never clean with abrasive cleaners or scouring pads, scouring powder, steel wool or oven cleaner.*This pan can be cleaned using a dishwasher but remember to re-season with cooking oil after every 10 dishwasher cycles.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 21, 2015', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Weight is perfect', 'author': 'Roberta', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I am a senior and don't like heavy pots &pans...the size is perfect because I make a lot of stir frys , weight is perfect too...I can't deal with heavy pans...cleans easily and actually fits in the sink as compared to the ones with the long handles...highly recommend to anyone, but especially seniors...oh, cooks well too😃", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 25, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Cooks great ..but watch those SHARP edges on the handle', 'author': 'Rick E.', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'Have only used it a few times .... but it cooks and cleans very well. There are very sharp ends where the side handle is connected to the pot. Easy to get cut on those. Caveat Emptor', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States July 4, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars A very good pot', 'author': 'Pat D', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This pan is a very nice size (12 inch diameter by 2.75 inch high) and weight and adaptable for all kinds of cooking it is also oven safe to 350° F. It has radiating rings on the underside for even cooking and is non-stick on the inside and outside. It has a thermo spot in the center which turns red when the pan reaches ideal cooking temperature. The handles stay cool are a good size and make it easy to lift the pan. When using in the oven I would suggest using potholders as a precaution and due to the handles being made of cool touch material I would avoid using it under a broiler. The glass lid is a plus and has a valve on one side to allow steam to escape. A very good buy', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 25, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent pot', 'author': 'sandra', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I like this pot. Perfect way to cook anything. It's nonstick. The lid is glass so you can watch the food without letting out the heat. The 2 handles is a great way of lifting the pot easily.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States September 18, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars You really can't beat it", 'author': 'Kevin', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I bought this to replace an older, similar pan I've had for years. First thing I looked for was if T-fal had one in the size I was looking for. I LOVE their pans! Thankfully they had one of the same diameter and this one is a little deeper.Super easy to clean and very sturdy given how lightweight it is. I like that it has two short handles instead of one long one. It makes it easy to have more pots/pans on the stove at the same time. It may seem trivial to some people but I like that the lid has a hole in it to allow excess moisture to escape. If you need a non-stick pan this size, this one is the way to go.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States June 11, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Durable', 'author': 'RUSH', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I like that its truly a multi purpose cooking pan. I use it for all my meal preps. Easy to clean and great vented see-through glass lid.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 28, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Does it all!', 'author': 'John', 'rating': 4, 'content': "This pan is larger than any of the burners on my ceramic stove...I would love a 10 inch version of this but it doesn't exist from any manufacturer. That said, it's also lightweight without being cheap, cleans up easily, has an excellent nonstick coating, and the depth makes it useful for pretty much anything you can throw at it. It's replaced a whole set of frying pans because it does it all! The center does seem slightly elevated so your oils will tend to move off to the side, but that's more of an observation...it hasn't caused any issues for me. The handles can also get a tad warm which I wasn't expecting. Overall though, I love this pan.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 21, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Less Sturdy than T-Fal that I am Replacing.', 'author': "Don't Take My Kodachrome Away", 'rating': 3, 'content': 'First pan arrived damaged. title: MICHELANGELO 8 Inch Frying Pan Nonstick, Small Frying Pan with Lid, Omelet Pan Nonstick with Ceramic Coating, Nonstick Pan with Lid, Ceramic Frying Pan with Glass Lid, Blue
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars I use this alots', 'author': 'Jon5793', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Perfect size I need to cook my breakfast! Also any frozen foods.Very good quality and durability.I can clean easy but be careful burn food. It might get black stain.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 30, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect egg skillet for convection range', 'author': 'Jacob A. Ratner', 'rating': 5, 'content': "When we converted to a convection range we had to get rid of all of our cheap aluminum non-stick coated pans. No problem really cause I mostly cook with cast iron anyway. But the one thing I need non-stick for is eggs. I don't know how anyone manages to fry or scramble an egg on cast iron or uncoated stainless. This did the trick just fine. Great non-stick surface, very nice glass lid (a big selling point for me), easy to clean and durable surface (no chipping or flaking, although I'm only using silicone implements in it). Only complaint is that the handle gets water in it when I run it through the dishwasher (yes, obviously I could hand wash it).", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 3, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Good but slightly convex', 'author': 'Josh B', 'rating': 4, 'content': "It's a fine pan, but the bottom is slightly convex, which is pretty annoying for that type of cooking. Oil will pool around the outsides rather than cover the whole pan.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 24, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great size', 'author': 'Rhonda', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Great size to cook a few biscuits covered on top of the stove. Interior is great. heats evenly', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 27, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars I stole this skillet!', 'author': 'Bakyet', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This non-stick frying pan was a steal. It has far exceeded my expectations. I cannot yet comment on it's durability as I have only had it a short-time but it cooks evenly and cleans super easy.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 7, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Uneven heating and poor nonstick performance', 'author': 'Roger D. Martin', 'rating': 3, 'content': 'I have yet to find a nonstick frying pan that can last for more than a year of daily use. Now, less than 6 weeks after purchasing this pan, I am seeing signs that it won\'t last even a year. Although the surface still looks new, foods have been sticking more and more in the last few weeks. I\'m crossing my fingers it doesn\'t get any worse, but I\'ve been using nonstick pans for 25 years and they all seem to start degrading after a few months.This pan is very lightweight, which my 12 year old son likes, but that translates into uneven heating performance. This 10" pan doesn\'t work on the 11" burner of my induction stove (it doesn\'t detect it and shuts itself off), so I have to use the smaller 8" burner. Unfortunately, the center of the pan gets much hotter than the edges, so my omelettes end up overcooked in the middle and runny on the edges.The best parts of this pan are the low price and the glass cover. But a couple weeks ago I purchased the much more expensive Cuisinart frying pan so that I can make a decent omelette. I\'m not sure what the warranty is with the Michelangelo (web page doesn\'t say anything) but at least with Cuisinart you get a lifetime warranty and they will replace your pan once the nonstick surface starts deteriorating (I\'ve done this a couple times in the last 5 years).', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 30, 2020', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Good quality', 'author': 'patricia wuestenhagen', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This pan seems to be of good quality and sturdy construction. As I have had this item just a short time, I cannot speak to the durability of it. It is very easy to clean.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 23, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Just what I was looking for', 'author': 'lt', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I bought this based on the reviews of other buyers. I basically use it for frying 2 eggs. It’s perfect! My other pan was too small. I scrambled eggs today and I could tell that this will be a perfect omelette pan also.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 9, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "4.0 out of 5 stars Don't drop the lid", 'author': 'Rebecca McGaughey', 'rating': 4, 'content': "This is a super nice, light-weight non-stick. Just don't drop the lid - I was putting mine into a floor cabinet when I dropped mine, so maybe 2 feet away from the ground, and it shattered everywhere. They don't sell replacement lids unless you want the super ugly universal pot/pan lids they sell. Keep that in mind if you're a bit clumsy like me.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 31, 2022', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars The center area was not flat', 'author': 'Buckaroo', 'rating': 3, 'content': 'The area in the center of the pan was higher than the edges, that made any liquid of semi liquid put on the pan, run to the edges. could not fry an egg without the yolk part staying in one side while the egg white run along the edges on both sides. So half the egg would be on one side and the white running along both edges. Looked like a face with two horns.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States April 18, 2023', 'is_verified': True}]

title: Cuisinart Stainless Steel, 5.5 Quart Sauté Pan w/ Cover, Helper Handle, Chef's Classic, 733-30H
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent and versatile pan', 'author': 'julian', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I bought this pan to see if I can use stainless steel and this is phenomenal. This pan is so versatile. I can make chicken, braise beef short ribs, sauté and do so much more. This is great for one pot meals. It arrived in perfect condition. It is easy to clean. I let the pan cool then fill it with water. Most of the time I can clean it right away after using no problem.. I don’t have any issues cleaning my stainless steel pans. It’s nonstick if you use it properly. I use medium to low medium heat. That’s more then enough heat to get a nice braise or sear because of how well this heats up. Heat distribution is also good. I’ll be switching over to an all stainless steel set in the future. This is very well made. I scratched the bottom but that was my fault and it still looks beautiful. It’s on the bottom and nobody can even see it. It holds up. Is very sturdy and can fit a lot of food as you can see I fit a whole butterfly chicken. It looks so nice. Great price. I took a picture of the pot after I used and cleaned it a few times. I’ll get barkeepers friend to keep them shiny and new looking. I hand wash and dry right away to preserve them. This is going to last a long time I hope.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States May 26, 2021', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent pan for the price', 'author': 'Joseph M. Cone', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I'm an avid cook and frequently use cast iron and stainless cookware. I needed a good saute pan and I was seeing prices close to the two hundred mark for the good, well known brands. I also saw the extreme of thirty dollar pans that were very light and extremely thin. I saw the Cuisinart Chef's Classic for under sixty dollars and saw the good reviews it had. I purchased it and I'm glad I did. It is not as heavy duty as Al-Clad and some of the high end brands, BUT it is considerably more robust than the cheaper pans. I cook on a gas stove and find that this pan heats up really well on a medium-high setting and doesn't have the hot spot like my cast iron pans have. Chunks of meat will brown evenly throughout the pan and I don't have to rotate pieces in and out of the hot spot like I do on the cast iron pans. This pan is a great size. I use it to cook for 3-4 people and can easily load it up to serve twice that many. Very versatile and easy to clean. I love using this pan for stews and such where I can brown the meat, saute vegetables and then add water and seasoning and let it simmer for a while. The lid fits well and the helper handle is a nice feature for when the pan is loaded down and is heavy. Even though only the bottom has the aluminum core, I find that it cooks very well and has good heat retention. The other brands are heavier and I'm sure are great for professionals, but for me, I think this this pan is awesome and I'll take the extra hundred dollars I saved and buy more cookware like this.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States June 21, 2014', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Purchased Jan of 2013 & still going strong', 'author': 'Tony', 'rating': 5, 'content': "No pictures on this initial review of this item. Just know that after 10, almost 11 years, this is a durable, and sizable sauté pan. I use this for family dishes and it's my favorite for a variety of multi-ingredient pasta dishes I make. It holds a huge amount of food to feed the entire family. It heats evenly and cleans up well. Stainless construction means you can cook healthy with no unusual coating concerns. And lastly, the rivets that hold the handles on the pan and stainless lid are just as tight as when the pan was new. And yes, this pan gets used weekly, and is definitely not babied.We're thrilled to have this 5.5 Qt saute pan and cannot recommend it enough.This is a solid 5-star item.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 2, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent', 'author': 'Mark', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Once again, Cuisinart hits a home run, this was just what I needed as a replacement for a Calphalon pan. So many dishes you can prepare with this, and the price is incredible. The quality is excellent, and very easy cleanup, this is why I keep buying Cuisinart products, they just work.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 18, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars decent, mine arrived warped, can be fixed', 'author': 'Sebastian Hahn', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'When it arrived, it was warped upwards at the center, causing oil to run to the edges of the pan instead of spreading out equally, and the opposite for heat distribution I guess. Hard to tell about heat since I was making a sauce (pizza sauce, using homegrown tomatos; saute garlic in oil first, before adding the previously blanched tomatoes and spices, and simmering for 30 minutes or so, then cool and puree).After I cleaned the pan, I took it outside and beat it (thorougly) with a rubber mallet until it seemed flat.Tested it today ( I made the pizza sauce and used the pan for the first time yesterday), sauteeing some mushrooms (pizza topping). Idk if it\'s perfectly flat after I "fixed" it, but oil and seemingly heat both spread evenly across the pan now.It didn\'t warp back up while sauteeing the mushrooms, so it must\'ve been some manufacturing defect or maybe I recieved someone else\'s return, idk. Or maybe damaged during shipping.In any case, I think I\'ll be pretty happy with it.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 16, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': "5.0 out of 5 stars You won't be dissapointed", 'author': 'By His Mercy', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This hands down was one of my best purchases for 2023! This is the perfect pan size for pan frying chicken as all of your chicken will fit in there all at one time. The distribution of heat also made it an excellent pan while make sauce for a large group of people. I would definitely repurchase this item.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 14, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Fantastic', 'author': 'andrew barker', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This pan works even better than non stick pans and is big enough to hold most recipes. Keep in mind for anyone who does not know stainless steel, make sure you YouTube how to properly heat it up cause I can promise you, if you follow those directions, nothing will ever stick and 9 out of 10 times it's incredibly easy to clean with little to no effort required", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 29, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Wonderful value', 'author': 'MeghanMN', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Function: We love this pan. It filled a serious hole in our kitchen supplies and now handles all our large meals. We do a lot of fish frying, stir frying, “one pot” meals, and the like in this pan. I love love the large flat space and even heat distribution. Especially for thin fish, this has been great. I also love being able to transfer from stovetop to oven for many of our go-to recipes. Prior to owning this pan, my husband did all the frying and I thought it was because I didn’t know how to do a good job, but it turns out I’d just never had a non-temperamental pan. Bonus: its large size cuts down on the amount of oil that jumps out of the pan and all over the stove and counter when my husband cooks!Cleaning: It does NOT function like a coated, non-stick pan but if you follow the instructions for both cooking and cleaning, your food will not stick and it’s very easy to clean. I despise dishes but I’m always happy to clean this because it usually handles the whole meal prep, so even though I have to hand wash it, I have less to do than most other nights. I use a dish wand (the kind that you fill with soap so you can hand wash without filling the sink) and did feel the need to switch to the non-scratch kind as I worried the regular pads were too abrasive. **If you’ve grown up with coated pots and pans and have never known anything else, do yourself a favor and read the instructions before you start cooking or you will not be happy with this pan.**Value: I bought this as a gift for my husband, who had planned to buy me a much more expensive pan like this, and almost every time we use it he comments how glad he is that I got him this inexpensive option first. We’ve been using it regularly for close to a year and it still looks like new.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 19, 2019', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Excelente producto', 'author': 'Juan Guirigay', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Material de buen calidad, buena construcción. Solo hay que tomar en cuenta que es muy diferente cocinar con acero que con teflon. He visto reseñas que indican que los alimentos se les queda pegado o que se les quema el fondo, esto es por el calor insuficiente, con acero siempre hay que dejarlo calentar un poco mas que el teflon, si no tiene la temperatura adecuada cualquier cosa se le va a quedar pegado, pero demasiado temperatura y se te quema, así que es todo un reto al principio pero una vez que aprendes cual es la temperatura idónea no tendrás ningún problema, todo sea por la salud', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 15, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Its been a great pan.', 'author': 'P. Ford', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I\'ve been using this pan for more than 2 years and its been great. It has a good capacity and cooks evenly, if you know how to cook. I use mine on an induction range surface. Let\'s talk about the "bump" in the middle of the pan so many seemed concerned about. These high spots aren\'t unusual in inexpensive pans, which this one is. If you pay attention, you will probably notice they flatten out when the pan comes up to temperature. Don\'t believe me? Go ahead and sear up some steaks or fry some chicken, or whatever. Then remove the food and add water, or wine to deglaze the pan. You\'ll notices that the operation goes quite smoothly. If you want a pan this size that sits flat and doesn\'t have a "bump", you\'ll need to spring for a professional 7-layer sauté pan. A good 5-layer can be had in the $400.00 range, but even those have the same "flaw". All in all, this is a huge bang for the buck!', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 15, 2023', 'is_verified': True}]

title: Cuisinart MultiClad Pro 10" Open Skillet, Inch, Non Stick Stainless Steel
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Fantastic non stick Pan', 'author': 'THOMAS O. MCCUTCHEON', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Cuisinart pans are the only truly NON STICK frying pans I have found. I have used a 12" Cuisinart frying pan multiple times per day. Never had anything stick yet. From fried eggs to steak, nothing sticks and is easy to clean. I needed this 10" pan for my induction cook top and as normal, the pan works great. If you think ckeap pans will do what you want, just remember that you get what you pay for. Cuisinart may cost a little more but the quality can\'t be beat. I will never buy any other pans but Cuisinart. I recommend this product to anybody that wants non stick pans.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 29, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Awesome Pan', 'author': 'Mike', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This is my second Cuisinart MultiClad pan (the other is a monster 12-inch skillet). It is well made, heats evenly, and just feels good to use. My only complaint, and this is with just about any skillet I have ever used, is that the handle is fasten so close to the rim of the pan, that it's difficult to clean in that one spot. Aside from that, it's been great, and I'll probably get another in a smaller size to complete the set.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States August 16, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars So great I bought a replacement set once the initial ones were retired after 6 years', 'author': 'TexApolis', 'rating': 5, 'content': "My fiance is a professional chef and I am quite a competent cook myself, and these pans outperform the set of All Clads that she was using. A much more justifiable buy than the HexClads I have also picked up, which have their own purpose. The non-stick is the best we have used, and these things can hold up to the abuse of being lazy with dishwashing cycles. My first set lasted nearly 6 years of cooking for my family plus some home work for my fiance's meal prep business, and I finally replaced them after the non-stick coating started to peel off of the top edges a little. Surprisingly the price only increased only ~20% over that time, and the price to performance and durability here can't be beat in my experience. Hopefully these will still be available when we need another replacement set another 5+ years down the road.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 21, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '1.0 out of 5 stars Non stick coating melts and delaminates from the rim after 6 weeks or less. See other reviews, pics.', 'author': 'SFJ', 'rating': 1, 'content': 'The nonstick coating melted back from the edge after 6 weeks of use (a dozen times of use). See pic. I had to accept the $65 loss.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 29, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars High quality; multiclad provides excellent heat distribution', 'author': 'Skeptic', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'High quality product; multiclad provides excellent heat distribution. But I wanted nonstick, and this pan delivers. My eggs cook to perfection and slide right out onto the plate, and no marring or scarring of my cooktop.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 1, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Pan Fan', 'author': 'James', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Love this pan, I have purchased several of these pans and they are easy to care for and last a long time.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 4, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect', 'author': 'Rebecca', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'Perfect size, fantastic quality..Exceeded expectation.. cool touch handle... Nothing to dislike...', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States December 8, 2023', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars I believe this to be the best nonstick pan I have ever cooked with', 'author': 'J. Sherwood', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I bought this to replace my 10" Circulon Unison frying pan that is about 5 years old. I cook a lot and would consider myself a serious home chef. I chose this pan after using the 8" nonstick frying pan and 12-pc Multi-Clad Pro set at my vacation house since 2012. I believe this to be the best nonstick pan I have ever cooked with. Better than Circulon Unison nonstick. Better than Analon Professional Nonstick. And slightly better than the LeCrueset Stainless Steel nonstick. Generally, the Cuisinart MCP cookware is excellent and I would say it comes close to the AllClad TriPly in my main home of which I have an extensive collection and have invested $$$$. The MCP is lighter for those who struggle with heavier pans however still has excellent conductivity on my gas ranges. I have seen feedback saying the handles were loose--Not the case with all the pieces of MCP I have purchased since 2012. Also seen a couple of buyers talking about discoloration--again NOT the case with mine and I cook like a chef using gas burners. I suspect that people probably had their burners too high despite the instructions. As with my high end AllClad, the Cuisinart MCP has excellent and even conductivity so pams get hot fast over medium high heat. I rarely have to use a high flame to cook anything or bring a pot to boil. So I have not seen any discoloration on my MCP pans and I am a serious cook! They clean up nicely in the dishwasher using Finish tabs for detergent. Trust me as an AllClad guy for 20 years--the Cuisinart MultiCladPro is a great economic alternative to very expensive AllClad if you don\'t cook enough to justify the investment of $$$$$ for AllClad. I have recommended Cuisinart MCP to my friends and realities with my high regards.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 10, 2016', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Enough mass to avoid overheating, I hope. ;-)', 'author': 'blank_by_design', 'rating': 4, 'content': "Some people in my household can only cook on the highest heat. 🤷\u200d♂️ The 'classic series is a little too light. This line seems much better for even heating. With less hot spot in the center, maybe the nonstick will last longer. But already I see the butter is not instantly browning before I can get an egg in there! The handle fits my hand better. Subjectively, I like the eased lip of this pan better than the thin ones.And it goes in the DISHWASHER!! Yeah!! No fussy anodized b.s. Win!", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States April 8, 2022', 'is_verified': True}]

title: 12-Inch Hybrid Tri-Ply Stainless Steel Sauté Pan,Non-stick Frying Pan with Lid,Skillet,Induction Chef's Pan,Heavy Duty and Oven Safe.（Detachable Handle）
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Great pan', 'author': 'TIA LEDFORD', 'rating': 5, 'content': "This pan is deep and non stick. It's been a great pan. Having a lid is great too.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 30, 2024', 'is_verified': True}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Love it!', 'author': 'Ajax', 'rating': 5, 'content': "I've been using this pan for a few weeks now and am very impressed with it. It has a no stick design that I have never experienced before and it was eager to see it in action. I'll be darned if it actually works! Even more so, I'm able to use metal utensils without worrying about scratching anything up! I'm very excited to get larger sized to use it more.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 3, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars An Ok Hybrid Pan', 'author': 'BiDudeWhoReviews', 'rating': 4, 'content': "Comparing this to Hex-CladFirst, the instructions are a bit lengthy and tend to be over translated. More info than you need.Washing before use, I just did what was recommended for my Hex-Clad. (Scotch Bright NON SCRATCH sponge with warm soap and water) I did this a few times and it was fine. No black residue like other's have mentioned. I then did a simple seasoning. (A little oil and heated the pan on high). Wiped the oil out with a paper towel and the pan was ready to go.This heats up/cools just like my hex-clad and I was able to try it on gas and induction.The one thing to remember with all pans is making sure they get to the right temperature before adding food. Skipping this can cause certain foods to stick.We've cooked a few dozen items in this since owning it, but it's really my go to for a small breakfast of Potatoes, eggs and chorizo.I would say if you're in the market for hybrid pans, do your research first. Make sure you're comfortable with functionality and requirements before moving forward.If you simply want a non stick pan to quickly cook things without taking care of them, these type of pans are probably not for you.A keeper for me.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 5, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Pan lover', 'author': 'Kristen', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'I really like this pan! Washes well (I’ve only hand washed) and the “diamond” bottom is lovely. I just wish it was bigger! A+', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States March 5, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars Heats Quick and Well Designed.', 'author': 'Jeremy W.', 'rating': 5, 'content': 'This is a well-made cooking pan that I\'ve put to use on a few steaks, eggs, and cheese sandwich or two. I\'m not much on cooking but compared to the default induction pans I have in the kitchen; this beats them by a mile as far as construction and heating up quickly and evenly goes.Pros:-Well-made material. It certainly looks and feels better than others I\'ve seen and the handle isn\'t some flimsy thing that\'s going to break off easily.-Heats up quickly and evenly. Very few if any cool spots on the pan while using an induction stovetop. The cheaper pots and pans I have always had some spot that wouldn\'t heat up right and it was noticeable.-Can be used on any kind of cooking surface Gas, electric, induction, etc. it has you covered.Cons: (or things to take note of)-It will tell you in the manual about needing to apply some oil or something to keep things from sticking. So, maybe not entirely "non-stick" if you just throw something in there from the start, but I\'ve had no problem with anything sticking and cleaning it off after use is hardly more than rinsing it off.-They state that a wooden cooking utensil is best to avoid scratching/damaging the surface. It\'s durable but you can still scratch it (and any pan) if you are using metal utensils.-You\'ll likely want to read the pamphlet regarding the manufacturing oils that could be on it. I followed one suggestion and boiled some vinegar and water in the pan and then wiped it down. It hasn\'t had any weird flavors or odors, but you might want to do the same regardless.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 7, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '3.0 out of 5 stars Not very non-stick', 'author': 'Alex Smith', 'rating': 3, 'content': "The pan is nice and heavy duty, it feels quite sturdy. My favorite thing is that the lid fits nicely, so many pans don't have that much it seems. What I didn't realize was that the design you see in the pan is textured, and I assume that is a part of why it isn't specifically very non-stick. It cooked the food I've had in it nicely, but depending on what it is, I don't feel like I can use this pan for items that are more delicate (eggs for instance).", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 25, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars This pan has become our go to', 'author': 'Honest reviews only', 'rating': 5, 'content': "It's not perfect. Things do get stuck a little bit. But it's worth it because it doesn't have the toxic coating on it. We've used metal utensils on and have been using this for a few months and it doesn't have a scratch. We fry eggs and cook small portions of food in it. Works really good. Easy to wash.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States February 29, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars A solid high quality product', 'author': 'Philip Wright', 'rating': 5, 'content': "So for this pan lives up to its description.Overall diameter is just short of 9 inches.The bottom is flat and it is induction ready.It has an aluminum handle which is securely riveted to the pan and it did not get hot in my tests, using an induction cook top. The glass top is also of high quality, with the handle secured by two screws and it has a small vent hole to allow steam to escape.I tested it with eggs and sausage patties, (several times) first heating it up, as with most non-stick pans, & it performed very well. Just wiped it clean with a paper towel.It has a bit of weight but is easily handled because the handle is very user friendly.I was a bit sketchy about the textured surface & I'm not sure why it is textured but it seems to be OK.At this time I cannot say how long the non-stick surface will last & only time will tell.It does spread the heat very well and that is good to prevent hot spots.It is a little pricey so I was finicky in this review, demanding near perfection & so far it has passed every test I've done. Only longevity cannot be determined so I will update if necessary.As always, this is an honest & unbiased review based on my personal experience.Highly recommended.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 7, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': "4.0 out of 5 stars Simple non-stick 'Hex-Clad-like' pan", 'author': 'Phil', 'rating': 4, 'content': "I've had this product for approximately one week and with anything new, it all works great. Questions related to durability can only be answered in time. This 8-inch non-stick, stainless steel pan heats quickly and evenly distributes heat. I've stir-fried vegetables and pan-fried eggs with no sticking or burning. Eggs slide gently around the pan while cooking with a gentle olive oil coating. There's no need to 'season' this pan at all.For a small pan, it is weighty and dense. The pan well is deep and coated with a non-stick material. My daughter asked if it was a hex-clad pan. The steel handle is riveted to the pan's well making it safe for the oven. The accompanying see-through vented lid with a steel handle seals securely over the pan during cooking. It's a nice little pan. I wish I had a larger version. This is a $40 pan at 8 inches. The value lies with the beholder.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 6, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars love this skillet', 'author': 'Shaw', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'Love the skillet. good quality', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 8, 2024', 'is_verified': False}]

Appears to be set at the appropriate value for money that I would expect.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States January 14, 2024', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Great Replacement Pan - No PFOA or PFOS', 'author': 'LynneA', 'rating': 4, 'content': "This pan arrived very well-packed and on first inspection is very impressive. I like the 'extremely durable shot-blasted, hard-anodized exterior that resists scratches like stainless steel' as listed in the description. It looks very good and high quality. There are no harmful chemicals, PFOA or PFOS free so I can feel safer about using it.On the base, the dotted area is what touches the cooktop, the center circle is indented. So you do have good surface area contact with the cooktop. I have a couple of pans that are the reverse of this and the center is what touches the cooktop so virtually no contact and the pans rock straight away.I cooked sausages and scrambled eggs this morning (with a little oil) and had no trouble with anything sticking and cleanup was with a paper towel and then a quick handwash. I wouldn't recommend putting this in the dishwasher as so many of the pods just strip the surface coatings very quickly.My one downside, the oil did go to the outside of the pan, so it is a little high-centered/not entirely flat.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 23, 2023', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Nice Pan', 'author': 'Chris', 'rating': 4, 'content': 'This is a great non-stick pan and a real value. Overall I really like this pan, and I hope to get many years of use from it.', 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States November 7, 2023', 'is_verified': False}, {'title': '4.0 out of 5 stars Good to use in the meantime', 'author': 'MelB76', 'rating': 4, 'content': "I've been needing a frying pan to replace one that I had recently thrown away. There weren't any instructions enclosed, so I needed to refer back to the listing for care instructions, etc. Apparently, it's oven and dishwasher safe, but I always hand wash my cookware. It has a good weight to it and the non-stick surface held up well. It's not the fanciest of frying pans, but it does exactly what I need it to do and good to have as a back-up in my kitchen.", 'timestamp': 'Reviewed in the United States October 21, 2023', 'is_verified': False}]

title: Granitestone Armor Max 5.5 Quart.Sauté Pan with Lid - 12 Inch Non Stick Deep Frying Pan with Lid, Large Frying Pan, Oven Safe Skillet with Lid, Multipurpose Jumbo Cooker, Stovetop/Dishwasher Safe

title: Fadware Nonstick Frying Pan with Lid, Deep Saute Pan 10 Inch for All Cooktops, Induction Deep Frying Pans with Sturdy Stainless Steel Handle, Dishwasher and Oven Safe Pan for Cooking, Black
reviews: [{'title': '5.0 out of 5 stars How did I live without a pan like this?', 'author': 'Dogstar', 'rating': 5, 'content': "Hybrid of a wok and saute pan. When you don't have a lot of room it's nice to have a pan that will do double duty, and allow you to make a lot of one dish meals for two or three people on the stove top! The non-stick surface is perfect. Heat conduction excellent. It works well on my induction hot plate. Cleans up easily, and looks good. Arrived quickly and in good shape well packaged. First thing I made, was transcaucasus cheese bread, followed by omelettes. Neither the eggs nor the cheese stuck at all.
